output: Mr. President, dear colleagues, I apologize once again for my delay.
This year marks the European Year of Intercultural Dialogue.
The involvement of all and the perception that education, knowledge and the interweaving of different cultures is crucial is already a fact taken as acquired.
For this reason, several initiatives related to this year have been carried out by the different areas of action and intervention.
In this context, the Erasmus Mundus program also plays its part. And in this new perspective, the new regulation is already in place.

The Erasmus Mundus program is an important contribution to the creation of centers of excellence in the EU, which will, in a certain way, help to sustain the brain drain to the European Union, as well as representing a significant role in the

In the promotion of European values, together with the nationals of third countries who come here to study and who find in the old continent a cultural and linguistic diversity unparalleled, which function as an attractive and distinct pole from the models existing in the rest of the world.
However, intercultural dialogue has suffered a lot to survive.

The problem of visas for Erasmus students around the world and the frequent difficulties in obtaining and renewing them lead them to live in a situation of semi-clandestinity in the European Union, as they often attend master's degrees but with tourist visas and sometimes expired.
I consider it more appropriate and urgent to seek a solution that allows for the solidity and transparency and effectiveness in the issuance of visas for these students.
Knowledge of the language, which allows cultural perception and mutual coexistence, beyond strictly academic mastery, is also crucial, so we cannot guarantee this premise absolutely.
Lastly, a word of thanks to the deputy Dessart-Nes for the way she conducted the whole process and for the balanced report she produced.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, the authorization for the granting of state aid for the modernization and renewal of the fishing fleets of the ultra-peripheral regions should be possible only until the end of 2009 or should it be in force for an indefinite period?
The particularities of the fishing activity in these regions justify that these aids can be granted beyond 2009 without the marine environment being minimally harmed.
State aid for the modernization and renewal of the fleets of the outermost regions for an indefinite period does not mean permanent and eternal aid.
They would be immediately interrupted if the studies and evaluation of the Scientific Council and the Regional Advisory Councils showed that need.
This is the solution that would best suit the very specific reality of fishing in the ultra-peripheral regions.

The same reasons that justify an exclusive fishing reserve up to 100 miles for the fishermen of each RUP also justify a differentiated treatment regarding the aids for the modernization and renewal of the fleet.
Fortunately, at the Fisheries Committee headquarters, the best solutions were found to address the particularities of fishing in the ultra-peripheral regions. Thank you very much.

Thank you very much, Mr. President. Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner Almunia, Mr. President of the Eurogroup, I would like to congratulate not only the rapporteurs but also the Commission for the initiative of having made this text, the balance of the 10 years of the Economic and Monetary Union.
It is a strategic text and this analysis was fundamental.
The euro, as it was said here today, is an undeniable success.

From Lisbon to Helsinki, from Dublin to Bratislava, the euro has shown resilience and solidity, even during the serious turbulence we have witnessed, and it is clearly important that the borders of this club be expanded.
But the times we live in daily test the solidity of the European project in many other dimensions.
The euro, as I said, is a central instrument for the functioning of the financial system.

However, the text itself of the Commission clearly points to the fundamental conclusion that neither the growth of the real economy nor convergence, in either social or spatial terms, accompanied this success.
On the contrary, the Commission clearly concludes that the disparities have worsened sharply during the decade of operation of the single currency.
This divergence affects regions of my country, in particular, the North of Portugal, but also other regions of member countries.
The impacts of the single monetary policy, namely the very high exchange rate practiced, hit more the regions that are more exposed to international competition and the most exporting regions.
Today, the crisis that resulted from the deregulation of financial markets is severely affecting the real economy and further worsening the situation of many citizens and many regions.

These regions, which are exposed to international competition, those that depend on small and medium-sized companies, those in which access to credit is more important, are today victims of this process and even threaten depression.
Mr. Commissioner, Mr. President of the Eurogroup, the success of the euro depends on the confidence that European citizens have in it.
The most powerful European countries have already started the process of relaunching the national economy.
We have the particular case of the initiatives that concern the automobile industry.
But in Europe it is more than that.
It has to be much more than the more or less coordinated sum of national policies.
It is time to turn the euro into a central tool of Europe, supporting a robust currency, but also a robust real economy, and to make the euro's operation be accompanied
of mechanisms that guarantee the central objective of achieving social and regional convergence, because it is, it is at the core, it is at the heart of the European project.
The debate on the coordination of economic policies in the Euro area has today an enhanced and undeniable impact and relevance.
But coordinating national policies is not enough.
More is needed.

Having a Lisbon strategy, which is a sum of national initiatives, and a Stability and Growth Pact, which differentially tightens the different countries that use it and that they have to submit to, are limitations to which is added the limited budget that we are exposed to.
Crises generate opportunities.
The monetary union can only be sustained by a convergence of the well-being of the member countries that comprise it, regardless of their citizens, regardless of where they were born.
What other way would we have to mobilize citizens for the single currency?

The Commission must be up to its own diagnosis and that is why we are eagerly awaiting the concrete proposals that the Commission will bring to this Plenary on the next 26th of November and will present to the European citizens.

It is essential that, from this crisis, a new phase of the Union is launched, in which the consolidation and strength of the financial system are accompanied by effective prosperity, made of cohesion and also economic citizenship.

Thank you, Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, dear colleagues. This oral question presented to the European Commission by Gerardo Galeote on behalf of the Regional Development Committee of this Parliament is fully justified and relevant.

In fact, it is necessary to make clear the reasons that lead the Council to block the reform of the Solidarity Fund, as it is not able to reach an agreement on a common position that allows the continuation of the legislative process.
It is difficult to discern the reasons that may underlie the Council's position, except perhaps for petty financial reasons.
Doesn’t the Council want a more agile and immediate response to natural disasters that occur?

The Council does not want this type of standard response to be given to other types of disasters, such as serious industrial accidents, terrorist attacks or serious situations in terms of public health.

It is important that these issues have a clear answer, just as it is also important to clarify what the European Commission thinks about this situation and if it intends to take any measure aimed at unblocking the legislative process.
The value of solidarity must also be fully realized in this area.
Citizens would not understand at all if it were not so.
I would like to say that I wanted to protest against the statement made by Mrs. Luling, which intends to condition the vote of the deputies in this House, and that conditioning does not make sense.

The interpretation that is being made is one that we do not share and it is only in this sense that I would like to ask the colleagues who know what they are dealing with, who know that we are defending other interests, which are the interests of public health and the interest of the citizens and the interest of the countries, to in fact vote in favor of the report. Thank you very much.
Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, for two months now, the political and media agenda has been dominated by the financial and economic crisis.
The referendum in Ireland or the difficulties in the Czech Republic over the Lisbon Treaty almost have no expression in the media.

Don’t you think that now the information and communication strategy of the Commission should be reinforced with the need and urgency of the Lisbon Treaty coming into force, also as a political response to face and overcome the crisis we are living in?
Madam President, Madam Commissioner, dear colleagues, the powers of the world have in their hands the international financial system.
He looked for a handout and it was already too late.
And so, perhaps it is time to solve, right now, another problem that we have been hearing about for decades.
For decades we have heard this music of the ignoble plundering of resources, how many times, as now again in Congo, over the blood of the populations.

I believe it is also time to pursue these companies, to pursue this ignoble trade, to freeze the accounts through which the profits of shame from this mineral resource exploitation circulate and are deposited at the expense of the blood and suffering of the populations.
I don’t understand why these companies are not listed in the same way that we already have a blacklist of terrorist organizations.
And I don't understand why the international community is not able to pursue these businessmen, who are not businessmen, they are real bandits, who put regional and global security at risk.
I encourage the French Presidency and the Commission to lead an international initiative in this sense. Thank you very much.
We heard here today several times that a crisis normally generates an opportunity, and that is true.
And if we want to take advantage of the opportunity that is open to us, the agenda is easy to know.
First of all, we know, at the level of the European Union, the need we have to introduce mechanisms of transparency, regulation and supervision in the financial markets.
It is not necessary for Commissioner Macrivi to launch more consultations, nor is it necessary for the Presidency to analyze and invoke more studies and
More proposals. Just look at the proposals that were timely made by the socialists and that many of them ended up being resumed by this Parliament.
Secondly, internationally, Europe cannot be in the international space in a passive way.

It must be an active agent in the construction of the new international order. It must be the defender of a new architecture that does not leave black holes in the system, as are the tax havens at the moment.
Thirdly, we heard today here the President of the Commission say that there is a reluctance in the coordination of strategies at the level of the different States.
It is true that if we had not heard from many members of the Commission for so long that markets self-regulate, that the State should stay out,
If financial markets had no impact on growth and employment, perhaps there would be a more active and more acting spirit of solidarity at the level of the different countries.
But today, the proposal we have in our hands is a proposal that does not go beyond a first step. If we compare it with the program of China and the United States, on the other hand, it does not...
It does not define clearly enough what the objective is, and the objective has to be employment, and thirdly, because a European program cannot be a sum of national agendas.
Today is the time for us to show the citizens of Europe that Europe is a network of rights, also economic, that protects them in times of crisis in terms of...
solidarity, growth program and support to small and medium-sized companies that, at this moment, are not receiving the results of the interventions that were made at the banking level.
The real economy is exactly that and we are here as Europeans to show the citizens that Europe is here too and above all because of them. Thank you very much.
Mr. President, dear colleagues, it is with particular satisfaction that I present myself before you to present the work done, which was done in conjunction with all in this initiative report.
For me and for all those who collaborated in the development of this process, we can say that we did our job.

To all, in particular to the shadow rapporteurs of the different political groups who have made a great effort to reach compromises with a future, to the staff of regional development, always available, namely Miguel Telcremades and Elisa da Farra.

To the PSE staff, to Lila and to Petros, to the European Commission, which, always represented by the many diverse general directions that such a broad report requires, permanently and closely followed the work and greatly contributed to its successful completion.

To my office, and in particular to Joana Benzinho, to all, my most sincere thank you, in the name of a more harmonious and structured development for the coastal regions and for tourism in the European Union.
The 27 Member States of the European Union together have more than 89,000 km of coastal areas.

This presents a variety of very particular characteristics that, according to their location, are marked either by cosmopolitanism, if we are talking about cities like Lisbon, Copenhagen or Stockholm, or by

because of the difficulties of being in peripheral or ultra-peripheral regions, with problems of connections to large urban centers or with accelerated contexts of desertification, such as Algarve, Liguria, the Canary Islands or Madeira.
In one way or another, everyone identifies with the notion of coast and coastal zone and lives daily with the advantages and disadvantages that are associated with them.
According to available data, by 2010, about 75% of the world's population will live in coastal areas.
According to the circuits and relations between them, we define as the 50 km in a straight line that go from the coast line to the interior areas.
Yes, regions and not maritime strips, detached from an integrated vision, which these matters so lack and which our ancestors would also subscribe to.
Here, this population will be concentrated in search of opportunities and economic synergies, and in many cases, with the expectation that these will revolve around tourism.
Thus, the evident need for a pragmatic and integrated view of the impact of tourism in coastal areas took over our minds and led us to get to work.

In the current context of financial crisis, in which the impact on the real economy becomes increasingly insurmountable, tourism appears as a sector with enormous potential to be directly or indirectly affected in a brutal way.

The regions that, for their development, have a crushing or total dependence on this, see their activity threatened and look to the future with distrust. Especially because tourism is not currently a competence of the European Union.
However, coordinated measures can and should be taken and the spirit in which the Lisbon Treaty was infused reflects this same trend.
However, waiting until the moment the treaty comes into force to start acting is to wait for the phase in which we will cry over spilled milk.
The political and tourist activity present and the fragile reality of the regions that depend on it demand urgent and effective action from us.

The fact that these are structurally dependent areas on tourism, as a job promoter, despite many times being seasonal work, this labor-intensive activity cannot be overlooked in a context of pressure on urban areas and unemployment.

For this very reason, this report that we now bring you, which was already of the utmost opportunity and urgency when the Regional Development Commission of this House decided to promote it, now assumes that it must be seen as a priority for the European Commission and for the European Council.

Priority, yes, to the innumerable initiatives that this incorporates, as well as those that it assumes its express support and that have already been conveyed by other institutions, in parallel with the measures taken in the emergency plan.

of the Commission, among which I highlight the review of the Globalization Adjustment Fund, in which the issues associated with this sector, which is the shock to which it is subject at this moment, must obviously be included.

It is crucial to ensure the development of new segments of the economy in these coastal areas, while guaranteeing their social and environmental sustainability and promoting the real integration of different sectoral policies, such as the maritime sector, transport,

energy, the cohesion instruments on the ground, the new quality products policy that the CAP revision incorporates with the announcement of the Health Check report and the new tourist products in these coastal areas, taking into account their crucial contribution to the European economy.
The implementation of an appropriate and holistic vision for this policy should be a reality in the short term in the European Union.

And to conclude, Mr. President, only with a clear articulation of these instruments and a rapid and effective action involving all the partners and stakeholders already on the ground, we will be able to ensure that we will have in the European Union a sustainable and promising coastal tourism sector. Thank you very much.
Mr. Commissioner, Madam Minister, e-justice is an important step in access to law, justice and courts.
I want to congratulate myself for the initiative, to congratulate the rapporteur and the French Presidency.

The e-Justice was one of the projects under discussion and it fell to Portugal, during its presidency, to lead the development and implementation of the pilot project that will allow all citizens to access services from other Member States in a simpler, cheaper, more comfortable way and in their own language.
This multilingual portal should be designed to serve citizens and companies seeking legal support and basic legal advice on cross-border legal issues.
The e-justice must be coordinated and managed by a responsible unit, which will also coordinate the contributions of the various Member States and their articulation with that responsible unit.
E-justice will serve the citizen and will strengthen our democracy.
I congratulate you on the launch of the portal in December 2009. Thank you very much.
Mr. President, Mr. Barroso, colleagues, I congratulate the work of Carlos Coelho, of the Martin Roury chair and of the remaining chairs.
In December 2004, the Council adopted a regulation that establishes standards for the security features and biometric data of passports and travel documents issued by Member States.
Now, we had the need to take new steps in order to combat the kidnapping and trafficking of children.
The use of passports by children, according to the principle of one person, one passport, can be a fundamental means of winning this difficult and important fight.
In my country, Portugal, the collection of fingerprints from children from the age of 6 is already a practice with a long tradition, which perhaps for that reason does not cause me any objection.
As a defender of the European cause, I believe that, in this matter, it is important to have harmonization.

It comforts me to know that Member States, such as Portugal, which have long defined the minimum age as 6 years to proceed with the collection of fingerprints, will not have to change their national legislation.
I must emphasize that the security of the passports that are being reinforced today is not limited to the existence of a passport.

The passport, by itself, corresponds to an increase in the security level, which goes from the presentation of the documents necessary for the issuance of passports, followed by the collection of biometric data, up to the verification and matching at the border control posts.
This report is one more step to affirm the rights of the person and to guarantee their safety.
Mr. President, first of all, I would like to greet the rapporteur Alexander Lambsdorff and the shadow rapporteurs, with a special mention to Barbara Weiler.
Dear colleagues, I believe it is essential that we move forward in the direction of integrating the national defense markets and even the strategic coordination of their productions.

We must effectively advance with the necessary specificities and precautions in the sense of applying the essential rules of the internal market to the defense industries, increasing transparency in the tenders that are organized and in the contracts that are signed involving the Member States of the European Union.
But at the same time, we must help in the development of the conditions that allow for greater competitiveness of European equipment and products in world markets.

Commissioner Macrivi, it seems important to me that this directive can ensure progress in the legal framework regarding public contracts in the areas of defense and security, advancing the construction of the internal market.

internally and respecting, obviously, the interests and rights of the Member States, especially in the field of security, and namely those that manufacture weapons, ammunition, and security equipment, such as, for example, my own country.

Mr. President, I would also like to highlight the provisions that allow for easier access of small and medium-sized enterprises to this market, namely through the improvement of subcontracting rules and the perspective of advancing with greater impact and depth in the decision-making process.

industrial for the creation of a true European market in the defense industries, which can also contribute to strengthening research and development not only in the defense industries but also in a set of European industries that benefit from the development of the defense industries.
Lastly, I believe that we can refer to the obvious articulation between defense industries and the Union's foreign policy.
But I would like to quote, regarding the deed, a recent intervention, translating a classic Roman saying: "If you want peace, prepare for war."

The European Union, as it is almost a peaceful superpower, we call these industries defense industries and not war industries, because we want peace and not war, and that is why we also need defense industries.
Mr. Vice-President Barroso, I agree with you, I agree with you on the dissatisfaction.
In fact, we must be satisfied with the set of measures, which are vast.
The truth is that irregular immigration continues to Europe, human trafficking continues, there are areas where there is a lot of...
Immigration, namely in the Mediterranean and towards Italy. France has advanced with a set of important bilateral cooperations, but other Member States have not done so.
It is necessary for the Commission to continue, without losing enthusiasm, this policy of cooperation and aid to the United States.
President, Madam Commissioner, I will try to put the issues in a very synthetic way.
First point, the issue of the European Union's special monitoring mechanism for the tests ended, as was said here, on December 31, 2008.
It is necessary, Madam Commissioner, to publish in a timely and routine manner the statistical data on imports, exports and prices, similar to what happens in the United States.
Without this data, the European Union is unable to react to possible unfair practices and the Commission itself is unable to define its strategy.
I was drawing his attention to this, just like other colleagues have already done.
Secondly, producing within the European Union increasingly requires compliance with safety standards, social standards, and environmental standards.
The RITS, for example, is a recent initiative that creates even more constraints for us.
It is important that the Commission has a clear strategy and that it is perceptible and subject to monitoring so that imported products have identical requirements.
How are these aspects being properly taken into account in the free trade agreements that are in progress?
And what about the Meidín? Can the Meidín actually help to solve this issue?
Third point. The European Union launched an economic recovery plan to combat the current crisis.
What role will trade policy play in this context?

At this moment, what is the Commission preparing to do when a series of other countries, such as China, begin to proliferate the launch of increasingly non-tariff barriers so that our European imports do not access the Chinese markets?

What proposal do you have regarding the updating or adjustment of the Globalization Adjustment Fund, as well as the support available under the Structural Funds, to improve the immediate situation of the European textile industry?
Last question, finally, in fact, will the crisis we are going through finally make the Commission sensitive to the devastating impact on the European economy of an overvalued euro?
How can the Commissioner raise awareness, I'm finishing now, raise awareness among her colleagues and the entities that deal with European monetary policy in the sense of rebalancing? Thank you.
For us, it is clear that we must applaud Obama's decision, the decision to close Guantanamo, to prohibit torture, illegal interrogations and the suspension of military trials.
However, dear colleague who is no longer present, Portugal and the Portuguese Socialist Government have no sense of guilt.
The Portuguese socialist government did not collaborate with the Bush administration, quite the contrary.

It was precisely now with the Portuguese administration, with the Portuguese government, with the initiative of Minister Luís Amado, that the possibility and the duty of the European Union and the democratic countries to welcome and receive the detainees without a formal charge in Guantánamo was triggered.

This is what is truly important, this is what should be highlighted as an example to be followed by the remaining Member States of the European Union. How important it is that tomorrow the resolution is approved by the set of parties that make up this Chamber so that, in unity, the decision can have more strength.
Mr. President, thank you very much to colleague Napolitano for the excellent report.

Fourteen years after Barcelona and five years after the first Euro-Mediterranean Parliamentary Assembly, we have a Union for the Mediterranean, with economic power, with parliamentary power, with civil society, with heads of government deciding together.
All with the desire to do more and better in a territory where 720 million citizens represent a potential for development and peace for the world.
To only look at the economic and business side is a clear mistake.

Naturally, responding to growth crises requires political response, but responding to humanitarian crises, emergency situations and military crises, such as the one experienced at the end of 2008 and beginning of 2009, is crucial.
Politicians and citizens must provide answers to the world’s problems.
The world asked for answers and months later we are still, citizens and politicians, designated in a platform such as the Union for the Mediterranean, late to react.
I hope that, at the very least, this moment has served to learn and move forward, because only those who make mistakes learn, but moving forward in the speed of the reaction is absolutely crucial.

The interest in the approval of this directive, of this proposed directive, lies essentially in the way it can contribute to boosting economic activity at the local level and support actions at the social level.

The application of a reduced rate is of great importance in the housing sector, both in construction and in renovation, allowing Member States that adopt it to reduce the respective cost for the end user.

The provision of local services, namely by small companies, can also benefit from this reduction in the VAT rate, ensuring and generating more and better employment through the promotion of the consumption of goods and services, thus stimulating the economy itself.
The restaurant activity, which is fundamental for the good functioning of local economies and the increase in tourism, can thus benefit greatly at the local level with this reduction in VAT.
These services, dear colleagues, should not circulate in the European internal market, which will help to reduce the reservations of some Member States already verified in the Council's plan.
Therefore, I cannot agree with the extension of this reduced tax on equipment, whatever the pretext.

The prudent way in which this proposal should be dealt with in the European Parliament should not give pretext to governments that have some reservations about the European Commission's proposal to use, in practice, the right of veto that European legislation still lacks in fiscal matters.
Thus, here we must prudently reject changes that make little sense and only make it difficult to accept the text.
As already mentioned here, not only is the best the enemy of the good, but whoever wants everything, loses everything.
This directive proposal is important not only for the strengthening of local economies, but also corresponds to the ambitions repeatedly expressed by various Member States.
We then supported the Commission's proposal as it was presented. This was, in fact, the meaning of the vote, as agreed by the Internal Market and Consumer Protection Committee.

I praise the work of the rapporteurs and call for the approval of this proposal in the exact terms in which it came from the Commission and was voted on in the Parliamentary Commission of the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. Thank you very much.
I have the floor to disagree with my colleague Edith Estrela, and that is precisely what motivated me to speak, when she caricatured the intentions of the Czech Presidency.
Nobody wants to send women home. The problem is that there are women who want or would like to stay at home.
There are even associations that seek to defend them. Women who are ignored, despised, discriminated against because they want to dedicate themselves to the family and we do not hear them.
And this is a matter of freedom, it is a matter of freedom of choice, which the left likes to invoke so much, but which it forgets here.
It is about respecting or not respecting the freedom of couples to choose their own orientation.
It is about being able to provide those who want to do so with a better quality of life, better quality fatherhood and motherhood.
That is what our society also needs to do.
We will not solve the problems of birth rate and people's happiness with prejudice.
We solve with policies adjusted to reality and to the spontaneous desires of people.
We are not going there with an obsession with the State and with the market.
Let's go with a fair look at the family.
Mr. President, dear colleagues, the difficult situation at Quimonda was aggravated by the emergence of the financial and economic crisis.
The Portuguese government has done everything it deems appropriate and useful to help solve the situation.
And we would like the Bavarian government to also act with a great sense of responsibility in this area.
Saving the Munich facilities will have a decisive impact on the units in Vila do Conde and Dresden.

The Portuguese Minister himself, Manuel Pinho, stated the great interest in making this company viable, which is so important for Portugal and for Europe, referring that Quimonda can be a competitive company at a global level.
Mr. President, the Portuguese Government is maintaining its efforts towards a solution that guarantees the viability of the company.
We hope that the German governments, at the federal and state levels, will effectively engage in solving this problem.
As for me, I would like to emphasize the strategic importance of maintaining this type of industry in European territory.
Let no national or state executive make the mistake of allowing this company to close facilities and liquidate jobs in the Union territory.
Dear colleagues, we understand the need to help restructure the large automobile industry groups, but the Union funds and the energies of the European Commission cannot be exhausted in these aids.

Dear Commissioner, we urge the Commission to support Quimonda, overcoming possible communication failures, and we appeal to Commissioner Vladimir Špidla, with whom we share work ties and political solidarity, and to President Barroso, who will never forget that he is our compatriot and of a significant part of Quimonda's workers.

We should highlight, before concluding, that the Portuguese President, Cavaco Silva, in Germany, recently stated that there was a new hope regarding Quimonda. And even though referring to the importance, as it has already been done by colleagues, of the economic sector in which Quimonda operates.
We take into account, therefore, that the Portuguese government is willing to support Quimonda with whatever is necessary, considering the economic dimension of the country.
Ladies and Gentlemen, let us help save Quimonda, time is of the essence.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, we have been talking about the Lisbon Strategy for years. And the times we live in may not be the most appropriate to talk about the Lisbon Strategy, but we undoubtedly need a strategy.
A strategy that responds to the difficulties and challenges that the current crisis presents to us.
And that is what we also expect from the Commission.

It is essential that the Commission does not distance itself from this matter and, instead, has the capacity to coordinate actions with the governments of Portugal and the governments of Germany and the German states.

It is essential to keep in mind that this is an industry, as already mentioned here, that interests Europe, for its quality and value, for the research it develops, for the environmental quality that is also associated with it. And it is essential that the Commission does not step back.
I subscribe to the invitation made by my colleague Peneda for the Commissioner and the Commission to move to Portugal.
It is essential that the Commission is aware that, at this time, Europeans are looking at Europe and expect answers from European authorities. They need to feel that European authorities are close.

European citizens do not understand a Europe that washes its hands. Instead, they want a Europe that has the audacity to get its hands dirty and to get to work, helping them to overcome difficulties. Thank you very much.

Mr. President, thank you very much. I also join my words to the tributes to Jamonet, but I asked for the floor to greet the President for the statement he made on the occasion of the European Day in memory of the victims of terrorism.
It was on my proposal that, five years ago, we adopted this orientation, which the Council consecrated in a meeting on March 25, following the tragic attacks in Madrid.
But my intervention was an appeal.

The Parliament has always been faithful to the celebration of this date, but unfortunately this date has not yet had, in the set of European institutions and Member States, the projection it should have.
I believe that the celebration of this date is one of the most important instruments we have to honor the victims, as the President did, but also to raise the level of public awareness.
I know that there are celebrations in Madrid today, but not much more.
And so, the appeal I make to the Commission, to the Czech Presidency, is that all Member States celebrate this date with dignity in the future. Thank you very much.
Ladies and gentlemen, dear colleagues, the crisis is deeper than we expected and unemployment will be higher than we predicted.
There are good reasons to suppose that the planned European stimulus is not enough, but it is already clear at this moment that it is taking too long to reach the citizens.
The Parliament's position is strong and clear. It has been and I hope it will continue to be so.
Our objective is to maintain employment and to create new jobs, with cohesion, with solidarity, both territorial and social.
In this moment of crisis, citizens cannot be satisfied with a Europe that does not give them answers, with a Europe that is powerless in the face of the problems they are going through.
What is the Parliament going to ask the Commission?

It naturally asks, through these reports, that it coordinates the national interventions. It asks that it uses all the means that are currently at its disposal to intervene and gives it all the conditions as a budgetary entity for this to happen.

He asks him to launch a clear European initiative for employment and tells him that it is important to have an agenda with a calendar to implement the measures to regulate the financial market, as well as to get the credit to the real economy.
But what is asked of the Council?
It is asked of the Council that, above all, it finds the political will that is at the heart of the construction of the European project.
The European Union is competition, but it is also cohesion and solidarity.
And there cannot be a single market without this guarantee, solidarity and cohesion.
That is why we all delegated, at the European level, the national autonomies that we had before joining this project. Thank you very much.

Madam President, Madam Commissioner, anyone who visits Sub-Saharan Africa easily recognizes, in most countries, the enormous weakness of their health systems and the extremely negative impact that this weakness has on the lives and health of the populations that those services should serve.
The indicators that are continuously released at the international level do not stop confirming it.
And in this sense, it is absolutely disturbing the notion that simple gestures and practices, not even very elaborate, nor particularly expensive, could be enough to save many lives.

European financial support may be crucial in this regard. And we cannot fail to keep in mind that cooperation in the health area is truly strategic and directly crosses not only one of the Millennium Goals, but many of the Millennium Goals.

Now, the Court of Auditors considered that, I quote, the community funding in favor of the health sector has not increased since the year 2000 in the proportion of its total aid to development, despite the commitments assumed by the Commission regarding the Millennium Goals and the health crisis in Sub-Saharan Africa.
"End of quote."

And it recognized, I quote again, the Commission contributed significantly, through its funding, to the establishment of the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria, but did not give the same attention to strengthening health systems, which was supposed to be one of its priorities.
End of quote.

According to the Court, this happened, I repeat, because the Commission did not have enough experience in the health field to ensure that the funding for the aid granted to this sector was used in the best way.
End of quote.
This is, therefore, a strong challenge that the Court of Auditors launches directly to the European Commission and that I support.
On our part, I want to reiterate the same challenge, now supported by the objectivity of these data and this evaluation.
Health services are already part of our development aid priorities, but they should be an even greater part of them, and deserve an increase in their funding.

Optimizing the way aid is provided, taking into account the apparently antagonistic needs of coordination in its management and proximity to the beneficiary populations, is to provide a service that can save many lives.
The European Commission cannot fail to respond positively to this challenge and it is in this sense that I exhort it.
Colleague Boas, just a moment ago, gave us a touching speech here and was able to put faces, human faces, on the dry coldness of these numbers from the Court of Auditors.
The challenge for us, Madam Commissioner, is for our cooperation to be able to put a look of joy and hope on these same faces.
And for that, Madam Commissioner, it is essential that the numbers in the health area in our cooperation are different.
Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, dear colleagues, once again, for sad reasons, we are discussing here the situation in Guinea-Bissau, which is a truly painful situation.
It is a country that has been living in chronic instability for many years, which tried a path to democracy in the early 90s,

Nothing went well, there was a coup d'état, a small internal war, and they live in great instability, political, military, tensions, deep rivalries, and now recently also the very worrying presence, increasingly evident to all observers, of interest in drug trafficking.
We strongly condemn these attacks, the death by bomb of Chief of Staff Tagme Na Wai, and also the assassination in particularly barbaric, if not savage, terms of President Nino Vieira.
Regardless of their past, we express our solidarity with their families, with the people of Guinea-Bissau, and we regret and severely condemn these attacks.
We wish for a return to normality. And the lesson I take from this, and which I would like to emphasize in the resolution, is that impunity is not the solution.
In the past, regarding the murder of Samora Machel and General Alverício Seabra, how did they turn a blind eye so that the guilty were not found and brought to justice?
It is obvious that this is not the solution.
And therefore we must make it clear to the State of Guinea-Bissau that those responsible must be found, the guilty must be brought to justice and we must provide all the help that is necessary.

I would also like to draw attention, to conclude, to the concern with the presence of drug trafficking throughout the region, the risk that this also represents for the European Union and the shocking presence, due to its evidence, in Guinea-Bissau.
I would also like to appeal to strengthen, in this context, the relationship with Cape Verde.

We have established a special partnership with Cape Verde. Cape Verde has very close relations with Guinea, a great knowledge, but it is also very vulnerable. And this is also essential for our own European security.
Therefore, the intensification of the special partnership with Cape Verde is also very important in this context. Thank you very much.
Madam President, dear colleagues, I would like to thank you all for the work done.

The three lines defined in the Green Book, concentration, interconnection and cooperation, can provide solutions to some obstacles to the harmonious development of the Union, namely the negative effects associated with

The concentration of economic activity, the inequalities in terms of access to markets and services resulting from distance and the divisions imposed by the borders between Member States, especially the most disadvantaged ones, but also between regions.
We must therefore promote the improvement of synergies between these policies with methods of effective evaluation of their territorial impact.

For this reason, it has always defended the definition of additional qualitative indicators with the objective of improving the design and execution of the corresponding policies on the ground, taking into account the different territorial specificities.
For now, the GDP continues to be the only criterion for eligibility to receive support from the structural funds.

However, this definition of additional indicators and the implementation of territorial evaluations should not be the source of more bureaucracy or more delays, but rather the simplification in the application of new policies and actions to support territorial cohesion.
The fifth Calari report, and to conclude, Mr. President, makes a specific reference to the transition regions located between the convergence regions and the competitiveness and employment regions.
It is necessary to pay attention to the fact that these regions need a clearer statute, with more security and stability for their development. Thank you very much.

Madam Commissioner, dear colleagues, in the context of this great debate on territorial cohesion and the future of economic and social cohesion policy, I could not fail to mention the very specific problem of the ultra-peripheral regions.

Regions that, due to the combination and permanence of a series of geographical factors, reveal a great economic and social vulnerability, particularly felt in a context of severe international crisis, such as the one we are currently experiencing.
I would therefore like to appeal to the European Commission, and in particular to Commissioner Hübner, to pay very special attention to the effects of the current crisis in the outermost regions.

An assessment of these effects in each of the outermost regions, namely in tourism, construction and the increase in unemployment, would be important to allow a specific European response for these regions.

I therefore challenge the European Commission to prepare a European response to the crisis for the ultra-peripheral regions that goes beyond the measures already announced within the scope of the economic and social cohesion policy for the generality of European regions.
A specific European response to the crisis for the regions of the Atlantic.

Mr. President, dear colleagues, in response to the global financial crisis, the European Economic Recovery Plan states that the cohesion policy significantly contributes to public investment by Member States and regions, and should act as a way to recover from the current crisis.
It specifically suggests the adoption of actions in priority areas of the Lisbon Strategy, in order to achieve growth and employment.
All the instruments used aim to achieve this purpose and accelerate the achievement of results.

In this sense, the expansion of the scope of the European Globalization Adjustment Fund and the acceleration of the European Social Fund have a particular responsibility to respond to the multiple social and economic emergency situations that require support.
I am sure that, today as in the past, your action will be all the more effective the more complementary your actions and areas are.

However, since the availability of new funds or new lines of action on the ground was not foreseen, it is particularly important that the European Social Fund be used to its full potential in the fight against unemployment and to rapidly reduce the pressure on competitiveness in the European economy, resulting from the current financial crisis and economic downturn.

I would like to emphasize that the REGI Committee has repeatedly identified simplification as essential for improving the management and implementation of structural funds, as the European Commission now proposes.
However, urgency was dismissed in this matter. And in the adoption of this regulation package, it was taken into account. And this cause never shied away from assuming its political responsibilities.

Therefore, despite many serious views that the particularity of the moment arouses, as well as the guarantees of speed of the process and the real benefit to citizens that the proposal intends, we abstain, for now, from presenting new proposals and amendments.
However, we alert to the need to start, as soon as possible, a process of evaluation of this fund, with a view to a complementary revision to be carried out as soon as possible. Thank you very much.
Madam President, the crisis, among other aspects, allowed to highlight the strong imbalances between the countries of the Eurozone, perhaps the main...
conclusion of the report of the Economic and Monetary Union to 10, but above all the extreme vulnerability of the countries that belong to the European Union but do not belong to the Eurozone.

Hence, the reinforcement of the available means at the European level to support crisis situations of the balance of payments is absolutely indispensable, and hence we welcome the transition from 12 to 25 and from there to 50 million euros of necessary means.
However, it is more important to attack the deep causes of the problems and not only their most evident manifestations.
Today, the enlarged Europe and the Eurozone must reinterpret the meaning of European solidarity and the objectives of cohesion and real convergence.
It is necessary to see in this light what is the capacity of European horizontal policies, but it is also necessary to revisit new financing instruments such as Eurobonds.
Financial assistance to the balance of payments is necessary, but it is far from sufficient to ensure the sustainability of the European project and the European single currency.
Mr. President of the Commission, Mr. Acting President, we are in an unprecedented crisis.

It was not, in fact, the time to discuss internally how to organize ourselves. Therefore, my votes are for the Lisbon Treaty to be quickly ratified so that we can face the world scene united and in solidarity as Europeans.

As for the economic crisis, in the report of which I was the author and which this Parliament approved by a majority, it was admitted that the relaunch plan, meanwhile presented by the Commission, was not enough.
Today we are certain that it is not enough.
A crisis that started as a financial one, extended to the real economy, then to employment and then became a social one.
It is not enough and it is blurred.

Every crisis holds an opportunity. This is the opportunity for the Commission to respond to the real problems of Europeans, through serious financial regulation and not the lighter and piecemeal one that is being proposed.

It is possible, as it is currently happening. Not made of national and individualistic plans, but of a true European initiative. Not through dispersed means, but concentrating on the real challenge that is employment.

In every crisis there is an opportunity. This is the opportunity for the Commission and for Europe to respond to the real problems of European citizens. And I hope that this happens through a new approach to the recovery plan. Thank you very much.

Mr. President, dear colleagues, I would like to express, not only on behalf of the PPE, as has already been done by many deputies, but in particular on behalf of the Portuguese deputies of the PPE, the great satisfaction with the result of the referendum in Ireland.
We believe that this clearly reinforces the development and evolution prospects of the European Union, which creates conditions for a new stage.

We would like to congratulate all those who contributed to the Treaty of Lisbon, in particular the Commission and the Vice-President Commissioner present here, and also, naturally, the Portuguese Presidency of the European Union.

It played a very important role here. And that is why we also want to say that it is with regret that we verify that, despite all these vicissitudes, and still awaiting the position of the Czech Republic, it will be with great joy that the Portuguese will see the name of their capital linked

It is a decisive step in the evolution of the European Union and I would like to say that we can also count on this perspective with another flag, which will also always be the flag of the Portuguese deputies of the PPE, which is the flag of the national parliaments.
We believe that the Lisbon Treaty takes a decisive step towards incorporating the presence of national parliaments in European democracy.

And for this reason, we believe that this dimension, which is the most important dimension of democracy, which is the representative dimension, and not, as we sometimes hear in this Chamber, the referendary dimension, that is,

The fundamental and essential element of democracy is representation and not direct voting. The Lisbon Treaty is also a big step towards increasing the participation of national representative democracies in the European process.
That is why we are very pleased with this decision by the people of Landers.

Mr. President, Madam Minister, Madam Commissioner, dear colleagues, a brief intervention to welcome the historic and broad result of the referendum in Ireland and to highlight the decisive role that Fine Gael and its leader and future Prime Minister of Ireland, Enda Kenny, had in taking the lead in this process.
A process in which the need to bring the European Union much closer to its citizens became very clear.
We are, all of us, the main recipients of all the Union’s actions.
It is essential that everyone is aware of the impact and benefits that Europe has daily in our lives.
Europe is our living space.
What is good for Europe is good for each Member State, is good for its citizens.
This is certainly the case of the Treaty of Lisbon.
With this treaty, it becomes much more evident that one can be, at the same time, a proud and committed national citizen and a staunch defender of the European project.

And the European Union, after a too long debate on its organization and functioning, will be able to focus much more and with new and much more effective instruments on the real problems that Europeans face: competitiveness, growth and employment.
I finish, Mr. President, Madam Minister, with a proposal for future generations.

Considering the information deficit regarding the values, skills, objectives and mode of operation of the European Union, the European Parliament should propose, at the end of compulsory schooling in each Member State, a new discipline of European studies of a compulsory nature.
In an objective, true and concrete way, young Europeans will effectively know our principles, who we are, what we do and where we want to go.

It is through knowledge from a young age that they will understand throughout their lives the potential and the enormous usefulness of the European identity of this unique project of voluntary sharing of sovereignty on a continental scale.

Thank you, Mr. President. Mr. President of the Commission, I begin by congratulating you in this first debate for what this new political control instrument means for the advancement and development of parliamentary democracy in Europe.
It is the European citizens, through their representatives, who benefit.

Considering the most recent developments, the Irish referendum, ratification by Poland and the latest statements by the President of the Czech Republic, I ask what is your assessment of the process of the Lisbon Treaty coming into force.
There have been efforts on the part of the President of the Commission.
And what is the forecast for a possible date for the treaty to come into force? And, on the other hand, to know if, at this moment, and according to this forecast, the Commission...

Have some transition procedures of treaties, from the Treaty of Nice to the Treaty of Lisbon, already been carried out, or is it still in a phase, so to speak, of expectation, therefore, in a phase of waiting to see?

Mr. President of the Commission, having heard this, I would like to know the following: in this phase in which everyone is waiting for the formation of the Commission, what is the perspective that Mr. President has?
It is whether we will have, until the moment of final ratification by the Czech Republic, a caretaker commission or if they will proceed with the appointment of the new commissioners.

Thank you, Mr. President. It is essential that the main objective of the creation of the European External Action Service is to focus the efforts of the European institutions on ensuring the creation of an effective service, capable of articulating, formulating and implementing a European response to the international challenges of the present.
It must still represent more than the parts that constitute it. It must be an added value in relation to the current efforts of the Member States and the European Union.
In this sense, it seems essential to me that what makes the Union specific is at the center of this new reality. And this specificity is the community method.
This is why I give my full support to the Brock report, which defends and safeguards a close articulation between the Commission and the future service.

I created this purpose to highlight two aspects: the importance of close coordination between the President of the Commission and the High Representative, also Vice-President of the Commission, to ensure its effectiveness and good functioning.
Lastly, the need for an alliance between the Parliament and the Commission to combat the intergovernmental drift that is announced and that can compromise the effective functioning of the service.
The Parliament must therefore be vigilant and ensure that the European External Action Service will be a centre of excellence, representative of the best skills in the field of foreign policy.
Thank you, Mr. President. Thank you, Mr. Commissioner. I would like to emphasize the importance of this issue raised by Deputy Galvão, as it is a matter of the most basic justice.

We all know perfectly well that in a pandemic situation of the A flu, it will be the southern countries that will suffer the most with this problem and with the consequences of the proliferation of the virus and not the northern countries.

And we have been watching, year after year, with total passivity, the death of millions of citizens as a result of pandemics that have already been eradicated or have treatment in the Northern countries. An immense list: malaria, dengue, yellow fever, tuberculosis.
We have no limits for this list and we passively watch this problem.

We use the Southern countries effectively as free suppliers of samples of the new strains of the virus so that we can improve treatment in the Northern countries, but we remain without an effective response to these problems. And so, to the questions that were raised, I would like to add a few more.
We want to effectively treat this problem as a public health issue or as a business.
Because if it is a public health problem, we have to ensure equal access to treatment in all regions of the world and for that, efforts have to be more effective.
On the other hand, I would like to ask, and I hope this is not the case, if we are waiting for the vaccine stocks in Europe to become so overstocked.
That the side effects are so negative in this plan, so that we can have an act of generosity and suddenly we start sending the necessary vaccines to the countries in the South.

And lastly, I would just like to ask if the European Union, if we Europeans and the Commission feel comfortable with a system or with a model where the countries in the North deal with pandemics through a prevention model and in the countries in the South they are dealt with as palliatives or just with the leftovers.

Thank you, Mr. President. First of all, I want to express my full support regarding the issue raised by Mr. Royle and, above all, to highlight the underlying issue, the underlying political issue that is at stake here, which has to do precisely with the joint programming of research.

What happened in terms of joint programming on neurodegenerative diseases and, in particular, on Alzheimer's, was that, in the middle of the process, the rules changed. We stopped having a report and started having a resolution, so our capacity for co-decision on this matter was eliminated. We stopped being deputies and became consultants.
And so, I would like to know if at least what we recommend will be taken into consideration or not.
The programming of research activities, regardless of the subject matter, is a political choice, not a technical one. In this sense, the role of Parliament must be valued and reinforced.
It seems to me that defining political priorities means that these must be scrutinized, that they must be transparent, that they must be democratic.
What happened with the process regarding the joint decision and the joint programming of the investigation on Alzheimer's is a process that should not be repeated and if it is repeated...

Please repeat, please notify in advance. I hope that the last thing that can happen to us is that the decisions and recommendations that the Parliament presented on this matter are not taken into account.
Dear, in the last month, the regions of Europe stood out in particular.
The European Week of Regions and Cities has consolidated the position of regions as a fundamental part of the solution in the European response to global challenges.
This was concluded, leaving no room for doubt, by President Durão Barroso, Commissioner Samessky and the hundreds of debates that took place.

Also, at a more specific level, the important meeting of the Conference of Presidents of the Outermost Regions of Europe, which for the first time included the participation of Members of the European Parliament, was a milestone in regional policy in favor of European construction.
The global challenges and the European responses constitute an excellent opportunity for a new strategy for the RUP.

These regions, such as the Azores, besides the permanent constraints that everyone is used to hearing about, present a set of potentialities that confer clear opportunities to achieve our progress and give a clear advantage to Europe in new essential domains to respond to global challenges.

And I say this so that the President of the Commission puts an end to the Palaciano coup that the Commission's no paper indicates was being prepared while we, deputies and European citizens, were making an apology for the ratification of the Treaty of Lisbon and its importance in the defense of the cohesion of the territory.
First of all, I would like to greet the rapporteurs, namely Mr. Martin and also Mr. Corbett, and say that, as a member of the PPE, I basically agree with the proposed amendments to the rules.
I would like to highlight the point that I consider important here and that has not been brought up tonight, which is the point of the national parliaments.

The democratic reinforcement of the European Parliament undoubtedly results from this regulation and the Treaty of Lisbon, but European democracy also results from the connection to the national parliaments.
And what this regulation, this proposal, is now doing is precisely creating these two democratic legitimacies, strengthening democracy.

On the one hand, democracy resulting from the instruments of the European Parliament, its control instruments, its legislative capacity, and on the other hand, the democratic collaboration of the national parliaments through different instruments.
And so here I am, so to speak, totally in tune with the proposals made.
I do not agree with colleague Duff when he understands that we should leave for later the introduction of mechanisms for relating to the national parliaments.
I believe that we can do it already, in light of the Treaty of Lisbon, and that this is very important.
I would also like to say that I support the proposal of my colleagues Sayer and Brock regarding representation in the COSAC and, finally, that I am
I am entirely in agreement with the observations made here by colleague Brock and other colleagues on the primacy of Parliament and of the deputies in relation to the services of Parliament.

Thank you very much, Mr. President, Madam President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues. I congratulate the rapporteur colleague for the work developed in this report and for her intervention a little while ago.
This new microfinancing instrument will allow the granting of microcredit to small businesses and to people who have lost their jobs and want to create their own business and their own job.
This is very important in a period in which it is expected that the economic crisis will result in the loss of 3.5 million jobs only in the European Union.
As a consequence of the economic downturn, banks have stopped granting loans for job and business creation and access to credit is more difficult at a time when it should be more accessible.
Now, this new microfinancing tool will go against the current trend of restricting access to credit, facilitating the obtaining of funds necessary for the launch of new companies and new jobs.
The European Commission's proposal aims to reallocate 100 million euros from the Progress Programme budget to this funding instrument.
We cannot agree with this proposal.
The financial and economic crisis is also a social crisis.
Thus, the reallocation of resources from the Progress that targets the most vulnerable groups is not at all the most appropriate solution.
For this reason, the creation of a separate budget line to finance this instrument is supported, as well as an increase in the allocation to 150 million euros.

We also agree on the need to clarify in the legislation itself that the target group are the vulnerable groups that have difficulty entering or re-entering the labor market and that face the threat of social exclusion.
Thus, the reference to specific groups should be removed.
Finally, we highlight that it is essential that people have financial support and also adequate training. Thank you very much.

Thank you very much, Mr. President. I would like to start by congratulating the Swedish Presidency and, in particular, Prime Minister Reinfeldt, both on behalf of the PPE and on behalf of the Portuguese delegation of the PPE.
Our balance of the Swedish presidency is of a practically absolute success, essentially in four fundamental areas.

The first one in the institutional area, the contribution of the Swedish Presidency for the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, for the very successful election of the President of the Commission.
For, namely, all the issues of ratification associated with ratification, it was extremely professional and was at the level of what is expected, the best practices of the European Union.
Naturally, for a country like Portugal, which played a decisive role in the approval of the Treaty of Lisbon, the contribution of the Swedish Presidency is invaluable.
A second point is the climate agenda, where, naturally, the Commission's work was also extremely important.
We must say that, from my point of view and from the point of view of many PPE deputies, it is in the area of climate change that the European Union has had the most success.
It is at the forefront of global combat and this is due to the effort of both the Swedish Presidency and, in particular, the Presidency of the Commission.
We also consider this balance to be very positive.
A third point is the point of financial regulation, which especially with this last Council, took a step that we consider decisive and that can have a very big impact on the exit from the crisis.
And so, I also wanted to congratulate you on the achievement of having reached an agreement in this area.
And finally, I would like to say a word about an area that personally means a lot to me, which is the Stockholm Program, and therefore the area of security, justice and freedom.

I believe that I, who followed both the TEMPER process and, in particular, the AIA process, consider this Stockholm program absolutely essential and I would like to congratulate the Swedish Presidency and Prime Minister Reinfeldt for this.

Thank you, Mr. President. For the recognition of professional qualifications, 15 directives were consolidated into a single legislative act, as is known, which originated various problems of practical application in the different Member States.

The difficulties are known and the Commission will have to inventory the critical points and make an analysis of the problematic areas that arise in the application of this important internal market device.
The protectionisms that manifest themselves at various levels constitute an obstacle not only to the free circulation of people, but also to the internal market.
We must try to identify the vague points so that the effectiveness of the directive is not undermined by mistrust.
The Union is not asked to do what the Member States should do, but there is an effort to be made to facilitate the removal of professional corporatism.
Improving the application of this directive will require the dissemination of the recognition of qualifications on the Solvit network and on the EURES network, by encouraging
Common platforms, implementation of effective contact points and, no less important, it should provide an articulation of this directive with the Services Directive.

Thank you very much, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, Ladies and Gentlemen. It is urgent that a debate is promoted about the Community Budget and how it can contribute to its sustainability and transparency in the future.

The post-2013 financial framework must be built on the basis of solidarity and territorial cohesion, values that are crucial for regions such as Madeira, which face permanent difficulties and therefore need permanent support.
I would like to share with you some ideas that I believe should always be present when thinking about and building the policy of cohesion.

The Commission has been referring, on several occasions, to some aspects that seem essential to me, such as the need for greater flexibility, simplicity, efficiency and more focus on achieving results in the definition and implementation of this policy.
But there are issues that raise some concern, especially considering the needs of the ultra-peripheral regions.
In this matter, allow me three brief notes. First, the current approach in terms of regions should prevail over alternative orientations, such as, for example, the value-added sectors.

A reorientation like this can put Objective 2 at risk, which currently benefits about two-thirds of European regions, in addition to potentially being counterproductive in regions with a very specific economic profile and competitive advantages. Secondly, it seems to me that maintaining the proximity criterion in cohesion policy is vital.

It should continue to privilege the allocation and management of structural funds from a regional and not national perspective, or even centralized at the European level. Third and lastly, but no less important, I would like to recall and highlight Article 349
Article 349 of the Lisbon Treaty provides for special treatment of the outermost regions in terms of access to structural funds, precisely due to their economic and social situation.

aggravated by conditionalities and unique characteristics of a perennial nature, which manifest themselves in such constant difficulties and which, therefore, require the claimed permanent aids. Thank you very much.
Thank you, Mr. President. Given the urgency, what we witnessed in Copenhagen was several steps back.

It is true that Copenhagen mobilized more heads of state than Kyoto, but it also created more divisions. And as a result, what happened was that we ended up in a situation where each one is for himself, where each state can define its own goals and, on top of that, in a voluntary regime.
Referring to a goal of 2 degrees Celsius or goals for financing without any clarification also cannot serve as consolation.
And therefore, what I think is that we have to act in terms of the future. And acting in terms of the future is to stop passing from rhetoric to action.
The European Union has always wanted to be a leader, it has always affirmed it.
But when we got to Copenhagen, he ended up hesitating, not defining or defending the goals that he had stated here would be his goals and that he would not abdicate.

And so what I ask is if in the future we will not be more just, if we will continue to allow that at the expense of this failure and of the decisions of some over others, the poorest continue to pay the heaviest bill.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. I would like to denounce here what is happening in Portugal at this moment, where it is clear that the social communication
A government plan to control newspapers, to control television stations, to control radio stations, was brought to light, which calls into question freedom of expression.
This week, a well-known journalist, Mário Crespo, had one of his chronicles censored, allegedly at the suggestion of the Prime Minister.
For this, Prime Minister José Sócrates has to give substantial explanations to the country. He has to explain that he is not dominating, coercing, censoring the freedom of expression in Portugal.

The way things are going, Portugal is no longer a state of law, it is a formal state of law, where the Prime Minister limits himself to formalities, procedures, formalisms and does not want to give substantial explanations.
For Portugal, we want a material rule of law.

Thank you, Mr. President. The Green Paper for the Reform of the Common Fisheries Policy, whose rapporteur is my colleague from the Azores, Maria do Céu Patrão Neves, is a unique opportunity for a debate about a sector that assumes great importance in the balance of local development of the ultra-peripheral regions.

Madagascar is following the ongoing discussion with particular interest and considers it imperative to propose the differentiation between artisanal and industrial fleets, which should benefit from different fishing regimes.
It is essential to defend the principle of positive discrimination, in what concerns limiting access to territorial waters within the exclusive economic zone, only to local artisanal fleets.
In Madeira, it is a priority to support the modernization of vessels, as well as management that ensures the long-term conservation of a wide range of species.
Only in this way will we be able to avoid unsustainable situations for economic, environmental and social balance.
Lastly, we will fight for fisheries in the outermost regions to have permanent and not time-limited support.
This report on the FEDER aims to expand the eligibility of interventions in the housing sector in favor of marginalized communities in our Member States.
Until now, this support was only applied to marginalized communities that lived in the urban areas of the new member states.
That is, since the vast majority of these communities live in rural areas and shelters, these communities could not benefit from the support to replace poor quality housing.
It is, in essence, about how to create a vaccine and give Member States and their regions greater opportunities in the policy of mitigating the specific difficulties of these communities.
Health is also equal treatment for all Member States, since marginalized communities with support and integration needs deserve our concern, regardless of the Member State to which they belong.

By concluding, in first reading, this important report on the fight against poverty and for human dignity, it is also possible to achieve its rapid application within the scope of the economic recovery plan, responding in a timely manner to the crisis that affects us.

Thank you very much, Mr. President. Mr. Commissioner, allow me to start by highlighting the role of the rapporteur, Mr. Van Nistelrooy, for his work in seeking consensus on this matter and also for the availability he always showed to incorporate other contributions into his report.
Tomorrow we will vote on modifications to the FEDER regulation that are of particular importance to the so-called old member states and also to Portugal.
These changes will allow the use of the ERDF in the housing sector in favor of marginalized communities, since currently this fund can only be allocated to urban development operations.

The amendments that I proposed, together with other colleagues, and that were approved by a large majority in the Regional Development Commission, will allow the old Member States, and not only the new ones, as provided for in the original proposal, to also benefit from this funding possibility.
With this, I tried to avoid setting a precedent, which I consider dangerous, and which would exclude all the old Member States from this and probably from other additional uses of community aid.
Which would make no sense, since housing problems, especially among marginalized communities, exist in both new and old member states.

I take this opportunity to reiterate that the length of time a country has been a member of the European Union should not be a criterion for the allocation of structural funds and that this criterion should be immediately abandoned.

The negotiation of the cohesion policy for post-2013 should be based on solidarity, aiming at territorial cohesion, and should be oriented to reward, instead of punishing, the regions that have shown themselves to be exemplary in the use of community aid.
At this moment, I would like to essentially highlight to the Commission and to the President of the Commission the way they worked with this Parliament throughout these months of investiture.
There is no body in the world, with executive capacity and legislative initiative, that is subject to the presentation by its President of a program before Parliament, to the hearing with all groups,

Parliamentarians, to a vote by an absolute and expressive majority, to bring here all the commissioners to be heard one by one with their own program, with three to four hours of direct questions, of questions with answers.

There is someone who agreed to negotiate with the Parliament a framework agreement, in which he agreed, first of all, to justify and expand the powers of the Parliament in the scope of the legislative initiative.

that accepted the principle of total access to information, whether in legislative and political action, or in international negotiations, that accepted to take into account the opinion of the Parliament on the Commissioners, on the reshaping of the Commissioners.
This means, once and for all, and from my point of view, that the Commission has shown, from July until now, that it is willing to have a close relationship with the Parliament.

By doing so, it clearly, vividly and unequivocally demonstrated that the strategic alliance of the Lisbon Treaty for the community method that colleague Saryusz-Wolski was talking about is the alliance between the Parliament and the Commission.
And for this reason, the Commission and the Framework Agreement deserve the full support of the PPE.
Madam President, five years after the Orange Revolution, Ukrainians seem to look at this period as a lost opportunity.
And the blame is not only on their political elites.
It is true that these were consumed too much in power and influence wars.
Many reforms were left to be done, many did not go beyond the paper.
It is inconceivable that in any democracy the electoral laws are changed between the two rounds of an election.
It does not dignify those who proposed them, those who voted for them or those who promulgated them.
and translates the intentions that are not praiseworthy and not recommendable in its genesis.
