And there is much to change due to the lack of independence of the Judiciary, subject to too much influence not only from the political power but also from the economic agents.
Without a free and independent justice system, there is no rule of law, human rights are not guaranteed, there is no foreign investment, there is no progress.
But the blame for this disenchantment also lies heavily on this Parliament and, essentially, on many Member States.
I would like us to put ourselves, for a few seconds, in the shoes of a citizen of a European country that, due to the vicissitudes of history, is not yet a member of the European Union.
What would we expect from the Union?
Solidarity.

But many chancelleries, with the exclusive concern of not bothering and displeasing Moscow, used and abused the permanent internal struggles in Kiev to avoid affirming, in an unequivocal way, that Ukraine is an independent and sovereign country.
As such, if that is the majority will freely expressed by its people, and as long as they meet the established criteria, Ukraine can aspire to be, in the future, a member of the European Union.
It should be noted that in the insular regions, air transport provides the only means of access and that the operating conditions are conditioned by the dimension of their passenger and cargo flows.

While there are regions in the mainland where the abundance of these flows is attractive to many air operators, attracting competition and low transport prices, thus improving accessibility, there are others, such as the Azores, where these flows are still reduced, not being attractive or of interest to operators.

As a result, airfares are higher, constituting an obstacle to the mobility of the population and a hindrance to the attraction of tourists that would allow this enormous potential for development and diversification of its economic base to flourish and consolidate.
This picture is particularly punitive in times of crisis, such as the one we are going through.

It is therefore essential to have temporary support that boosts the increase in flows so that the market starts to function, also sharing these regions of high tourist potential with the objectives of the trans-European networks in bringing the peripheries of Europe closer together.

Thank you very much, Mr. President. I take the floor today in this Chamber with a voice choked with the consternation of someone who lived and witnessed personally the tragedy that last Saturday struck Madeira.
My words are obviously to join the feeling of pain and mourning that has hit the families of the deceased victims, which now amounts to 42, to whom I pay my tribute and respect for their losses.

The true dimension of this catastrophe is yet to be revealed, since the search and rescue teams, who have been working non-stop since Saturday in a Herculean effort that I commend, are only now beginning to reach the most isolated populations.
And we fear that the number of victims may increase.

The scenario is one of large-scale destruction, with significant material damage to access roads, completely destroyed highways and bridges, and essential services such as water supply and electricity.
There are about 600 people who have been displaced and lost their homes and personal belongings.
The economic and social impact of this catastrophe prevents people from resuming a normal life.
But now we need to look ahead.
I also need to send a message of solidarity, hope and trust to the people.
It is necessary to help. And it is in this chapter that the European Union and the Parliament in particular have a word. They are fundamental in the process of mobilizing the Solidarity Fund.
And when we are called to intervene, we have to do it quickly, because we cannot ask these people to wait, especially when they need us the most.

I appeal here to the Commission and its President, Durão Barroso, especially to the Regional Development Commissioner, Johannes Hahn, and I support his initiative to visit Madeira in the shortest possible time.
asking him to also be the bearer of this message of hope, of help and of support for reconstruction. Because now is the time to rebuild what nature, unfortunately, once again took away from us.
But I am sure we will do it. Because, as the anthem of Madeira taught me, the people of Madeira are humble, stoic and brave.
It is the people who, between the hard rocks, worked the land. The hero of work on the steep mountain.
Through wood, it will honor its history and, in the path of work, it will fight and achieve its well-being and glory.
We begin today this plenary session with a minute of silence.

And it was a minute of silence with two meanings: one of solidarity with the victims of this disaster that hit Madeira and their families, and a sense of tribute to all the workers who have tirelessly assisted these victims.
But the minute of silence should make us reflect and should also lead us to a reflection that goes beyond the one we are doing here.
What we saw in Madeira is a phenomenon that will tend to repeat itself more and more.
Climate change causes extreme phenomena to repeat and we must have responses to them.
We cannot avoid natural disasters, but we should not be condemned to always have such dramatic effects on people's lives.
This is why we must fight for planning and zoning policies that are oriented towards the public good.

But I want to emphasize, Mr. President, that what is most important and what brought us here is that the European Commission, the European Parliament, the European institutions must have the capacity to respond urgently to an emergency situation. And for that, the necessary financial resources are needed and the necessary speed is needed.
A tribute of solidarity with the families and friends of the victims of the tragic events of Saturday in Madeira Island.
As a citizen, as a Portuguese and as a European, I cannot fail to support the Parliament and the Union in their active solidarity with the Autonomous Region of Madeira and its people.
It is in the regions where the presence of the Union needs to be felt, and it is precisely in these moments when its solidarity is most needed that it is also most important that it be felt.

I also want to express my solidarity with the pain of the people of Madeira and insistently ask the European institutions, and in particular the Commission, to unlock all available means, all means at their disposal, to provide this assistance.
I would also like to emphasize that when there is a disaster of this kind, it is much more difficult to tackle its consequences when it occurs in poor countries and in poor regions.

But in the case of Madeira, we also have to consider that Madeira's economic base is directly affected by the fact that, depending on tourism, it has a double consequence when its natural beauties, its accesses, its quality of life is all destroyed.
Therefore, there is indeed a different situation when we have problems of this magnitude in poor countries, in poor regions, and particularly in mountainous and tourist regions, such as Madeira.
Therefore, it is absolutely essential that all the adaptations that were foreseen and requested and that were mentioned here regarding the Solidarity Fund do not wait any longer.

so that they come into effect immediately, because, due to climate changes, these processes will unfortunately be repeated, especially in the poorest regions of Europe, which are those that experience torrential regimes in terms of water and extreme drought during the summer. Thank you very much once again, Mr. President.
Commissioner and Council, we are here to talk about reinventing the energy system on a European scale through investment in low-carbon technologies.
I think it is a very important challenge, as it is mentioned, in fact, in the communication that is made.
And it is one of the challenges that we have to face head-on. But there is no clarification here and that is why it is important to raise these issues and ask for clarification.
It seems that not only is the clarification of the funding missing, but the political clarification is also missing.
It talks about energy efficiency, carbon capture, nuclear, biofuels, solar energy and it even talks about energy efficiency as a cheaper way to reduce emissions.
It surprises me that there are other much cheaper ways to reduce carbon emissions that are not even mentioned in this communication, such as, for example, the reduction of consumption.
energy, micro-generation, distribution and different forms of distribution and different projects that do not have to go only through large structures and access to energy.
I think that there we would be contributing to more financial clarification to make the plan cheaper.

And therefore, within this political clarification and within this financial clarification, it is still necessary to talk about what seems to me to be an absolutely important point, which is the tone that is permanently placed on public-private partnerships as if they were the solution to everything.
When we ask where the money comes from, the Commission tells us that it comes from where it is.
I confess that I am not more enlightened by being told that the money will come from where it is, without being told exactly where it is.

And therefore, this bet on public-private partnerships, which is systematically made when we talk about low-carbon technologies, we are surely left with a certainty. It is that not knowing where the money comes from and knowing that they are public-private partnerships, we know in advance who will pay.
In the beginning, it will be the taxpayers who will pay, and in the end, it will be the consumers, who are also taxpayers.

And we know that those who pay less are, in the first place, the institutions and private organizations that make investments, are remunerated for them, but in the end end up monopolizing the profits.
And without this clarification, what seems to me is that, once again, we are systematically passing on to future generations the bill for the change in the European energy model.

Mr. President, the European Union recently celebrated, within the World Trade Organization, an agreement with the countries of Latin America, in which it committed to substantially and progressively reduce the tariffs on the importation of bananas from those countries.

I would like to draw your attention to the fact that such an agreement has directly negative effects on European banana producers, namely on the banana producers of Madeira in Portugal, but also, and even more intensely, on the Canary Islands in Spain.

I recall that the situation of the producers in these regions is already seriously compromised by the physical and orographic characteristics of the islands and by the size of their farms, which leads them to face permanent difficulties that hinder their development.

It is therefore urgent to take measures to defend the banana producers of Madeira and the Canary Islands, taking into account the serious and immediate impact that the new Geneva Agreement will have on the European import market and, consequently, on the production and marketing of bananas from these outermost regions.
Mr. President, dear colleagues, Mr. Commissioner, as rapporteur of the opinion of the Employment and Social Affairs Committee, I would like to start by
To congratulate the deputy who is absent, even if it is a forced absence, and to highlight the way he was able to elaborate this important report, facilitating the main objective.
I would also like to congratulate Deputy Creel for the presentation she gave us.

The main objective is, without further ado, to make the procedures simpler and accelerate the implementation of the programs funded by the Cohesion Fund, the Structural Funds and the Regional Development Fund.
In the context of the current financial, economic and social crisis, the pressure on national financial resources has been increasing.
This pressure will decrease with a better use of community funding, with the faster arrival of these resources to the beneficiaries most affected by the economic crisis.
More than 20 million Europeans are unemployed, that is, more than 4 million than a year ago. And, unfortunately, the trend is to increase.

This situation requires that the cohesion programs are properly implemented, since they represent a more powerful and relevant lever to help the real economy, namely small and medium-sized enterprises and employment.
SMEs are the engine of the European economy and the actors of sustainable growth and job creation in quantity and quality.

The continuation of the simplification and clarification of the rules governing the cohesion policy will undoubtedly have a positive impact on the pace of implementation of the programs, particularly because it will be possible to...

national, regional and local authorities, the possibility of resorting to clearer and less bureaucratic rules that will allow more flexibility in adapting programs to new challenges. Thank you very much.
Thank you, Mr. President. Of course, this crisis was an unforeseen crisis and, of course, the precautionary principle had to take priority.
But there are lessons to be learned. And the first one is that, for five days, there was no sufficiently strong and politically responsible European voice.
And that voice was missed in what concerns the defense of passengers' interests, the clarification of their rights, the search for transport alternatives and the coordination of solutions.

A second conclusion is that the exit from the crisis cannot appear to the eyes of the common citizen as a game of forces between those who want to avoid losses and those who want to defend the precautionary principle.
There must be clear transparency and clear objectivity regarding the conditions under which one leaves a situation of total closure of the European space.
And therefore, the improvement of scientific tests and coordination at the level...

Thank you, Mr. President. I would also like to start by congratulating the work and persistence of colleague Tikal in this important file and for the work she did to improve the energy performance of buildings and for a more sustainable Europe.
Energy consumption in the European Union, as we know, is much higher than what is acceptable and that is why it is so important to move forward with proposals of this nature.
It is high time we had an ambitious policy in terms of Europeans and that we add to this ambitious policy complementary measures, especially in the crisis situation we are in.
The construction sector is considered one of the sectors, one of the markets with the greatest potential in terms of energy economy, but it is not only that.
And it is not only that, and for that reason it is the sector par excellence for the affirmation of public policies. And it is in that sense that I would like to conclude, Mr. President.

We must, therefore, take advantage of this opportunity that is given to us, of investments in improving the energy efficiency of buildings and its potential for creating millions of jobs in the coming years.
And not only in new buildings, but also in the rehabilitation and recovery of existing buildings, degraded or inadequate.

Let us take advantage of this legislation as a fundamental contribution to the reanimation of the European economy and we cannot continue to waste the investment that can and should be strategic for the recovery against the crisis and we hope that there is investment from the Commission and that the Member States know how to take advantage of this investment. Thank you very much.

Thank you very much, Mr. President, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues. I would like to start by congratulating colleague Manders for the work developed in this report, as well as thanking the colleagues who collaborated with him in this dossier.

In fact, the mere fact that this proposal simplifies and improves the current regulatory framework, by bringing together all existing legislation, three basic directives, on the naming and labeling of textile products, is in itself an important fact.

But beyond that, this proposal will have a positive impact on private agents and public authorities and will also allow the inclusion of new developed fibers, thus encouraging innovation in the textile and clothing sector.
This review will also intensify the transparency of the process of adding new fibers to the list of harmonized fiber names.
It does not seem to be any doubt that the agents involved will benefit from this regulation.
Let's see, the textile industry will benefit from a reduction in administrative costs and the possibility of marketing new fibers earlier.
On the other hand, the authorities of the Member States will not need to transpose the changes to national legislation, which will allow for a significant cost saving for these Member States.
Consumers will be guaranteed that the named fibers meet specific characteristics, also benefiting from the fact that new fibers will reach the market sooner.
For the European industry, the introduction of these new fibers is important as a way to promote innovation, while also increasing the level of information provided to consumers.
In the current context of a globalized world, emerging economies, with increasingly broad markets, in which millions of products produced by millions of companies circulate,
The bet on innovation and the speed with which this innovation reaches consumers is absolutely crucial for companies, especially for small and medium-sized companies.
that the application of this regulation may increase its competitiveness.
These small and medium-sized companies will surely gain market share with this new regulation and, in this way, will contribute to the increase in employment in Europe.
Thank you very much, Madam President, Minister, Commissioner. The shortage of organs for transplant is a major problem.

This has already been mentioned here several times and it is a major problem that raises issues both of public health and of those associated with the strengthening of the parallel market and the trafficking of organs, which in no way enhances our health systems and our citizens.

And therefore, we have to fight this crime and fight it through a set of proposals like those we are discussing here. It is a way, it seems to me, more than important and more than relevant and therefore I want to focus on the dimensions and the most important issues raised by these two proposals.
Because the system we have until now, and not having these two proposals, is a system of enormous inequalities.
Inequalities between Member States, inequalities between existing systems, inequalities of access to organs, inequalities between citizens that, it seems to me, we will not be able to support and...
Therefore, it is important to reinforce that these inequalities are reduced. And these proposals aim to combat precisely that.
I think that the European system, which maintains, however, some specificities of some of the countries so that they are not obliged to have more restricted systems, is the answer to this problem.
And the work that was developed by the reporters, by Mr. Nicolás Zic and by Mr. Perello Rodrigues, are works of extreme importance and contribution to this problem that we are facing.
If we are talking about proposals that have as their basis and support issues such as gratuity, voluntary work, confidentiality, data protection,

The traceability, the responsibility, and here I think it is important on the side of the Parliament that goes until the recovery of the patient and not only until the donation, and the cooperation between Member States, I think we are on the right path.
I must, however, refer to the relations between the living. I am pleased with the inclusion and expansion, this expansion made with rights,

Obviously, guaranteeing all rights and all conditions, but it is very important that we go beyond the restricted cycle of the conventional family, because otherwise it would be just another way of having other forms of equality.

Therefore, promoting data as the main source of transplants and protecting data and patient safety seem to me to be more than enough reasons for us all to be together tomorrow and vote in favor of these two extremely important proposals for humanity.

Mr. President, Madam Minister and Commissioner, the ability to replace deteriorated human organs with those of another person, preventing rejection, is one of the great successes of contemporary medicine.

The European benchmarking reveals differences, it reveals that medium-sized countries like Portugal score very well in such comparisons and larger countries like Spain are today recognized as organizational leaders and good practices.
Some principles and practices to safeguard.

Firstly, the reinforcement of scientific knowledge and information that leads more and more donors to donate while alive and to generalize post-mortem donation. Secondly, the prohibition of the commercialization of donation.

not only in the Member States but also outside them, preventing transplant tourism and combating organ trafficking. Thirdly, the proactive promotion of donation in hospitals as a way of overcoming shortages.

Finally, Madam President, to ensure equal access to transplants for all those who need them and qualify for them under harmonized clinical criteria, complying with the principle of universal access to health, a paradigm of social Europe of which we are proud.
I congratulate the rapporteurs for the work done.
I would like to emphasize that it is with great, let's say, satisfaction that the European People's Party and the Portuguese deputies of the Party
The European Parliament has started this process of accession, of the European Union to the European Convention on Human Rights.

We, a country like Portugal, which has always been at the forefront of human rights, with the abolition of slavery in Portugal in 1761, with the pioneering abolition of the death penalty, can only be, evidently, interested and supportive of this process of education.

However, I would like to draw attention to the fact that we consider it very important that the European Parliament follows, step by step, the entire negotiation of the European Union's accession to the European Convention on Human Rights.

We consider that this aspect, from a technical, legal and political point of view, is fundamental because the Parliament is also a House of Human Rights and a House where human rights have great relevance. And I would now like to make a note that we consider very important.

For us, members of the European Parliament, who are in contact with many states outside the European Union, it is very important, it is a very good signal that we give to the members of the Council of Europe, the entry of the European Union, to the members of the Council of Europe who are not members of the European Union.
It is a signal of reinforcement and commitment from the European Union to these Council of Europe members in their situation and in the levels of democracy and respect for fundamental rights.
Madam President, Commissioner, social housing is an economic service of general interest with an important role in the market, creating positive externalities to the benefit of the whole of society.
According to Protocol 26, attached to the Lisbon Treaty, it is up to national, regional and local authorities to execute and organize this type of service.
Hence, it is not understandable that the target audience is restricted to families with incomes below 33,000 euros.
It is a measurement of poverty that is made in absolute and purely financial terms, which does not contemplate the diversity of the 27 Member States, summing up to a simple argument of solvency.
Now, social housing addresses cultural, social issues, proximity to the workplace, the important redefinition of the role of women in the market, the mobility of workers in the European space.
The fight that the European Union is waging to get out of the current crisis goes through economic growth, which drags an increase in immigration and ethnic minorities.
economic and cultural, and the need for their integration, even with the risks of ghettoization that are associated with them and that we must fight with a fair balance.
Is the Commission not entering the field of competence of the Member States?

Madam President, Madam Commissioner, dear colleagues, allow me, Madam President, to point out the fact that we are debating the first report of the Agriculture Commission, subject to the new ordinary legislative process provided for by the Treaty of Lisbon.

This is a historic moment, and by confirming this Chamber the sense of the vote that I propose, it will start in the best way this new period of sharing of competences in the agricultural matter in the European Union.
I am talking exactly about the islands and their outermost regions, in a practical demonstration of the will to build a union that is strengthened by cohesion,
In the spirit of active solidarity, respecting the specificities and differences of its parts, as the only viable path to the construction of our common European project.

I also speak, introducing fundamental regulation for the viability of the already centenary sugar cane in the Azores, a region from which I come, so I especially congratulate myself, thus contributing to a
Healthy agricultural diversification in a region where the milk sector occupies, as we know, a unique dimension at the national level, irreplaceable, which we must sustain and consolidate.
Madam President, I would like to thank the Commissioner, the officials of the Commission with whom we worked and negotiated, for the openness and flexibility shown.
The Spanish Presidency of the Council also made an unlimited effort so that our shared will to reach an agreement in first reading became a reality.

This gratitude is, obviously, extended to the shadow deputies of the other political groups, as well as to the excellent officials of the Secretariat of the Agriculture Commission of this Parliament, whose collaboration allowed us to reach a result that I consider very positive.

I would also like to highlight the decisive contribution made by the Azores Agricultural Federation and by the Regional and Republic Governments in the way they got involved and committed to finding a solution for Azores sugar.

The presentation of the Council Regulation Proposal on October 2nd to the Agriculture Committee took place at a time when there were no prospects for the Lisbon Treaty to come into force, which was still awaiting ratification by all Member States.
In this context, the initial idea of the Commission and the Council was that the proposal would be approved in a simplified process, without any changes, to take effect from 1 January 2010.

With the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, and despite the prevailing opinion at the time by other political groups, as well as by the Council and the Commission, that the proposal should continue in the simplified procedure, because they understood that

The proposal did not require amendments and should come into force quickly. Despite eliminating this opinion, I and the Socialist and Democratic Group understand that Parliament should pronounce itself within the scope of the Lisbon Treaty, assuming its role as co-legislator.

We did it at the right time, because from then on new possibilities opened up, first with the contribution of the Regional Development Commission and the opinion of colleague Nuno Teixeira, whom I take this opportunity to thank.

To congratulate and thank for the collaboration always provided throughout this process and then with my report introducing the new possibilities for sugar in the Azores, as well as with the contribution and support of the colleagues from the Agriculture Commission.

I would like to say, finally, in this first intervention, that regarding the amendments proposed by the REGI Commission and voted on in the AGRI Commission and supported by me, we did not manage to obtain their acceptance in the compromise reached in the Trilogue.

It was essential to obtain a commitment in the first reading, thus safeguarding the improvements already obtained and the need for it to come into force so as not to compromise its retroactivity since January of this year.
However, since the Commission is already preparing a review document of the POSEI, we will certainly have the opportunity to debate them soon.

Thank you, Mr. President. Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, we are facing an acceleration of a global change that has devastating consequences for our economic, political and social systems and, consequently, for all our citizens.
We are witnessing today an unprecedented weakening of the States' response capacity.
The European Union has the responsibility to identify common causes and allies and to act clearly and unitedly on the world stage.
Extraordinary situations require lucidity and joint action.

If we do not take the necessary measures of rigor and collective responsibility, Europe will be condemned to marginalization and impoverishment. And only a strong Europe, respectful of its common rules, will be able to give an adequate response to the new times.
Weakened and indebted states do not have the capacity to protect their citizens.

Because, in the following, we need to be able to regain the trust of citizens, win the battles of stability, budgetary rigor, job creation, stability of the monetary union, globalization and strategic choices.
This under the penalty of having our future compromised.
And the future is won by betting on social cohesion, ensuring peace, building a new model based on the values of freedom, social justice and responsibility.
Thus, the 2020 Strategy and the integrated guidelines Europe 2020 constitute essential instruments for a new cycle of growth and employment in Europe.
For a correct implementation and realization, it is necessary to define quantifiable and clear objectives in employment, education and poverty reduction.

It is also decisive for the success of the strategy that everything is done to facilitate the transposition by the Member States of their national objectives and to ensure the correct execution of this strategy. Thank you very much.
When the Economic and Monetary Union turned 10, the Commission considered the euro the most successful project of the Union.
Today, we would have difficulty in affirming it without limitations, because the crisis has shown that the Economic and Monetary Union is an unfinished project.
The minimum rescue measures were taken in an emergency climate, but let us not be fooled. The pressure conditions, the direct interests of the main...
The painful nature of the decisions, the slowness of the Member States, weakened the image of the euro and of the European Union in the eyes of the citizens and of the world.
We have to face the facts.
The European Union and the Euro are a process of integration, not a mere cooperation between countries.
It is an unfinished process that, at this moment, either strengthens or runs the very serious risk of disappearing.
There are three issues that need to be addressed. First, it is important to consolidate the instruments that were launched in this emergency climate. It is necessary to create a monetary fund.

It is necessary to advance with Eurobonds, it is necessary to advance with the European supervision and regulation architecture and it is necessary to advance with a European dimension in the management of banking crises.
Second dimension. It is important to understand that there is no strong currency if the economy is weak. The 1% growth forecast for the European Union is unsustainable in terms of...
either in terms of its demographic composition or in terms of combating unemployment. The 2020 Strategy is nothing more than a set of good ideas if it does not have means of implementation.

Third dimension, Mr. Commissioner Olliren, fiscal consolidation is important, but it cannot coexist with growing divergences between the Member States that make up the Union. The policy of convergence must be urgently reviewed. Thank you very much, Mr. President.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. Several colleagues here from the PPR have already given a very complete picture of the situation.
I believe that now it will be necessary to demand and to make a reference to the role of the national states.
In fact, national governments also have a role here in the sense of imposing in their statutes the requirements
and the conditions for the single currency to be strengthened and this project of monetary and economic integration to be carried forward.
And here I would like to say that our party, the party linked to the PPE, which is the PSD in Portugal, is supporting the government in the austerity measures, because we consider...

That the mistakes that, over these 15 years, the Socialist government has made in Portugal and that today, unfortunately, are visible to everyone, that these mistakes need to be fixed and will have the support of the PSD to be fixed.

But if we are supporting the austerity measures, we also criticize the Portuguese government, and it is a good example for other similar cases, because it is not reducing spending. And what is fundamental is not just...

Increasing taxes to reduce the deficit. But it is reducing spending. It is demanding that the government has the courage to take measures that reduce spending, that alleviate the deficit, that alleviate public debt.
This applies to Portugal and to other States that are today in a difficult situation. And we, as European parliamentarians, have the responsibility to also make ourselves heard in our countries.

apology of the necessary measures so that the euro comes out strengthened and so that this integration space and this dream, which is a dream of the PPE and which is a dream of all of us, can be realized.
That is why we criticize those governments that do not have the courage to take the necessary measures in their states.

Madam President, dear colleagues, I would like to start by saying that the report on the evaluation of the results of the 2006-2010 Roadmap for Equality between Men and Women, which aims to influence strategies on this matter for the future, could, in our opinion, have been more assertive and less controversial.

In fact, the way of approaching several ethically sensitive issues, namely the issue of women's sexual and reproductive health, should have been different if the objective was really to obtain the greatest possible consensus.

That said, I would like to emphasize that in times of so-called normal economic growth, the concern with women's rights, namely with the disparity between the situation of men and women in work, in society, in the family, is great. But these problems are deeply aggravated with the economic and social crisis like the one we are experiencing.
Hence the need for a reinforced strategic commitment from Member States, at the level of local and regional entities and community institutions, regarding the protection of the environment.

To say that, in line with what President Dole and colleague Werner Langen said, it is essential that there is an economic government of the Union, but that this economic government is centered in the Commission.

This is the first point that I wanted to highlight. And having said this, I would like to say that we should not only, as was done this morning, have our debate focused on the immediate issues, but also
also in those that are part of the 2020 Strategy. And I would highlight in particular the issue of education and training of the younger ones, the issue of innovation, research and development.

Because these are the niches that will allow Europe to be competitive in the global space. And today I must say that, unfortunately, the European educational model has failed. And it has failed because, when compared to the model of emerging countries,

Like India, like China, like Brazil, it is today a less demanding and less rigorous model. And for this reason, it is also asked that in the audacity of this idea of innovation, development, research and education, there is rigor and demand in the context of European educational systems.
Only with this rigor and demand will we prepare our young people to compete in the global market.

We cannot think only about the crisis of this year or of the next two or three years. We have to think about the strategy for Europe in the next 10 to 20 years, and it depends on a rigorous and demanding educational system.
Mr. Commissioner, never before, as today, has the European project, built with so much effort in the last 50 years, been so threatened.

The frustration of European citizens is enormous. The financial system that was supposed to serve them destroyed their savings, their pensions, their investment projects, their jobs, in short, their future.
Regarding the necessary strengthening of the entire financial services market, banking, insurance, securities, the path to follow is clear and lies in the architecture that we discuss here today.
We do need a strong European supervisory architecture, which covers all products and actors, which is equipped with methodologies and instruments of
effective interventions and that is able to respond to the reality of a market that, especially in the European context, does not recognize national borders.

Risk cannot and should not be eliminated from the financial market, but we need regulation that makes this risk more transparent and prevents the accumulation of bubbles whose explosion affects the entire system and drags down the real economy.

But if, despite these defenses, new crises occur in the future, it is crucial to have mechanisms that limit contagion, especially with regard to the banking system, because it is vital to the functioning of the economy and is the repository of citizens' savings.

It is precisely in the powers and competences of the banking authority that lies the capacity to execute a new strategy on the management of cross-border crises in the banking sector, which is the subject of my report.
It is not in our hands to prevent banks from going bankrupt, but rather to ensure that their reorganization or eventual liquidation is done in a way that is...
in an orderly manner, limiting the side effects on the rest of the system and, above all, avoiding that the taxpayer pays the costs of the crises they generate.

For this, a set of new devices is needed. It is necessary to equip rules, definitions, methodologies, instruments and common terminology to all those involved in restructuring, reorganization or liquidation operations.
It is necessary to harmonize the relevant national legal frameworks for crisis management, namely bankruptcy and liquidation laws.
It is necessary to grant supervisors broad intervention powers.
It is necessary to design clear criteria, not only quantitative but also qualitative, that allow interventions to be initiated in an institution in difficulty.
It is necessary to prepare contingency plans.
This whole process for 27 Member States requires time.
However, around 50 banks out of the 12,000 operating in Europe represent 70% of the assets.
Now, this means a huge concentration of risk, but also an opportunity to intervene on them as a priority.

There are conditions for us to propose a special and urgent process of meeting the banks, which, being cross-border, due to their size and relations with other banks, have a possible systemic impact on the financial system.
Now, for these banks, it is possible to anticipate special supervision by the new European Banking Authority, although operating in the National Supervisors College.
It is possible and urgent that they, according to the risk they generate, start making contributions to a fund that finances the eventual interventions.
that are necessary and it is important that the banking authority creates a specialized unit that coordinates interventions in case of difficulty in these banks.
In general, the proposed elements ensure that interventions in transnational banks of a systemic nature are consistent and coherent and, among other things,
different countries and, above all, that a principle so dear to Europe is fulfilled, that the costs of pollution caused by these banks are borne by the polluter himself.
This proposal fits perfectly with what we are discussing, especially regarding the powers of the banking authority. I would even say that it is the most evident test of its effectiveness.
In the case of the vote in the Economic and Monetary Affairs Committee, there was a very large majority in favor of this proposal, 87% of the votes.
We also have here in the plenary the massive vote of this institution, in the sense of massively supporting this proposal, which is visionary, realistic, but pragmatic.
Let us take urgent and necessary action to relaunch the hope of Europeans in Europe, in their financial system and, in particular, in the banking system. Thank you very much.
Thank you. Briefly, to highlight only four points.
The first one is that it was an extraordinary experience to work in such a solidary way with my colleagues from the other political forces.
Thank you very much for including it in the supervision package and, in particular, thank you very much to Mr. Garcia Margalho for all the collaboration that was possible to obtain.

Secondly, I would like to thank my personal collaborators and also my colleagues who contributed to the specific report that I am responsible for, which allowed me to incorporate 90% of their proposals.
A special word for the Secretariat, for Susana Vrabova and for the Commission's services.

Lastly, my word of thanks to the Commissioner, to his services, and the very clear expression of hope that, in fact, based on the report that I hope will be approved tomorrow, it will be possible to build a solid foundation, a truly European foundation that protects citizens.
Thank you very much, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner. I would also like to start by thanking the rapporteurs for this excellent work.

Deforestation, as we know, is one of the main environmental and social problems of the planet and every year we lose 13 million hectares of forest, thus contributing to 20% of the world's carbon emissions and constituting a huge threat to biodiversity.

The contribution of deforestation to climate change is undeniable and, as such, it is highly responsible for the occurrence of extreme weather events and floods, or even for the desertification of vast areas of the planet.
The loss of forests puts all of humanity at risk, but this risk and this impact is not equally distributed among all of us.
The communities with fewer resources and the communities that are more dependent on the forest and nature to survive are the most affected.
Deforestation is related to our collective existence, to the scarcity of natural resources, to their distribution, to the rights of local and indigenous communities, to social justice.
The main cause of deforestation is illegal logging, which accounts for 20 to 40% of the world's industrial timber production.
Therefore, we are also talking about the transfer of wealth from producing countries to consuming countries of the same timber.
This illegal practice puts at risk the sustainable exploration of wood and the companies that do it.
Pretty words are not enough.
This Parliament must adopt strong and consistent measures in this fight.
This report takes a very significant step in this direction by defining the prohibition of timber trade.
Good intentions are not enough.
Effective means are needed, namely sanctions, which in this case can be of three types.

First, fines, which actually remove the economic benefit from the illegal practice, aggravated by recidivism. Second, confiscation of the wood and products in question. And third, immediate suspension of the authorization to carry out a commercial activity.

And so it is because whoever explores or commercializes a natural resource must be socially responsible. And so it is also that whoever places wood or wood products for the first time in the European Union must be obliged to due diligence to ensure that it is legally explored wood.
This is why all the following operators must provide basic information about this timber, namely its origin and destination.
The population must still have the right, and I end here, Mr. President, the right to access information about who complies and who does not comply. Thank you very much.
Thank you, Mr. President. Europe needs to renew confidence and hope.
In a crisis that is not yet over, we had the firefighters, as Jacques Delors said,
We hope that the Belgian presidency will bring the architects.
The first test, naturally, will be in September, the Council's approach to the Parliament's proposals regarding the financial architecture.

But today, one of the biggest European challenges is to ensure that the European currency does not collapse, either due to the lack of accompanying instruments, or due to the lack of growth in the Eurozone, or especially due to the increasing divergences and internal tensions caused in the economies that compose it.

Cutting structural funds today, as proposed by the Commission, which were created to stimulate convergence in diverging economies, seems to be putting the firemen to stoke a fire that is not yet extinguished.
We clearly need architects.
One last question, I would like to know the external dimension of the European Union's action, in particular, to know a little more about what the Belgian Presidency proposes for Cancun and Doha.

Thank you, Mr. President. This report of initiative that we are debating today, on the responsibility of the DEB, to whom I congratulate for the way it was conducted and for its good final result, and in which I had the privilege of being shadow and negotiating the 17 commitments obtained, is absolutely essential at a time when...

Agricultural policies are increasingly market-oriented, farmers in Europe are faced with very low income levels and millions of consumers, as a result of the crisis that affects us all, are in dire need of keeping food prices affordable.

This is why, if farmers' income is going to depend more and more on the values generated in the markets and on the price of food for its proper functioning, then improving the functioning of the food supply chain

It becomes absolutely necessary for a more equitable distribution of the generated value from agricultural producers to final consumers, ensuring fair income for the former and adequate prices for the latter.

For this, it is necessary to rebalance the relations established along the food supply chain, give them transparency, while ensuring the existence of a framework of good, fair and competitive practices.
In this sense, we support the Commission in taking into account the proposals widely supported in the Agriculture Commission.
A few days ago, in Aroca, Portugal, all the workers of a shoe company were fired by a simple mobile phone message, without any further explanations.
I bring this case here because it is, unfortunately, a blatant example of the abuse of collective dismissals in Europe.
It goes against all European norms and offends any sense of common sense, respect and dignity.
In Europe, since the crisis began, there are 8 million new unemployed, totaling 25 million. How many have been fired in such a shameful way as this?
I would say more and more, unfortunately.
The European Union says it is the bearer of a long tradition of safeguarding workers' rights.
However, the current legislation has not been effective.
What additional measures will the Commission take?
This is why this question is so relevant.
There is no justification for dismissals like the one in Aerocab.
It will be an innovation to fire someone by SMS, but it is not a good innovation, it is a terrible one, surely. Thank you very much.
The environmental disaster currently under discussion, although occurring outside the geographical space of the Union, concerns all of us, European citizens.

The notion of sustainable development, which we believe in, is a concept that has no administrative borders, no religious beliefs and that looks at the planet as a whole and not as the sum of its parts.
The Jordan River is, therefore, a problem for all of humanity and not only for the populations or communities directly affected by the scarcity or low quality of its water.
“Think globally, act locally,” common sense tells us.
That is what we are doing here today, thinking globally.
As the European Union, we must help to act locally in order to minimize and reverse this permanent degradation of the flow and quality of the waters of the Jordan River.
And to act or help to act, the Union already has legislative, institutional framework and instruments at its disposal.
I am referring to the Union for the Mediterranean, its secretariat and the FEMISE, managed by the European Investment Bank.
This is, obviously, a theme that the delegation of this Parliament, which I preside, will follow closely in relation to the countries of the Mashreq.
It is obvious that the action leading to the resolution of this environmental tragedy must, first of all, be undertaken by the States and local authorities whose populations directly benefit from it.
In this context, I would like to highlight two ideas present in the resolution.
Firstly, the creation of a commission for the management of the entire Jordan River basin, made up of representatives of the states or authorities that use those waters.
And here, Europe can help by sharing, for example, the experience of the International Commission for the Protection of the Rhine River.
Secondly, support and dissemination of good practices in relation to joint community projects involving Jordanian, Israeli and Palestinian citizens.

namely those promoted by the Friends of the Earth Middle East, which colleague De Roos just mentioned, regarding the efficient and correct management of the water resources of the Jordan Valley basin.
Finally, Mr. President, and in an even broader scope, to highlight the example of cooperation and peaceful coexistence that this design conveys.

At the moment when, although regretting the absence of the European Union in the process, we welcome and encourage the resumption of the new process of direct dialogue between Israel and the Palestinian Authority, we want to welcome this direct involvement of the two parties.

Thank you very much, Madam President, Mr. Commissioner. The coordination of efforts in the European semester, which was the subject of analysis yesterday in the Ecofin, is in itself positive, but it is only part of the reality.
It is necessary that growth and employment work as priorities alongside the compliance with the Stability and Growth Pact.
It is important that the European Monetary Fund is created.
It is necessary to deal with sovereign debt alongside all the other obligations required for participation in a monetary area. And it is necessary...

I hope that the evolution of this work does not go in the direction of the dangerous idea of sanctions and I count on Commissioner Barnier and his experience to help the Commission to move in that direction.
A second note to sincerely congratulate you for the work done in financial supervision.
I think that Commissioner Barnier, in particular, together with this Parliament and the Belgian Presidency, managed to reach a good agreement, an agreement that honors us.
and that defends the interests of European citizens. And my votes are that the agenda that is missing follows the same methodology and that we reach the same success.

Thirdly, I would like to tell you that I sincerely hope that, as regards the resolution of banking crises, especially systemic and cross-border banks, progress will be made in the direction of valuing the European dimension.
Lastly, Mr. Commissioner, it is very important to revisit our agenda for G20, especially if we do not want to give up the fight against fraud and tax evasion.
tax, if we do not want to give up the fight against tax havens and, even, if we want a more determined contribution from banks and financial services to work effectively.

Thank you, Madam President. Today we discuss another situation of human rights violation, the imprisonment of Syrian activist Haitham al-Maleh, an 80-year-old lawyer accused of spreading false and exaggerated news that weakens the national feelings of his country.

In addition to violating the rights of numerous international treaties and conventions, the imprisonment of this human rights defender is also contrary to the country's own legislation, which stipulates that military courts should not have jurisdiction over civilians.

The decision that was taken in relation to this man and in relation to other Syrian prisoners, detained for similar reasons, the various detentions, the restrictions on freedom of movement and the arbitrary measures taken

by the Syrian authorities are practices that contradict the important role of Syria in the whole region and do not reflect the efforts that have been made in this country to improve the social situation.
I repeat, today we are discussing yet another situation of human rights violation.
It is not possible to separate it from the various discussions we had here this week.
I highlight two. The first is the condemnation of the death sentence by stoning imposed on Sakineh Ashtiani.
Many voices have joined together and there are already some results.

It is not yet time to sing victory, but it is even less time to be silent. Secondly, we approved today an important resolution against the abuses imposed by the Sarkozy government on Romanian and Bulgarian citizens.
The defense of human rights has no borders and is not a fight that can only be waged out there.
Today we gave a good example of how to stop it also behind closed doors.
The unjustified imprisonment of Daetany Almalé unites us all here today.
He is a human rights defender.
Human rights defenders must be free people and that is what we demand from the Syrian authorities.
We, human rights defenders, will not leave you alone. Thank you very much.

Mr. President, the fact that there is a growing tendency for the safety profile of new medicines to only be fully known after they enter the market, requires a more effective pharmacovigilance system than has been the case until now.
We are facing a typical risk management problem, but at a macro and supranational level. Let's make it closer to the citizens, now.
New medicines have played a fundamental role in public health and in the advances in health care over the last few decades.
However, adverse reactions to drugs continue to be the fifth leading cause of hospital death.
The proposals presented reinforce the contribution of medicines to modern public health through a community pharmacovigilance system, improving coordination and transparency.
Its objective is to monitor, detect early, communicate and evaluate adverse reactions.
The new medicines will have a graphic symbol that mentions that they are still under scrutiny.

It stimulates the participation of the user in the control, stimulates national efficacy studies, opens up a new sensitivity to environmental consequences and improves community control institutions, the PRAC.
That is why I congratulate you, Mr. President, on the proposals.
I congratulate the rapporteur and also the Commission for the spirit of cooperation, as well as the Presidency of Spain.
And therefore, with the proposals presented in this legislative package, we welcome the final document that will be voted on tomorrow. Thank you, Mr. President.
Mr. President, I would like to start by thanking and congratulating the rapporteur, as well as all the colleagues who were involved in this process.
We know that adverse effects of medicines are the fifth cause of hospital death, it is never too much to repeat it, and a strong and transparent drug surveillance system is essential.
We now have the opportunity to strengthen the safety of medicines that are already available, going beyond laboratory tests that do not always anticipate problems.

If concrete examples were needed to justify the importance of a new system, look at what happened with the H1N1 flu vaccine. The speed at which the vaccine was put on the market and the lack of care in investigating the side effects that were detected and that still delay a complete investigation.
This is why it is necessary to continue to deepen this path.
This directive ensures the most active involvement of health professionals and patients in identifying difficulties.
In fact, cooperation between countries and the Union can be a positive-sum game.
Thank you, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner. A Europe without economic, social and territorial cohesion is not a Union.
Mountainous regions, islands and areas with low population density have their own very difficult challenges that must be overcome in the name of a Europe of the people.
But we must go beyond statements of intent, otherwise we have the opposite effect, that is, we reinforce inequalities.
These regions are huge reservoirs of important resources.
Biodiversity, forests, wetlands and green areas provide an essential service for all and, however, suffer with the consequent limitations to their economy.
There is a need to pay back.
The populations of these regions must be supported in solidarity by everyone.
Give me two proposals.
First, the potential contribution to science and development.
Many of these regions are authentic open-air laboratories, given their wealth, but they do not have equal access to resources for research.
Why not then equip them with centers of excellence in research, generating quality jobs and boosting their economies?
A second proposal has to do with energy.
These regions can and should be the embryos of projects that demonstrate the potential for self-sufficiency and energy sustainability, namely through the micro-generation of local sources.
Reducing this dependence would increase equality and job creation.
Lastly, I would like to point out that using the GDP as the only or main indicator for the allocation of funds in aid can only result in more injustice.
This is why it is very important to use complementary data, namely those that portray the social and economic reality of these regions.
I cannot fail to make a special reference here to the people of the Azores, Madeira, the mountainous areas and the depopulated interior areas of Portugal.
With their effort, they greatly contribute to the development and quality of life of all Europeans.
These and all the regions have their context.
Social, economic and territorial cohesion should not be seen as a charity service.
This is where we define whether we want a true European redistribution policy or not.
I consider this resolution to be very important, but a first step. Thank you very much.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, the objective of territorial cohesion, now enshrined in the Treaty of Lisbon, materializes the value of European solidarity and the commitment of the Member States and the Union to reduce the existing disparities between the various regions.
However, it is not enough to express the objectives to be achieved in the text of the treaties.
There are regions in the Union that have permanent constraints that strongly condition their economic and social development.

It is therefore necessary to implement specific programs that allow these regions to effectively and truly overcome their delay, by promoting an adaptation of their development model to their potential and resources, and contributing to achieving the objectives of the EU 2020 strategy.

This incentive for these regions should result not only from the means of regional policy, through its structural adjustment instruments such as the Cohesion Fund and the four structural funds, but also
Also, of a different use of the various sectoral policies, which have a relevant territorial impact in each region and can, therefore, have a stimulating effect on their economies.
To determine European assistance to these regions, it is certain that we should keep GDP as the main eligibility indicator.

However, considering its natural disadvantages, it is relevant to resort to other measurable criteria, capable of providing a more realistic picture of its level of development, such as the unemployment rate, population density or the level of education.
Only then will it be possible to have a more complete picture of the complex reality of the most disadvantaged regions.

To this effect, the case of the outermost regions should be highlighted, whose status is recognized by the new treaty and which are a group of regions of the European Union that have specific characteristics and also deserve special treatment.
The outermost regions, united due to their particular characteristics, also diverge in their levels of development.

In relation to these, complementary indicators of the GDP should also be used, capable of providing a more complete description of its specific reality and thus contributing to a more accurate determination of its level of development. Thank you very much.
Thank you, Mr. President. I support this motion of resolution that calls for the need for a European strategy that makes it possible to translate the principle of cohesion
The Treaty of Lisbon gains territorial opportunities for the populations of territories that suffer from various permanent natural constraints to participate in the European project.

I come from a region, the Azores, where these constraints are shared and intensified, just like in other regions known as the outermost regions of Europe, in the terms of Article 349 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the Union.
Following the Commission's communication, "Cross-border regions, a trump card for Europe" in 2008, and after the broad debate in which the RUP themselves participated,
We are also actively awaiting our version of this strategy, which will have to take into account not only our constraints, but above all our potential.
I therefore appeal to the Commission to be swift in its presentation so that we can establish the best strategy before the debate on the new perspectives.
financial, because we must first define the content of the policies before allocating the necessary means for their execution, as has been happening with the community policies now under review.

Thank you, Mr. President. Mr. President, Mr. Commissioners, dear colleagues, after four consecutive years of reduction in the unemployment rate from 2004 to 2008, the current economic crisis has nullified many of the progress made.
Unemployment rates in the European Union have increased significantly, for example, in Portugal we reached the record value, unfortunately, of an unemployment rate of 11.
Another negative phenomenon is youth unemployment in the European Union.
Europe is thus going through a period of transformation and faces enormous challenges.
The crisis wiped out years of economic and social progress and exposed the fragilities of the economies of its Member States and, consequently, of the European Union itself.
The 2020 Strategy points out the paths to follow.
The European Union must intensify all its efforts to promote employment and social inclusion as part of its strategy to combat the economic and social crisis.
Thus, the proposal for the resolution on the future of the Social Fund, currently under debate, is supported, as this fund plays a crucial role in achieving the objectives of the 2020 Strategy.

In fact, this fund is the main financial instrument that allows the European Union to achieve the strategic objectives of its employment policy, improving the levels of education and qualification of its citizens.
The FSE should be strengthened as the main driver of the 2020 Strategy and should be used by the Member States to invest in qualification, employment, training and professional retraining.
Finally, I would like to highlight that the reform of the European Social Fund, to be carried out together with the remaining structural funds, should facilitate and simplify its management and
To reinforce transparency, as well as to focus funds on achieving results and on the realization of objectives that are effectively felt by citizens in their daily lives. Thank you very much.
The European Social Fund is probably the most structuring instrument of cohesion.
It must therefore have a great articulation with the Regional Development Fund.
It is essential to have a global approach to the issues to be solved, that is, a global vision for local action.
Local and regional authorities are the entities that best know their realities, their investment needs, job creation, and which measures are most appropriate to promote employment in their regions.
We must take into account the positive experiences of the regions.
In the Azores, an outermost region where unemployment usually reaches record levels, the unemployment rate is 6.5%, the lowest in Portugal.

This is largely due to the prospective planning strategy used for employment, defining the factors to act on, how to achieve the desired growth and also the use of the European Social Fund as an operational instrument of this strategy, acting on education, training and employment promotion.
The horizontalization of the cohesion policy is the only way to ensure the success of the 2020 strategy.
The cohesion policy is the great pillar of European solidarity.
It is through cohesion that the objective of reducing disparities between regions is achieved and the harmonious development of the European Union as a whole is encouraged.
In the next period, from 2014 to 2020, we must define a framework capable of reinforcing the effectiveness of regional policy.

Governance at various levels should be encouraged with greater involvement and participation of regional and local entities, respecting the principle of subsidiarity and as provided for in the new Treaty of Lisbon.
The special situation of the ultra-peripheral regions should not be forgotten.
This set of regions faces very important challenges and must continue to benefit in the future from specific arrangements in the application of European policies.
GDP should continue to be the main eligibility criterion, but we must take into account other indicators that can provide a more complete picture of the regional reality.
It is an aging population with very low birth rates.
These factors represent enormous challenges for the European Union, to which we must give concrete answers.
This observation has been consensual during this debate among us, despite the different views that this discussion has been highlighting.
In Portugal, for example, the birth rate does not ensure the renewal of generations and reveals a reality that compromises the future.
This situation occurs in my country, as it does in most of the Member States of the European Union.
I am sure that more flexible policies regarding maternity leave can help reverse these trends.
We must send families a consistent message of support for motherhood, with concrete measures for better reconciliation of professional, private and family life.
Women should be protected so that they can choose to have children without having to leave the job market.
The achievement of this challenge is essential if we want to reach the economic and social objectives of the Europe 2020 Strategy and combat demographic aging.
In Portugal, for example, maternity leave is already paid at 100% for 120 days, in an attempt to counter the low birth rate we are experiencing.
I therefore defend that women's salary should be guaranteed during maternity leave, in the manner presented in the report under discussion.
Allowing each Member State to create, by 2020, the conditions that ensure the objective of full salary payment during maternity leave seems a sensible procedure.
Finally, I greet the reporter Edith Estrela for her persistence in defending the measures aimed at protecting families, while also contributing to countering the aging of the population.
First, regarding these two reports, I would like to congratulate and give public testimony, which I have already given in the Constitutional Affairs Committee, of the notable work done by the...
colleagues Lena, Svoboda, Rohrer-Bernt, Diana Wallis and Rebecca Harms, who were part of the Parliament's delegation that negotiated this framework agreement with the Commission.

I would also like to record the great openness and highly constructive spirit of collaboration of the President of the Commission and, after the new Commission was appointed, of Commissioner Šefčovič and his teams.
I believe that a remarkable job was done, which led to a historic agreement, which is an agreement that represents the first framework agreement after the signing of the Treaty of Lisbon.
Lisbon and the first framework agreement that has a direct basis, an express basis in the treaties, more precisely in article 295 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.
I would like to say that this agreement actually creates a relationship of great transparency and great dynamism, even some intimacy in the relationship between the parties.
the Parliament and the Commission and essentially represents a commitment, a balance between the vision of the two institutions on the new role that each of them has after the Treaty of Lisbon.

I believe that the work of our negotiating team was, in fact, very positive, because it was possible to translate into this framework agreement those that are the new competences and that is the reinforcement of powers that results from the Treaty of Lisbon.
This applies to the legislative procedure and to programming or planning, namely, for example, just to give two examples, in the involvement of Parliament in the
the Commission's work programme, or, for example, in matters related to the use of soft law in those that are legislative competences of the Parliament by the Commission.

In a second line, a very important aspect is the reinforcement of the powers of control and scrutiny of Parliament. Whether it is in detailing, in specifying the rules of election of the President and the body of Commissioners, whether, for example,

As for the presence of Parliament in matters such as the reshuffling or the eventual dismissal of a Commissioner, or, for example, the hearing of the directors of regulatory agencies, or even the monitoring of international negotiations.
In all these dimensions, there was, in fact, a consecration of powers, which are powers that result from the Lisbon Treaty.
It is also very important to have access to information, and in particular, access to classified information or information that is classified.
Confidential. And, beyond that, the exchange of information and views between the Parliament's representatives and the Commission's representatives.

For example, we know that today it is already possible for the Commissioner responsible for institutional affairs and the President of the Commission to participate in the relevant parts of the Conference of Presidents.

Or, for example, that there are several dialogue platforms between the Conference of Presidents, the Conference of Presidents of the Committees, the President of the Parliament, the President of the Commission and the College of Commissioners, all of them expressed.
The presence of the Commission in Parliament was also reinforced, namely through the application of the Question Hour not only to the President of the Commission but also to the Commissioners.
I would say, therefore, that, in deep respect for the Treaty of Lisbon and for its new balance of powers, and in deep respect for the idea of separation of powers,
We have here a clarifying agreement that will make the Treaty of Lisbon current, alive and applicable.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, I begin by congratulating the rapporteur colleague for her work, as well as congratulating all those who collaborated with her in this report, which made it possible to obtain this agreement in first reading.

The present directive, which reformulates the previous directive, which is more than 10 years old, intends, as was recognized here by all, to put an end to a generalized problem in the European Union of payment defaults.
These delays, which in some Member States are unjustifiably long when they involve public administration.

The negative effects of this practice on the economic life are enormous, both at the level of small and medium-sized enterprises and at the level of the internal market. And these negative effects can no longer be tolerated, especially since we are going through an economic and financial crisis like the one we are experiencing.
This legislative amendment will provide coherence and will make sense of the plan to relaunch the European economy and the application of the SMOL.
Business Act. Surely this directive will improve the liquidity of companies.
Creditors will have an effective and efficient tool to exercise their rights against bad payers.
With this directive, the censurable practice of public entities will be the exception.
Public administration bodies must set an example of good citizenship and pay bills for goods and services within a month.
Now, it will be up to the institutions involved, the Council and the Member States, to allow the transposition of this directive to be done as quickly as possible. Thank you very much.
Thank you, Mr. President. Today, there is a great disparity in many Member States regarding payment conditions for companies, especially when the State, SMEs and large companies are involved.

We who come from companies know that in this situation of economic crisis and increased difficulties in financing, companies are increasingly struggling with liquidity problems, even finding themselves in many Member States exposed to an increased risk of bankruptcy.
It is clear that the current directive that attempted to regulate this matter had limited effects, which is why the proposal that we are now analyzing represents an important step in fulfilling
The payment terms, not only in the relations between companies and public entities, but also, and this is essential, in the relations that companies establish among themselves.

We now have legislation that brings us greater added value, with a clear system of sanctions for late payments, and that also brings us an effective improvement in the balance of the abuse of the dominant position that the State and large companies establish.
Thank you very much, Madam President, Madam Commissioner. Allow me to speak about the unsaid.

I listened very carefully, Madam Commissioner, and from what I heard, I would like to say that, so far, the most effective action, both from the national authorities and from the European authorities, was the management of silence.
Industrial accidents can and should be avoided. This is also why there is European legislation and it seems obvious that the law was violated.
There was inefficiency, a late response, abandonment of the affected people, and in particular, of the most disadvantaged.
People died and many are still under threat today of what can happen to their health.
It is impossible to calculate the total costs and it is immoral not to care for the victims.
How is it possible, I ask you, Madam Commissioner, that we know about news through reports that reach us from Hungarian citizens and the authorities see nothing or tell us nothing?
That is why I would like to ask some questions.
How can the banks pressure citizens with mortgaged homes in the affected area, asking them to pay what they owe, when their homes have lost their value?
How can we allow telephone operators to cut off the only means of contact for those in the disaster area?
How can the company responsible for this disaster be operating again?
And lastly, Madam Commissioner, you spoke about mitigating the effects of the mud spill.
I ask you what the reasons are to continue to mitigate the true dimension of this human tragedy.
It is as if we are always starting from scratch.

Thank you, Mr. President. Dear colleagues, we all recognize that the control of macroeconomic variables in the short and long term in the European Union has failed, namely the budgetary frameworks and the accumulated national debt.
The crisis has highlighted the need to strengthen the single market, with the Monti and the Four Presidents' reports in mind.

It is essential to develop e-commerce and cross-border trade, simplify online payment processes, standardize products and services, harmonize tax instruments, in order to create consumer confidence and boost the economy.
The Union must exit the crisis in a sustainable way, ensuring solid growth and responsible budgets, but also employment objectives.
Indicators such as the unemployment rate and the employment rate of the active population must be included in the monitoring system.
The indicators that will measure the progress of the 2020 Strategy cannot be forgotten either.
The feasibility study on the issuance of common European bonds may constitute an opportunity to deepen and put into practice financial instruments for the defense against speculation.
We would have liked to have gone further than a simple study.

The creation of the European Monetary Fund deserves our support and we see it not only as a discipline instrument, but above all as a means of reducing the speculative manipulation of sovereign debt markets.
The cooperation with the rapporteur Feio was fruitful and it was possible to achieve a comprehensive, balanced and rich text.
Thank you, Mr. President. Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, I would like to start by thanking Deputy Feio for the work of harmonization and the spirit of commitment with which he imbued his report.
But the conclusion we reached was that the Parliament, in certain files, and this also happened in financial supervision, is
It is capable of uniting and is capable of taking a strong position that defends the interests of the citizen and this strong position must be recognized by the Commission and by the Council.
This aspect is particularly relevant at the moment when a legislative package of six extraordinarily sensitive proposals is initiated, many of which this Parliament has powers of co-decision.
We will be equally active, but without concessions.
Our spirit is one of dialogue, but not of going beyond the objectives we intend to defend.
In this regard, the FEIO report highlights some aspects that are framing.
One of them is that economic governance is more than a package of sanctions.
Growth and employment need their own initiatives.
It is necessary to take initiatives that combat the growing internal divergences of the European Union.
It is necessary to have concrete proposals about the European Monetary Fund.
Stable solutions are needed for sovereign debt.

In fact, there are more than 20 million small and medium-sized companies in the European Union.

The document points out recommendations such as economic strategies to exit the crisis, main highlights.
