The granting of tax incentives and even subsidies to SMEs to maintain and create jobs.
the creation of a new Small Business Act, endowed with a stronger social dimension.
The establishment of a European network of serious consultants for the dissemination of their knowledge.
Innovation as the most powerful engine of economic growth and, as such, the essentiality of an organic link between industry and innovation.

Mr. President, the smart growth, as advocated in the 2020 Strategy, can only be achieved if we mobilize, in a smart way, the different potentials contained in the European diversity.

and the Council to act, that they cannot do without an integrated European maritime policy in obtaining intelligent growth, essential to the success of the 2020 Strategy.

Thank you, Mr. President. I begin by congratulating Commissioner Barnier for the presentation of this important document.
As diagnosed, the impact of the crisis we are experiencing is being felt in all sectors of society and our economy, causing our citizens to feel disheartened and distrustful of the single market.
But it is precisely this single market, one of the strengths that Europe has to fight the current crisis.
For this reason, we strongly welcome this communication, which represents a new ambition for the policies of the single market, allowing us to regain confidence in our model of social market economy.
In the current situation, the European Union must pay particular attention to its 20 million small and medium-sized enterprises.
In this sense, one of the priorities of the Union should be the creation of mechanisms that solve the problem of access to credit by these companies.

We also highlight the Commission's proposal to evaluate the Small Business Act by the end of 2010, in order to facilitate the life of these companies, namely in bureaucratic and tax simplification, as well as in the appreciation of social responsibility.

We hope that these 50 measures now presented contribute to deepening the internal market, making full use of it, which can represent for the European economy an additional growth. Thank you very much.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. We are here today to discuss what has been presented as one of the main priorities of the European Commission, which is the innovation policy.
It finally gains shape, namely through the European partnerships for innovation and with this pilot project that we are discussing here today about active and healthy aging.
However, there are still many aspects to be defined, namely in terms of clarification, in terms of defining future projects and in terms of priorities.
Who will finally define the priorities and based on what criteria?
I think that these answers are owed to us.
But I would like to leave some concrete and specific notes regarding this first project on active and healthy aging that was presented to us.

And these notes are, from the start, a positive note, because I think it is positive that it focuses on a sector of the population that is particularly vulnerable in a Europe that is increasingly aging and increasingly disadvantaged.

However, I would like to add even more questions to these questions, because it seems contradictory to me that a project is presented in this area when, at the same time, we do not have a place to support this innovation.
How are we going to support it?
What is the vase?

Is there any viable innovation in a context like the one we are experiencing, in which there is a persistent and systematic attack on the welfare state, on the reduction of access to health, on the systematic cuts in the services provided, on the continued disinvestment in this area?
The title of the communication that was presented, "A Union of Innovation, More Employment, Improved Lives, Better Society", is ambitious.

I would even say that I would have no problem subscribing to it personally, but let's agree that it is contradictory to what has been the practice in the Member States, with the cuts and with the austerity measures.

I think that there is sustainable innovation if there are rigorous, sustainable, demanding public policies. If not, the light goes out, little remains and little response we have to give to these populations. Thank you very much.
Dear colleagues, we welcome the Commission's efforts to place research and innovation at the top of the political agenda.
We are facing an integrated strategy to make the European innovation ecosystem more effective and profitable in the service of a sustainable economy.
The European partnerships for innovation emerge as an instrument and the great challenges in which they are organized are sufficiently broad so as not to be the object of controversy.
However, it is not yet clear how the sub-themes priorities will be defined and how the preponderance of each discipline within them will be defined.
What level of transparency can be expected for stakeholders to participate? How to arbitrate conflicting interests?
What is the relative role of the Commission, the Member States, the regions?
How to ensure accountability within a complex structure?
What will be the financial dimension of these partnerships?
The Commission and the Council, Mr. President, must ensure excellence in the implementation, which is not guaranteed with the few months of pilot testing planned for the first partnership.

on the one hand, the workers are required to have them in order to access the market, which is the most elementary justice, and on the other hand, that these are compensated in the exact measure of the damage caused to them.

It is true that in these agreements there are winners and losers, so let us take care of the losers, because the winners do not need it.

concrete to help economic recovery, and in this case in a central domain, which is the energy domain.

And that is why I think this report can help us invest not only in energy efficiency and renewable energies, which is very important, but also in bringing concrete benefits to local populations, which naturally translates into concrete benefits for the European population as a whole.

microgeneration as presented here, and the last note that it was a great gain of this Parliament to manage to guarantee that there was a concrete definition of the amount of financing to be applied in these projects.

Dear President, dear colleagues, Mr. Commissioner Dali, the patient must have the right to know as much as possible about his disease and which medicines are available to treat it.
But how to distinguish information from advertising?
Where and how to gather objective and unbiased information?
There are different interpretations of the texts in force. It is necessary to harmonize them, striving to reinforce the sovereignty of the citizen.
The information must be reliable, validated by the authorities, independent, accessible and aimed at a non-specialized general public.
The aim is to create a more enlightened and responsible citizenship on the part of the end user.
The deadline given to the European Agency for tacit approval should be extended from 60 to 120 days.
The requirement of a foundation for rejection reinforces the adversarial system and balances the final result.
EMEIA has an essential role as a privileged source of objective information.

I would like to end by greeting rapporteur Fjellner for the work done and congratulate him for having accepted almost all the proposals I presented in the Internal Market Committee as rapporteur for the opinion. Thank you.

Commissioner, dear colleagues, the mortality of bees is increasing and the number of beekeepers is decreasing. A problematic situation for agriculture and for biodiversity, as has been said here, given the enormous implications in the production of food and plant species that depend on their pollination.
The life of a worker bee is very short, about six weeks, and is very sensitive to external changes.

nature and on which the highest level of research could contribute to obtaining better applied answers and more correct reinforcement of measures in favor of biodiversity and the reduction of the effects of climate instability.

Mr. President, let's be clear. The solidarity mechanism for sovereign debt did not work, it does not work. The price of Greek debt did not go down, Ireland is in trouble.

The economic turmoil and the contagion were not contained. The process that was created was created late, is intergovernmental and should have existed in another format since the beginning of the creation of the euro.
The President of the Commission now proposes a consolidation of this system.
But in the third of the instruments that are proposed to be used, it suggests the involvement of the private sector.
We had already heard this proposal from Chancellor Merkel and it was as a consequence of this premature and untimely announcement that the markets went crazy.
The Parliament will fully use its powers and with the greatest responsibility and spirit of cooperation in the co-decision process that accompanies the legislative package.
legislative on economic governance, but it will not do so by sacrificing haste, speed, putting quality in second place.

Therefore, let us be clear, the Parliament will actively participate, but a matter as serious as the solution of the sovereign debt cannot be decided on the sidelines and in defiance of European citizens and their representatives. The two elements are together.
Lastly, we Europeans need a clear European vision at this moment of crisis.

A European mechanism for consolidating sovereign debt is needed. Eurobonds need to be issued and the Eurozone needs to be sustainably protected through European systems and not intergovernmental ones.

It is necessary to strengthen the European budget. We cannot continue with 1% of the European budget level and it is necessary to place growth and real convergence at the center of European political priorities.
It is this agenda that the Commission and the new President must defend.
And the President of the Commission cannot be an emanation of the Ecofin Council.
This is what we need to present to European citizens.
Mr. President, Mr. President of the Council, Mr. President of the Commission, I would naturally like to say that the PPE's position is clear. It is a position in the sense that
that the resolution of this crisis, this serious crisis that Europe and the European Union are experiencing, can only be achieved through a deepening of economic governance and the community method.

For us, there is no doubt that only with more community method, only with economic government, only with the proper instruments of a true single currency in the Eurozone space, is it possible to face and tackle this crisis.
But this means that each of the institutions, the Council, the Commission and the Parliament, assume before the Europeans their responsibilities.
And it must be said that it is clear here that at least the largest groups of the European Parliament are willing to cooperate in an obvious way in the sense of increasing
The community method of introducing economic governance, of giving the single currency the necessary conditions for it to succeed in the context of the European crisis.

And it is also evident today that the same happens with the Commission and with the President of the Commission, who, contrary to what the Socialists and the deputy Elisa Ferreira say, has shown that it is neither an emanation of the Council nor an emanation of the Parliament, but an emanation of the European interest.
It is now up to the Council, in December, to assume its responsibilities.
This is what we count on and with your manifest adherence to the European ideal, President Van Rompuy.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. I would like to start by congratulating colleagues Luan and Manesco for the remarkable work they developed in their respective reports.
Both constitute an important contribution to the ongoing discussion on the new cohesion policy for the 2014-2020 horizon.
Today, more than ever, the achievement of economic, social and territorial cohesion is essential for the affirmation of the competitiveness of the European Union on a global scale.
This goal will only be achieved if we are aware that only by reinforcing and developing the regional dimension will we have a Europe that is cohesive internally and competitive externally.

In this particular case, I would highlight three points that I consider to be crucial. First of all, decentralization, making local and regional authorities, especially those with legislative powers, participate more and contribute to a better application of the cohesion policy.

Member States are invited to involve regional and local authorities in the negotiations on the future of the structural funds, on an equal footing with national authorities and representatives. And, lastly, the strengthening of the role of regional authorities in the preparation, management and implementation of programmes.
Only with the greater involvement of these authorities in the whole process will the principle of subsidiarity be fulfilled.

Another aspect that I consider crucial is the request for a simpler architecture for the funds after 2013, not as a consequence of the economic crisis, but as a general principle of the future cohesion policy, in order to facilitate the absorption of the funds.
The main concern underlying the Lisbon Treaty was to bring Europe closer to its citizens.
So let us not only do that, but also make their lives easier, avoiding unnecessary administrative burdens that are a deterrent to their participation.
Only then will we be able to achieve the goal of true territorial cohesion.
Only then will we see a reduction in the disparities within the European Union, which are currently very contrasting and with a huge gap between rich and poor regions.

More participation also means more responsibility. And it is this responsibility that must be assumed and shared by all, doing more and better in the sense of having a stronger and more competitive Europe.
Madam President, Madam Commissioner, colleagues. I begin by congratulating colleagues Edith Bauer and Anne Hedh for the excellent work done in this report.
Human trafficking dishonors our society and requires a strong and coordinated reaction from all of us.
Organized crime, which is behind sexual exploitation, forced labor, the trade in human organs and other ignoble practices, must be effectively combated, but must be primarily prevented.
What is at stake is the defense of human rights and the protection of the most vulnerable people, namely women and children.
Experience has shown that the current legal framework is not sufficiently effective and that the European Union needs to do more.
It is essential to have greater cross-border cooperation, including effective sharing of information and best practices.
This proposal, and well, highlights a victim-centered approach.
Policies in this area should cover aspects related to social issues, social inclusion, such as the social rehabilitation of the victim. Thank you very much.
The NATO Summit took place in Lisbon, so allow me to say a few words about what happened in my country in relation to this Summit.
At that time, the Portuguese authorities would prohibit the entry of European citizens into the country for only one reason: these citizens were bringing with them critical texts of the Alliance.
In these days, the least we can say is that there was an arbitrary regime in Portugal, a real thought police.
A regime so special that it led the Portuguese government to buy anti-riot material worth 5 million euros, which did not even arrive in time for the summit.
These are the priorities, after all, of a government that faces a huge social crisis.
In the Europe we dream of, freedom of expression is a fundamental value.
The Europe we dream of does not bow down to military organizations that write their history with blood.
From the NATO summit came the legitimization of its military intervention throughout the planet.
The subordination of the European Union to the military strategy and to the North American interests also came out.
Thirdly, the militarization of access to energy sources was consolidated.
Lastly, the military defense of the development model that generates environmental imbalances and that disturbs the social crisis was instituted.
Therefore, I would like to say, Madam President, that in my opinion, with this summit, we lose in democracy, we lose in freedom and we lose so that some may gain with war.

And now I give the floor to Mr. Rangel, who has one minute and a half. Thank you, Madam President. The first point that I wanted to make clear here and that is important to reinforce in this Parliament is that
That, contrary to what sometimes seems to be read in the press and in the statements of some European leaders, the euro, as a currency, was fundamental to respond to the current crisis.

Without the euro, we would be in a very difficult situation, with the currencies of the most fragile countries in a huge devaluation and with a possible German mark in an impossible appreciation to support the German economy and the European economy.

And that is why the euro was a factor of stability, especially not only for the countries that are in the eurozone, but also for the currencies of the countries that did not want to join the eurozone.

And for that very reason, because we have to defend this community that managed to respond to the crisis better than any other, and as we will see in the future, for example, what will happen to the dollar and the United States of America, we will see how the euro actually has advantages.

We now have the responsibility in this Council to do everything to defend the euro, namely to create a stabilization fund that follows the community method and that is capable of introducing responsibility in the...

Countries that are in a more fragile situation, fragility and solidarity in those that have fulfilled their obligations and that have not always shown, at least in their external statements, to be available to be solidary in the context of the Eurozone.

I would like to give my sincere congratulations to colleague Sorbú for the excellence of the report produced, strongly advising the Commission to take it into account, especially in those aspects in which the complex dimension of agricultural issues, which in many ways go beyond the strict dimension of agriculture,

Agriculture requires the involvement of other areas, such as competition, the internal market and financial regulation, and also requires its treatment in other extra-community forums, such as the G20 and the WTO.

The issues that are absolutely crucial for agriculture, for farmers and for the availability in sufficient quantity and quality of food to the populations of Europe and the world, can only be effectively addressed if they are tackled in all their dimensions.

The ambitious goals of the CAP reform can only be achieved if the reform goes beyond the narrow boundaries of agriculture and if its goals are also taken into account in the necessary interventions of other policy areas and in other global bodies.
This report made it very clear and I welcome it.

Thank you, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, and dear colleagues. I would like to start by thanking all the words that were left here regarding the report that the Parliament presents on Alzheimer's and other dementia diseases.
We all know that the situation we are experiencing is substantially dramatic and that it is still very underdiagnosed, as was mentioned here.
And I just want to mention one issue that was transversal to all the interventions, but probably not so highlighted, which is the issue of the dignity of patients, of their rights.

And not only of the patients, but also of their relatives and of those who take care of them, whether they are formal or informal caregivers, and of the professionals who are associated with this type of disease.

I am happy, frankly happy, with the words of the Commissioner when he says that he shares the same concerns as the European Parliament and that the European Commission sees all the recommendations of the report that the Parliament presents in a very positive light and that it will do everything in its power to put them into practice.
We know that each day that passes is later than the previous one, in this matter, it gives urgency to what we have in our hands.
And therefore, we also know that tomorrow the Parliament will speak about this matter.
We will await the result of the vote, but we know, Mr. Commissioner, that European citizens expect much more from us than solidarity and moral comfort.

They expect concrete and adequate actions from us. And I hope, Mr. Commissioner, that you will put into practice, and that the Commission, which has the initiative, which unfortunately this Parliament does not have, will put into practice.

All this priority that it gives to this domain and that transforms it into a legislative initiative so that citizens and their families see their rights respected and are treated with equality and dignity, as they deserve. Thank you very much.

First of all, I would like to say that this Parliament, on a day in which we are discussing the Hungarian presidency, without prejudice to being able to address all the issues it intends to, should focus on the problems of the European Union, which it is not doing here.

or aspects, which are aspects of Hungary’s internal life and which, at most, can be regulated in a healthy and normal relationship between the European Commission and the Hungarian Government and Parliament.
I would like to say here that, beyond the priority that the Hungarian Presidency will naturally give to the economic and financial issues on the agenda, I am very pleased to see that...
The Hungarian agenda for this semester is very clear and very ambitious, focusing on and prioritizing three issues that will be essential for Europe's future.

Food, which is about to enter a serious global crisis, energy, which is essential for our security and for our economic sustainability, and water, which has been little talked about, but which will be the next challenge for Europeans after food.
I wish you success in achieving your goals.

Thank you, Madam President. I think that these two countries, like others in this region, show us how, in recent years, European leaders have often been more on the side of business than of democracy, more on the side of dictators than of the poor.

I am frankly concerned about the situation that is currently taking place in Egypt and with today's developments. And that is why I understand that it is not calm that we should have, but we should have solidarity.
Solidarity with the millions of Egyptian citizens who are in Cairo and throughout the country, tired of hunger, tired of oppression, tired of unemployment.

And that is why, after today's speech by Mubarak, after the regime's dogs have been unleashed, after a clear and open path has been created for violence, we must say that we must stand by these people.
We cannot allow a strategy of fear to be created so that they return home.
36 years ago, in Portugal, we would have gone home if we had listened to these advices.
It is still good that we returned, because that way we had the Democratic Revolution.
Thank you, Mr. President. Mr. Commissioner, I would also like to say that I think this issue is important for us to continue living in the deception that we have lived in Europe.
A deception or a false promise, call it what you will, because we have been operating, especially in the matter of collecting stem cells from umbilical cords, based on information that is misleading.
And we know, and it has already been mentioned, that in Europe the collection of stem cells through the umbilical cord does not reach 1%.

And yet, we also know that its possibilities for the treatment of diseases can be endless, diseases such as those already mentioned, cancer, Alzheimer's disease, rare diseases, the possibilities are immense.

But what we let happen was the establishment of a set of private banks for the preservation of cells and telling parents that they could store their children's cells and from then on, at the time of birth, and from then on cure them in the future if necessary.
I think we should be more responsible than that, because the probability of guaranteeing that this happens is very low, as we know.
And this false promise that is sold to parents costs money.
In Portugal, for example, this false promise costs three and a half minimum wages.
The solution clearly involves creating public banks of stem cells, because only with public banks can we guarantee equal use and equal access.
and an effective medical treatment and more research that is equal for everyone and not just using stem cells as merchandise or a growing business that is only for some.
Therefore, I believe that solidarity, common sense and impartial information are not, after all, things that can be classified as excessive demands.
We do not have the power to impose, we have the power to promote.
This is within our competence and I think we should do it in the name of equality. Thank you very much.
Thank you, Mr. President. The price of food has reached its historical maximum and this is the seventh consecutive time that it has increased.
There are several factors that can explain this increase, the first being a short-term factor.
It has to do with the coincidence of bad weather conditions in some countries, such as Russia and Argentina.
But there are two factors that are structuring, they are of structuring order, and that is why I bring these two factors here.
The first one has to do with the fact that some food producers and consumers, who were exporters, have become importers, as is the case of China.
And the second one has to do with the fact that the weight of some large multinationals can make prices play in their favor.
The example of cereals is very clear at this level. It is dominated by six large multinationals.
This situation, therefore, places farmers in a huge uncertainty about the prices of food products.
Europe must, therefore, return to doing what it stopped doing some time ago, that is, protect its producers and consumers.
In a world where everyone resorts to protectionist measures and where multinationals manipulate prices, we cannot continue to be naive. Thank you very much.
I would like to congratulate the rapporteur colleague Marisa Matias and congratulate all those who collaborated with her.
Unfortunately, over the last few years, we have witnessed an increase in the falsification of medicines in Europe.
According to data from the European Union, 1.5 million boxes of counterfeit medicines are sold annually through the legal supply chain.
It is a criminal activity that represents a serious threat to European patients and to the European industry.
The objective of the present directive is to prevent the introduction of counterfeit medicines into the supply chain and thus protect public health.

I would like to highlight in the opinion that I have elaborated the following key points: the introduction of the definition of counterfeit medicine, clearly emphasizing the protection of the consumer, the application of security devices
safety of prescription drugs, accountability of all players in the distribution chain and, finally, the application by Member States of effective sanctions to deter this criminal activity.
Mr. President, I obviously want to thank all the comments that were made by all the colleagues and all the female colleagues.
I will not comment on them one by one, that is not the intention.
I think that if there were any doubts about what the word commitment means, it was made very clear here what commitment means.

We don't all have the perfect proposal, but much more important than knowing if it's the perfect proposal is knowing that we have an instrument in our hands that will allow us not to postpone the protection of patients' health any longer.
And we have the obligation not to postpone its adaptation, we have the obligation not to postpone real action, and we can only do this together.
I must also say, personally, and the Commissioner mentioned the issue of inspections, in my initial proposal I presented an amendment for mandatory inspections in third countries.
Compromise is exactly that. And, in the meantime, you gain in some things, you lose in others.
The Commission explained to us that it would be impossible to obtain this.
I would like to leave another note regarding this commitment.
I think we all see ourselves in the commitment, but I also think and am aware that we will all be demanding for it to be fulfilled, because otherwise it will not be effective.

In this commitment, safeguards are guaranteed so that we can follow the process, evaluate and systematically have information that allows us to verify if it is being implemented or not, properly or not, and if changes are needed.

I would like to conclude by thanking the European Commission for its collaboration, and in particular the Spanish Presidency and the Belgian Presidency, with whom we have worked together over the last six months.
There are no perfect proposals, no perfect interventions, there are flaws, but I think we have a strong and robust commitment to allow us to fight and defend the health of patients.
And as my intervention is also full of flaws, I failed to thank colleagues Regina Bastos and Amália Sartori, from the partners of the other commissions.
Thank you very much for your support as well.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, it is not worth repeating that the current moment is the most serious test to the survival of the euro and, therefore, of Europe.
The Polymath report opens up constructive solutions and that is why I also want to congratulate our colleague for the ideas she has put forward.

The gravity of the moment does not result from the fact that the Eurozone as a whole has a deficit or excessive external debt. It results, rather, from the fact that the economies that comprise it diverge persistently and gravely under the impact of common policy.
And we lack the tools that allow the convergence between these economies, that allow Europe to regain balance, that allow Europe to grow.

Let's be clear, the Eurozone and the European Union will not survive with the current level of integration and the diversity of the economies that make them up, with a growth of 1% of the collective wealth.
In practice, after the crisis, the only solution we were able to build was the austerity recipe. And it is the workers and the companies who are paying for it today.
the deficits generated by the speculative crisis of the financial sector, in the rescue of which 26% of the wealth of the European Union was committed.
The tax on financial transactions, with a very low rate, for example, 0.05% on transactions of high-risk, highly speculative products, it is true that they should be paid by their consumers.
But why shouldn’t they pay, if ordinary citizens pay VAT on bread, milk and other basic products?
The tax burden must be redistributed in a way that harms workers and companies less and is shared more evenly by the financial sectors, particularly the speculative ones.
And Mr. Commissioner, I think that the Commission cannot, at this moment, refuse or evade the clear message that this Parliament is giving you politically.
The public consultation cannot exclude the analysis of the tax on financial transactions, on the contrary, it must be analyzed with the highest priority.
We know very well what happened with the H1N1 flu and that should serve as a lesson to all of us.

And I don't know if you remember well how all this started, but the truth is that it started in one way and then the response was completely disproportionate in relation to the dimension of the problem.
That is why the report that was voted on today is so important, because we must learn from what was done so that it is not repeated.
We have the right to know who made the decisions, how the whole story unfolded and who decided that it should have happened that way.
As we have the right to know which countries responded in a certain way, why they responded, without transparency and without leaving us...
We must have the least possible doubts, because we have all the doubts if there is no deal. We must have the guarantee that no residue remains if there is no deal related to this flu.
That is why I understand, Madam President, that all public health threats must be faced, but it is not indifferent the way they are faced, nor who pays for them.

Thank you very much, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner. We are here to talk about proposals on salaries and proposals on the retirement age, and the least we can say about these proposals is that they are frankly unfair.
They are unfair and insist on recipes that have already been proven more than once to be failed recipes.

There is no guarantee in the society we live in. And that is why I would like to conclude by saying, Mr. President and Mr. Commissioner, we cannot continue to condemn people to poverty.
I hope, sincerely,
Thank you, Mr. President. I begin by saying that I fully support what my colleague said.
The prevention of natural and man-made disasters is of enormous and growing importance and the European Commission systematically presents us with a number of intentions of procedure and calendar.
But there is a very complicated problem, as already mentioned.
The Solidarity Fund is an instrument that normally responds to these situations, but it responds in a very, very long time, nine months to a year. And this is after the disaster.
As also already mentioned, and I repeat, and we will repeat it as many times as necessary, the case of Madeira, which had a huge disaster a year ago, has not yet received any support.
And I ask this and reinforce this question. Isn’t it time for the Commission to review the procedure of the fund itself and the funding model itself?
How can we maintain an emergency fund to deal with situations that are increasingly chronic?
We don’t know where it will happen, but we know that it will happen, and climate change is there to prove it.
Therefore, the exception can never respond to a situation of regularity. Thank you very much.

Mr. President, the concerns raised here regarding the prevention and response to disasters are of great sensitivity and of the utmost importance to our populations, which should not and cannot be postponed.

We are talking about very sensitive situations, which affect people's safety and their belongings, which often move us all due to the loss of lives, the destruction of families, the devastation of entire lives of work.

But all our demonstrations are of little value in the face of the dramas that, in a media way, impress and sensitize everyone, if we then fall asleep on the work we must do so that those situations can be avoided, minimized or better assisted.
Mr. Commissioner, the matter here is very well focused by my colleagues.

It is an area where the European Union can better demonstrate its presence alongside its citizens, helping them to prevent disasters, especially when they occur, and be by their side in the moments when they need it most and are most vulnerable.
I will answer with all my face, although I do not want to turn a debate of the European Parliament into a debate about Portuguese politics.

By the way, if deputy Edith Estrela wants to debate Portuguese politics, she has a simple solution. We must have elections, candidates for the Portuguese Parliament, and she will have the opportunity, in the opposition, to debate with the PSD government the policies she intends for Portugal.
I only say this, we can no longer bear a government that failed four times over two years.
It is impossible, it is unsustainable, it is not credible to the markets, there are no more solutions with the socialist government.

Thank you very much, Mr. President. Madam Commissioner, dear colleagues, I begin by congratulating colleague Schwab for the negotiating persistence that led to this important commitment and I also congratulate all those who collaborated with him in this report.

We want not only to ensure a high level of protection for European consumers, but also that European companies, regardless of their size, can provide goods and services to consumers in the 27 Member States without unnecessary legal obstacles.
This new directive will end the legislative fragmentation that has been harming the participation of our companies in the cross-border market and will give an important boost to the internal market.
It highlights the new provisions regarding the information to be provided to the consumer, requiring that this information be clear, intelligible and provided in a timely manner.
It is also important that the burden of proof regarding the compliance with the information requirements falls on the trader.
As for contracts concluded at a distance, especially those concluded by telephone or over the Internet, their rules should be defined and the consumer protected by simple and effective mechanisms.

We are certain that, at the end of the institutional negotiations, the new directive will contribute to making the European Union more competitive and dynamic, as is required in a global economy. Thank you very much.

Thank you very much, Madam President, Mr. President of the Council and Mr. President of the Commission. First of all, I would like to congratulate you on the results of the Council of 24 and 25 March, namely the consolidation of the semester of

European, but much more than that, either by the institutionalization of the European Stability Mechanism, or by the bundle, so to speak, of the Euro Plus Pact, which had already come from the Eurozone Summit of March 11.
I believe these are very positive results for Europe and it is a shame that this process was not completely concluded on March 24th and 25th.
I believe that if we had given that signal, if the States had given that signal in the Council, closing this reform package of the Fund, we would be today in a much better position.

stronger to face the 3-4 months. And, in part, we would have mitigated the effects of the crisis that my country, Portugal, is currently experiencing, and about which I also do not want to fail to say a word.
To say that, in the case of the PSD, fully integrated in the PPE, there is an absolute and total availability to comply with the requirements and obligations of integration in the European space.
That is what we have done, even now, at this moment, when there are difficulties regarding short-term financing,
Unlike what the Socialist government has done, the Social Democratic Party has shown total availability to give Europe the guarantees that are necessary in the context of this crisis.

And with this I want to give this signal, without bringing internal politics to the European Parliament, of the commitment, of the pledge, of the total guarantee of the Social Democratic Party in the rigorous agenda that the country will have to have after its elections on June 5th.
Thank you very much, Madam President, dear colleagues, Commissioner Stefan Fule. The historic moment we are living in demands a firm and determined action.
Like many of you, it is with a mix of hope, concern and expectation that we watch the events unfolding in the Mediterranean basin.

However, I am satisfied with the proactive position that the Parliament is preparing to adopt regarding the review of the European Neighborhood Policy for the South, which I hope will lead to a greater presence of the Union in this area, not only as a payer, but also as a committed partner.
First of all, by affirming the absolute need to defend our founding values in relations with neighboring countries.
We can no longer compromise in the defense of democracy, nor in the defense of human rights, and much less in the defense of social justice.

We can no longer privilege short-term stability at the expense of the superior interests of citizens and their uncompromising defense, of their individual and collective freedom, with particular attention to the rights of women.
In the future, the Union must prioritize a bottom-up approach in its neighborhood policy.
It is essential that this happens.
Only greater involvement of local communities and civil society will ensure maximum effectiveness in its implementation.

But I cannot help but express a frustration. I regret that this Parliament and the Commission do not want to take this opportunity to differentiate, once and for all, the Eastern Neighbourhood Policy, with the countries that potentially can become, in the future, our partners in the Union, from the Southern Neighbourhood Policy.
I also challenge the Commission to demonstrate, in its review process of April 20, the ambition that the current moment demands. A policy of neighborhood...
Tailor-made for each State, with clear benchmarks and a careful assessment that allows for a future Mediterranean economic space with the new democracies of the South.

To conclude, Mr. Commissioner, we trust that the good environment and cooperation that have characterized the work on this topic will lead to the permanent involvement of the European Parliament in the planning and evaluation of this policy. Thank you very much.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. The reports we are debating, and which I congratulate the rapporteurs for, reinforce a set of initiatives that aim to relaunch the internal market.
I would like to highlight the commitment of the European Commission, particularly of Commissioner Barnier, whom I greet, and the positive reception of this Parliament through the
Consumer Protection and Internal Market Commission, to give priority to the competitiveness and dynamism of the market, a fundamental pillar of the 2020 Strategy.
Citizens and companies expect effective boosts so that Europe can grow economically again, expect an increase in employment, and aspire to create more prosperity.

And as the Commissioner pointed out, the opening of markets to our companies, eliminating obstacles and difficulties, will give them a very special boost and an unparalleled opportunity that will allow them to continue their mission as the driving force of our economy.

The measures aimed at reducing the administrative and bureaucratic burden of SMEs and their access to credit and to the services market, the European patent and the recognition of qualifications are essential.
The relevance of the development of e-commerce to strengthen the confidence of consumers and companies in this type of trade. The bet on innovation.
Important for strong and lasting growth. Social entrepreneurship is essential to create innovative business projects for social inclusion.
These are some of the measures that will ensure this ambitious project of completing, deepening and making the most of the single market for the benefit of European citizens.
Finally, the important recommendation for Member States to redouble efforts to improve the transposition and implementation of the rules of the internal market. Thank you very much.
I also want to add my voice to all those who have expressed concerns here about the low income of fishermen, aggravated by the historical prices reached by fuels, particularly in recent months.
As it was very well said here, the cost of fuels has a very high impact on the survival of our small and medium-sized shipowners, particularly aggravating the already fragile fishing yields.

This vertiginous rise in prices is also bringing us deep negative effects: reduction of trips to the sea, miserable earnings on the part of fishermen, aggravated by the low prices paid in the first sale.

Increase in imports from landlocked countries of aquaculture and fishing products for the European market and a consequent abandonment of the activity due to financial difficulties with the loss of jobs.
In this context, to avoid the continuity of the worsening of the crisis, it is necessary to act, and to act with celerity and with depth in the problems of fishing.

The Commission must therefore provide positive responses with short and long-term measures to face the adversities that the sector is facing and the serious losses of income that our fishermen are experiencing.
Mr. President, Mr. Reporter. First of all, I would like to congratulate, in particular, the work of our PPE colleague, Mário David, who I represent today, for being absolutely...
I am unable to attend this plenary session and I wanted to say that we always considered that support for the victims of the floods in Pakistan was an ethical and moral imperative.
And for this reason, we strongly support all measures that were taken in the sense of traditional humanitarian aid.
We do consider that we should continue to work towards helping to stabilize the situation of so many millions of affected people.
What we cannot accept is that the European Union's trade policy is now considered an appropriate and adequate instrument for humanitarian aid.

The truth is that this brings two dire consequences. One consequence within the European Union, especially for the southern countries and for their textile and clothing industry, which is now highly weakened by an economic, social and financial crisis without parallel since the

Firstly, in the Union. And secondly, at a global level, in the WTO negotiations, where this opening of the largest commercial bloc in the world, which is the European Union, to these potential Pakistani exports, can completely unbalance the negotiations.
And it is no coincidence that they find themselves in the impasse they are in.
It is therefore natural that, in a situation like this, we had to say, regarding the history of this regulation and the difficulty it had in these eight months of intense negotiations,

We have collaborated with the most constructive proposals, which we will now, unfortunately, have to take a position, which will be a position in the sense of supporting the amendment that, in essence, provides for the end of this regulation proposal as we know it.
We will have to do it at this moment, not for less solidarity with Pakistan, but because we consider that humanitarian aid should be given in the right place and in the right way.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, I would like to start by saying that, naturally, I believe that the agreement that was reached for Portugal is a balanced agreement.
It is a very hard agreement for the populations, but it puts its fundamental point in the structural reforms to increase growth and competitiveness.
and I believe that this is very positive.

I do not take the attitude of others who consider that countries like Greece, Ireland and Portugal did everything right, they did not make mistakes, they did not exaggerate, they did everything right and it was only the international crisis that caused problems.

No, our governments made mistakes and had wrong policies. But that does not mean that there is no opportunity now, in the context of the Union, to have here the possibility of getting back on the right and correct path.

And that is why it is important to remember here that, in fact, it is necessary to say to the public opinion that is against the support to the countries in difficulty that they are not giving money to these countries, they are only lending money to these countries.
But they are lending it at very high interest rates and, therefore, they are making a deal that is positive for their budgets and for their populations.

But I also say here that perhaps it is time to have a global European response with the admission of eurobonds, with the admission of the possibility of selling in the primary market to respond to international markets.

And it would perhaps be time for the European Commission itself, the Fund and the IMF to review the interest rates, so as to give the possibility of lowering these rates, to have a sustained growth of these countries that are today in difficulties.

Thank you. I give the floor for one minute to Mr. Correia de Campos. Thank you very much, Mr. President, Madam Commissioner and Madam Rapporteur. This strategy is important for all European countries, especially for those whose economy lacks more competitiveness.
It is essential for the creation of small and medium-sized companies.
Today, it is more about the active generation of new jobs.
It is essential for universities and laboratories, whose relationship with the productive sectors depends on part of their survival.
It is essential for the financial system, which will have a new market in innovation, as the classic manufacturing model is exhausted.

Innovation is at the top of the European agenda and, being a pillar of the EU 2020 strategy, it will have to be served by new financial instruments so that it does not succumb to budgetary limitations of the moment.
I would finally like to greet Judith Merkies for her important contribution to a more innovative Europe and with an economy more based on knowledge. Thank you very much.
Madam President, Madam Commissioner, I would like to start by congratulating colleague Odi for his excellent report.

The mid-term evaluation, although late, allowed to highlight the critical aspects of the 7th Program, its excessive bureaucracy, the industry's disinterest, the number and complexity of the new instruments, the slow pace of disbursements.
There is still a greater risk of diverting funds from the current framework program to large-scale programs of questionable added value.

But it also allowed to highlight positive aspects, a greater articulation and international cooperation between scientific groups in common projects, some cases of success, among them the European Research Council, and a greater gender balance.
There are priorities that must be developed. First, simplification. Second, promoting scientific excellence, not in some countries, but throughout Europe. A greater connection of...

The framework program with innovation, with instruments aimed at small and medium-sized companies and entrepreneurship, of which the most successful is the Eurostar program, which should be expanded. Thank you.

Madam President, Mr. Commissioner, I will address the proposal that I have come here today to present to Parliament and I tell you frankly that I think we have the right, some of us, to be disappointed with this proposal, because the proposal that is presented is not only weak, but it also has immense gaps.
I think this is a European issue, not an issue of the States that have a nuclear industry and those that do not, it is an issue of the whole of Europe and Europe desperately needs good news.
And I must sincerely tell you that one of these good news is to guarantee to the citizens that we are taking care of their safety.
Now, when these tests are done in the terms that the Commissioner presents, that is, a first phase is done by the interested parties themselves, a second phase is done by the States that

They defend those interested parties. And a third phase is done by the parties that are truly interested. I wonder if the result will not be to say, after all, that all nuclear power plants are in very good health and recommend them.

We know that is not the case and, therefore, I hope there will be serious consequences and that we can tell our citizens that we are taking care of their security and not just pretending to do so. Thank you very much.
I expect from this European Council, especially with the climate that has been experienced in recent weeks, a decision of great responsibility.
And with more responsibility than the one that existed in the last Council, in which a problem was postponed for three months, only because of electoral calendars.

I hope that this decision of responsibility will essentially make it clear that economic and financial issues are crucial and decisive for Europe, but that economic and financial issues are instrumental for what is the main purpose of Europe, which is the purpose of maintaining peace.
If an approach to the problems is made that leads only to the States beginning to distrust each other, to install distrust among the different States.

To create and to stir up differences and rivalries between the states of the South and the states of the North, between the central states and the peripheral states. What we have been led to is the decline of the European Union.

I believe that what is at stake in this European Council, regardless of the technical solutions, regardless of the political disagreements, is whether we want or not the European project to continue to be a valid project for the strategy of peace in Europe.
I think that's what's at stake.
What I notice in many speeches by leaders, both those in countries in difficulty and those in creditor countries,
It is an irresponsible speech, which often even appeals to some characteristics of nationalities that are extremely negative.
I therefore appeal, and only for this, to the sense of responsibility of the leaders of the European governments to find solutions that lead Europe to an exit and to a solution.

Thank you very much, Madam President, Mr. Commissioner. My first words are to praise the work done by the rapporteur, colleague Jorge S. Travacáquis, who did an extraordinary job in identifying the future synergies for enhanced effectiveness among the various structural funds.

Your report is also part of this joint debate on cohesion policy, a debate that assumes greater importance not only because of the substance of the topic, but also, and above all, because of the opportunity in terms of the timing of its discussion.
In fact, we are currently in the process of learning about the Commission's proposal, not only regarding the new financial perspectives, but also regarding the future cohesion policy post-2013.
The policy of cohesion is a fundamental policy for the European Union.

It is a horizontal policy that, through its instruments of excellence, the structural funds, finances projects and programs in the Member States, seeking to reduce the disparity between the levels of development of the various regions.
Experience, however, has shown us the difficulties in terms of efficiency and results that stem from the fragmentation and complexity of this policy.

That a single strategic framework for the various funds, with an integrated and results-oriented approach, is the starting point for more and better synergies between the various instruments and for strengthening their effectiveness.
It is also essential for better coordination between the various sectoral policies and for better efficiency in the application of resources.
We must take advantage of the danger of crisis to seek new alternatives.

It is certain that all these reports that are being discussed today will pose enormous challenges. And we know that to respond to these challenges we also need a good budget. But we have to make a clear distinction between budgetary aspects and political objectives.
The political objectives are well known. And, in fact, only by affirming these political objectives will we be able to offer a future to the regions.

And if that is the case, we must then put the budget at the service of the future of the regions and of the citizens, and not the citizens and the regions at the service of the budget. Thank you very much.
Thank you, Mr. President. The cohesion policy is the key policy for the future of the European project.
The construction of a common space, with an internal market and a proper currency, requires a certain level of convergence of its member states and regions in order to function.
The current competitiveness differences and the development asymmetries inevitably led to the fragility of the European space and to the crisis that affects the Eurozone.
This is why this vital need for convergence absolutely requires a powerful cohesion budget, which cannot be weakened to finance other policies.
The European Union, to do more, has to have more. And this is achieved by increasing its budget and not reducing, even if cleverly, the cohesion budget.

I therefore ask the Commissioner if the creation of the Fund for Infrastructures and the new innovation policies, which will be articulated with cohesion and regional development, which I support, without an increase in the Community budget, will not be transformed into the Trojan horse introduced in the cohesion budget.

The modernization and renovation of the energy infrastructure are essential factors for the objectives of sustainable and intelligent growth that we seek with the 2020 Strategy and for the energy security that we need.
It is essential to involve all regions in this challenge.

For this, the incentives provided in the regulatory systems must be improved, namely those that apply to higher risk projects and more innovative projects, such as those being developed in the Azores Islands in renewable energies.

The regions should be associated with the phases of conception and implementation of projects, in the definition of priorities, in their elaboration and execution, because this guarantees better results and, therefore, a better defense of the European interest.
The current economic moment further emphasizes the need to adopt an innovative and integrated approach to energy issues, taking into account all aspects, economic, environmental and social.
It is essential not to lose sight of its medium and long-term effects, seeking to ensure all European citizens a safe, sustainable and affordable energy.

The report we are debating is of particular importance, considering the influence that social services of general interest have on the daily lives of European citizens, as well as on social cohesion, job creation and economic growth.

The collaboration with rapporteur Próncias de Roça was very fruitful and clarifying, as the rapporteur himself just said, allowing for the adoption of several commitments in the Employment and Social Affairs Committee.
For the result that we have here today and that we are debating, I congratulate and praise the reporter.
In fact, on our part, the main concern was to make it clear that the competencies in this matter fall to the Member States.
The national authorities are responsible for defining, organizing and financing social services of general interest.
Thus, it is unnecessary to create harmonizing legislation at the European level, given that the realities of these social services of general interest are very diverse in the 27 Member States.

Just look at the health services, social security, employment, social housing, which are examples that proximity and knowledge of the contexts are the cornerstone for the adequate and fair provision of these services. Thank you very much.

Mr. President, as the rapporteur of the opinion of the REGI on the future of the European Social Fund, I would like to congratulate my colleague de Roos, highlighting the fact that we are facing an essential pillar of the social market economy model that we defend for Europe and in which the ESF plays a fundamental role in its cohesion.

Social cohesion at the level of the European Union advises not to neglect the existence of minimum protection levels in all Member States, without prejudice to the respect of the competences of their national, regional and local authorities.

European regions play a very important role in providing these services to the population and their opinion must be taken into account, given the nature of their constraints to ensure the provision to the population.

In a time of crisis, such as the one we are currently experiencing, the National Health Service constitutes a social protection network for the most disadvantaged or for those whose income does not allow them access to private services.
It is thus important to ensure that Member States that decentralize powers do so with the respective financial means so that regional and local authorities can ensure good service to the populations.
Ms. Ashton, I begin by saying that it is obvious that we must continue to support the democratic revolutions that are taking place in these countries.
I don’t have much time and that’s why I just want to leave some notes.
First of all, we cannot forget that the conditions for negotiation, considering a democratic transition and not a civil war, have to be defined by the people who are in these countries.
The situation in Syria is serious, this applies to Syria but also to Yemen and Bahrain.

If we want to avoid civil war, the last thing these countries need is to have Europe meddling in their internal affairs, and especially, and very particularly, through the presentation of military or paramilitary solutions.
And I say this because we must totally reject what is happening in Libya.
NATO and the United Nations have surpassed all the resolutions, even those that were voted by the United Nations Security Council.
It is this silence regarding Libya, this repudiation that we must make, and it is because it does not contain this resolution that I cannot subscribe to it. Thank you very much.

Thank you very much, Mr. President, Mr. President of the Commission, Mr. Prime Minister. First of all, I would like to congratulate the Polish Presidency for the ambitious program it has brought here, and in particular, congratulate it for the...

Neighborhood policy, not only to the East, but also to the South border, where I believe that there is, at this moment, a challenge and, perhaps, more demanding than the one we have to the East, which is more long-term and less short-term.

But having said that, I would like to ask the Prime Minister and the Polish Presidency to pay special attention to economic integration policies, economic governance and the supervision of financial markets.
I believe that, at this moment, no matter how ambitious our goals are in the areas of defense, energy, food security, environment, agriculture, and multi-annual financial frameworks, if we do not...

If we do not solve, in a clear and solid way, the problem of the debt crisis in the European context, we will not have a strong enough Europe to deal with the challenges that the Polish presidency has set itself.

And for this reason I was calling attention to the fact that it is fundamental to convince the remaining Heads of State and Heads of Government that it is necessary to give more economic integration, more economic government to the European Union.

Without this, what will happen is that instead of being the leaders or at least the representatives of our people, whether in the Council, in the Parliament, in the European Commission of Interest, instead of being that, we will be just...
Mr. President, as the President of the Mashreq Delegation, I would like to leave a phrase about each one of my, in quotes, obviously, four countries.
Starting with Syria and reiterating what some colleagues have already said, I regret that the international community seems, in the eyes of public opinion, to have two weights and two measures.

It is necessary to denounce, if necessary, the countries that in the Security Council, and I am obviously referring to Russia and China, and, well, Brazil, but with the right to veto, have prevented the international community from taking a position more in line with the values that we share.
Regarding Egypt, there is an urgent need to raise awareness among Egyptian authorities about the postponement of elections, as has already been done in Tunisia.
As for Lebanon, it is necessary, I believe, that this debate should send a very clear message to the new Lebanese government.
so that they are aware that they will be judged based on their conduct in relation to the charges brought by the Special Tribunal for Lebanon.
Jordan is an example that a peaceful transition is possible and that, perhaps, there is only a need, at this stage, to sensitize and encourage the authorities to accelerate the reform process.
We cannot forget, obviously, in a debate of this kind, the peace process in the Middle East and reiterate our hope that the Quartet meeting next Monday can...
to be productive and to reaffirm that this House would certainly like to see a much greater involvement of the European Union in this whole process.

I have no doubt that there will be a new round of negotiations before the United Nations General Assembly in September. But I hope that this round of negotiations will be productive and done in good faith.
Thank you, Mr. President. I would like to congratulate the rapporteur and all those who contributed to achieving this work.
There is no doubt that this report will be a reference in terms of recommendations and solid and coordinated responses to the challenges of the crisis.
If there is a conclusion that can be drawn, it is that the crisis we are experiencing will only be overcome with a deepening of European integration.

In a time of serious financial, economic and social difficulties and of painful austerity measures in some Member States, such as in my country, Portugal, it is tempting to take refuge in a protectionist and nationalist attitude.
But this is a mistake.

The European response to the crisis involves a true European economic government that pursues sustainable growth, promotes job creation and develops the social market economy, providing long-term answers with defined objectives with which the Member States identify.
The strategy to exit the crisis needs to be financed with a sufficiently ambitious community budget.

To avoid a new sovereign debt and euro crisis, it is necessary to have closer coordination in terms of budgetary policies, as well as the creation of a system for issuing public debt securities and eurobonds.
I conclude by emphasizing that, in this difficult period, it is also necessary to maintain social protection levels, especially for the most vulnerable citizens. Thank you very much.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, Presidency in office, it is usual to say that crises help to strengthen Europe.
Historically, that was the case, but today I am not so sure that this is still true.

The slow, improvised, reactive way the Union is reacting to the Greek crisis worsens the situation every day and spreads the contagion and lack of confidence in the Union and its currency in a frightening way.
This, despite the problems of the Eurozone, result in obvious flaws in the construction of the single currency, which today are concentrated in its most fragile links.

For the current crisis to result in the strengthening of the Union, a strategic vision is needed, as there was in the past, and which, unfortunately, neither the Commission nor the Council have been able to impart to the program and to the European project.
This report from the Parliament, however, gives us this vision: more Europe and not less is the solution.
The Parliament reminds that the market and the single currency generate intolerable divergences between economies and that they must be countered by specific policies.

It acknowledges that the functioning of the euro requires a reinforced European budget with own resources. It requires a European agency for the joint issuance of debt, capable of protecting the States from market speculation.

and provide them with credit at reasonable prices and terms. It also recognizes that diplomas and the transferability of workers between countries require mutual recognition of social rights and pensions.
The Parliament united to send clear messages. We hope that the Commission and the Council will listen to them.

Madam President, Madam Commissioner, dear rapporteur colleague, I would first of all like to congratulate and give my best wishes to the rapporteur colleague for considering that this report is extremely useful and allows us, in fact, to take new steps in the area of mediation.
The report presents an overview, a range of the solutions adopted by the various Member States in the implementation of the
Directive 2008/52/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 21 May 2008 relates to mediation in civil and commercial matters.
Now, we all know the advantages of mediation.
On the one hand, it is a judicial mechanism for conflict resolution, it contributes to the decongestion of courts, to the rationalization of the justice system, providing, at the same time,
providing the parties with the possibility of obtaining an amicable, faster and less costly, less onerous solution to the dispute in which they are involved.

It is therefore crucial to reaffirm the objective of the first article of the Directive, when it calls for the adoption of measures to encourage the use of alternative dispute resolution methods, and in particular mediation.
Promoting access and use of extrajudicial means of conflict resolution contributes to improving, simplifying and making our justice system more accessible.

It is therefore a very important challenge for the European Union and for the establishment of the area of freedom, security and justice, I would say for the idea of the rule of law within the European Union.
And it is for this reason that in this context of crisis, I consider it very important that, as stated in the report, it is possible to raise public awareness, the operators...
judicial experts on this topic and appeal here to the Commission and to the Commissioner so that a legislative proposal on alternative dispute resolution is presented quickly.
Thank you very much, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner. I also want to refer to the fundamental importance of this report in terms of transparency of what is the European energy market.
And I just want to say that it is a central domain of cooperation in European terms, if we safeguard some of the dimensions that are fundamental. Among them, avoiding that...
Liberalization translates into an increase in energy prices for citizens, ensuring equal access and taking care in terms of sanctions, as already mentioned by numerous colleagues.

And precisely because this is a central domain of European cooperation, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, I cannot fail to refer to it and to question it and ask you, looking you in the eyes, Mr. Commissioner,
I would like to give you the opportunity to explain the recent statements you made regarding Greece, Ireland and Portugal, as they are also matters of European cooperation.
Symbolic measures such as flying flags at half-mast, Mr. Commissioner, is to reinforce the shame of citizens who are worthy and who fight for a more...

Thank you very much, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner Šefčovič, Council representatives, Polish Presidency. First of all, I would like to clarify that I will be speaking here in a dual capacity. On the one hand, replacing the author of the opinion of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs.

Constitutional, my colleague Mr. Schmidt, Danish, who is absent because the election process is taking place in Denmark at this moment, and therefore I am representing him as a member of the AFCO, but also as a member of the jury, as a shadow rapporteur in the jury of this report.

The first issue I wanted to address is that, in the crisis we are in, in the economic and financial crisis, the issue of smart regulation, of smart regulation, of better legislation, is a central issue.

There is no doubt that in the so-called structural reforms that can boost the economic and financial take-off of the European space, the improvement in legislation and regulation is absolutely essential.

It is evident that a Europe that aims to be, on the one hand, dynamic and competitive, must have simple and accessible regulation for businesses and, obviously, for citizens. And, therefore, it must be guided by their needs.
The truth is that, in this sense, it is essential today that, first of all, the program of reduction of administrative burdens is achieved, that all efforts are made in the sense of...

Promote consultations with market agents, with representative associations of citizens and companies, and that the impact assessment of the legislation itself is carried out, which is also extremely important, so that the

The decision-making process can essentially be based on the opinion of those who are the recipients of the legislation and can be done without administrative assignments and with the least economic and financial costs.

It is important to say that, for the Commission on Constitutional Affairs in particular, the idea of the principle of proportionality and subsidiarity is relevant, this idea that European intervention should be an appropriate intervention and not an intervention that promotes the complexification of the system.

...legal and of the regulatory system. And for this reason, we give special attention, in our opinion, to the reinforced role that national parliaments have in this dynamic, precisely because of the principle of proportionality and the principle of subsidiarity.

It is therefore essential that, also at the level of smart regulation and at the level of improving legislation, we now involve the national parliaments, so that, whether at the European level or at the national level, both legislation and regulation...

so that they are more agile, more intelligent, more efficient. And, therefore, this is a good time for us to put into practice what we announce every day, which is a more competitive Europe and a more agile Europe through more intelligent regulation.
Mr. President, the number of homeless people, as well as those living below the poverty line, has not stopped increasing in recent years in several Member States.
The economic, financial and social crisis and the increase in unemployment have aggravated this problem, as everyone has already diagnosed.
We also all agree that this phenomenon is the denial of important values of the European Union, respect for human dignity and respect for fundamental rights.
In my country, for example, which is subject to a strong austerity measure, the concept of homeless, according to the National Plan, encompasses people who go to ask for help to have a meal.
The number of people seeking help to eat has increased by more than 20% since 2008.
There is a greater increase in families and people in need, who have seen their living conditions altered by unemployment and also by bank indebtedness.
This is just one example that shows the seriousness of this situation.
Last year, the European Parliament approved a written declaration on a strategy for the European Union for the homeless.

With this statement, this Parliament has alerted to the need for the European Union to equip itself with a strategy supported by national and regional strategies, with the long-term objective of ending the situations of people who sleep on the street and long-term homelessness.
National strategies should focus on preventive measures, but also on concrete actions to improve the quality of services provided to the homeless and the availability of affordable housing.
It is also evident that this European strategy must be compatible with the social housing policy of the Member States.
We took note of the Commissioner's words and registered the point of the situation that he made.
I finish by urging the European Commission to give a strong push to coordinate the action of Member States and regional authorities in order to combat this social injustice. Thank you very much.
We are debating the peace process in the Middle East, but is there any process going on that I have missed?
Unfortunately, no.

The European Union repeatedly states, as does the majority of the international community, the existence of two peoples and two states sharing the space between the Jordan River and the Mediterranean, who have the right to aspire to live in peace and security.
But without dialogue between the parties, in which, being in a pile of hatreds and misunderstandings that has been going on for 63 years, only extremisms and frustrations are fed.

It is essential that Europe and the Arab League get much more involved in the search for a negotiated solution for the borders, based on the ones that existed in 1967, with the exchanges that allow the majority of the Jewish settlements to remain in Israel.

That the issue of Jerusalem, a holy city, future capital of the two states, be clarified and mutually accepted as a symbol of peaceful coexistence between two peoples who have the obligation to fulfill the prophecy of Isaiah that it is the land of milk and honey.

That all countries of the world participate in the resolution of the Palestinian refugee issue and that the international community, and in particular the Arab nation, participate in the necessary financial compensations.

It is still absolutely essential that a military force under the aegis of the UN and the participation, among others, of American and Islamic forces be placed on the ground as a guarantor of the maintenance of peace.
May there be courage and political will.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, tourism requires a clear and coordinated European approach, with a close look at the potential and challenges that the different tourism modes have to offer us.
The tourist diversity that the European Union presents is so rich that it allows for an exponential growth of this sector and of the European Union's own competitiveness.

A bet on this key sector, which represents 10% of the GDP and about 12% of employment in the European Union, will allow to create not only European added value, but also to face the economic crisis in which we find ourselves.
I come from an ultra-peripheral region, Madeira, where tourism is the main economic activity.

And for this reason, the creation of a specific section for the sector in the 2014-2020 financial framework is essential for the cohesive and sustainable growth of tourism, which is essentially composed of small and medium-sized companies.

The implementation of a true European policy for sustainable and diversified tourism requires a concrete strategic plan, with a well-defined calendar, actions and funding, capable of strengthening the visibility and quality of the tourism sector in the European Union.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. The lack of a peace process underway is calling into question basic rights and has led to the adoption of unilateral measures on both sides that have not been...

It has not contributed in any way to the easing of tensions in the region, and much less to the effective search for a life for the two peoples who have the right to live harmoniously in peace, security and with dignity.

It is time for the international community to say enough. It is time for Europe and the Arab League to push for a lasting solution, with common sense, presenting viable solutions, without delay and with deadlines.
It is obvious that the United States and Russia are no longer part of the solution.
Let's start with Jerusalem. Why not recover the initial idea of a corpus separatum administered by the UN and that functions, obviously, as the capital of the two states?
Borders. Let's start with the ones from 1967.
Land parcels should be exchanged whenever possible and coherent.

Israel's defense is taken care of, an obviously unavoidable issue for the Jewish people. For example, through the placement of blue helmets with Americans, Europeans and Islamic forces next to the Jordan.
Refugees. There are about 4.8 million of them and they have the right to their dignity, to a future linked to a land, preferably their own.
