But it is not exclusively an Israeli problem, nor a Palestinian one, it is also ours, of the neighboring Arab countries, of the Arab community in general, but also of Europe and the rest of the international community.
Colonatos must end its expansion and this is not negotiable.
The announcement made today is shameful and translates hypocrisy and bad faith into an announcement of availability for immediate negotiations.
Above all, we want negotiations in good faith, with a deadline for their conclusion, from which the international community, to maintain its credibility, will have to have another attitude.

Thank you, Madam President, Madam Commissioner. Since the shameful situation in the refugee camps in Tunisia has been mentioned, we all share, and I share a lot, what has been said by my colleagues who have just spoken.
I am not referring to that in particular, I am referring to another situation that is more omitted, which is that of the citizens who were received in the homes of families in Tunisia.

And this is one of the situations that should make us even more ashamed, because, let's look at Tunisia in a crisis situation, it knew how to be supportive. Europe does not know how to be supportive and is not in a process of transition to democracy, and it did not know how to be supportive, it did not know how to receive.
I think it is, in fact, shameful that we can count in the hundreds the number of refugees that were received in Europe.
Many of these people, contrary to what was said, no, cannot return to their homes.
And there were children who were enrolled in public schools, which has implications for infrastructure, it has implications for what is the reception in these countries.
And that is why, Madam Commissioner, I am very sensitive to the appeal you are making, and I am not saying this ironically, I am saying it seriously. But please, and the Commission?
And in Europe?
What can it do?
How does Europe live so well with this double standard?
We are so quick to repatriate and so slow to help, Madam Commissioner.
It can’t go on like this.

Mr. President, I would like to congratulate you on this supplement of hope that you have given to all European deputies and, in particular, to the citizens of the European Union that we represent here.

And having said this, I would like to say that we now expect from the Commission a very, very determined action together with the Council so that this sovereign debt crisis can be resolved in the short term.
We know it is a marathon, but immediate signs are needed.

And therefore, without prejudice to us all starting to think about an amendment to the treaties that gives political translation to the whole project that we brought here today, without prejudice to this, something needs to be done now.

This set of measures and, eventually, an agreement, an agreement between the States, what I have called a kind of para-social agreement, that goes beyond the treaties and that can, from this moment on, put all these ideas into motion.
Congratulations on your courage and determination.
I believe we are on the right track and we leave here today with another determination.

Mr. President, the crisis that the European Union is going through has had serious consequences in all Member States and thousands of workers have been affected by the dismissals caused by globalization and by the crisis.
We cannot fail to affirm our solidarity with these workers who lost their jobs and to affirm that Europe must help Member States to maintain an employment rate and to combat unemployment.
The rapid reintegration of workers into the labor market is a priority objective.

An example of the usefulness of this fund is my country, Portugal, which resorted to it four times, although we were aware that access to this fund could be improved, especially in countries most affected by the crisis.

Thanks to the existence of this fund, the adjustment to globalization has made it possible to help thousands of workers through professional training measures, help in the creation of companies and incentives for recruitment.

This proposal is positive because it will allow Member States to request the intervention of this fund to support workers who have been laid off as a direct consequence of the economic and financial crisis.
We support the extension of the deadline and understand that the Member States most affected by the crisis should have greater and easier access to this Globalization and Crisis Support Fund.
Thank you, Madam President. I congratulate the Polish Presidency and also Mr. Commissioner Ali Ren, just to say that I consider that...
Today, in the sequence and in the development of what was done in the State of the Union speech, a very, very big step was taken to be able to solve the problems of the crisis in the Eurozone.
Because the Commission has assumed here its commitment to use its power of initiative and to use it together with the Council to solve this crisis.
I believe this is an extremely important step. And it is the only way we have at this moment to solve the crisis in the Eurozone.
There is no possibility of resolving in the short term only with an intergovernmental approach. And therefore it is necessary that the States, the governments of the States, give...
The Commission, the instruments and the mandate for it to lead this resolution process, for it to put into practice, execute and develop this roadmap that was presented here.
But I did not want to fail to say that this is not incompatible with the fact that we do, at the same time, develop our capacity to change treaties.

I am also convinced that in the medium term it is necessary to change the treaties, but we will also have to do it in the sense of strengthening, in the sense of giving more strength and greater position to the Commission.

It is through the strengthening of the community method, now in the short term and later with a change in the treaties in the long term, that we will achieve more integration and a solution for the 17 countries of the Eurozone and for the 27 countries of the European Union.

Thank you, Mr. President. Dr. Durão Barroso came here today to announce that one of the measures is that banks that do not have capital requirements must present plans to obtain them and, if they cannot present them, they must then suspend dividends and bonuses.
I could not fail to agree with this presentation made by the President.
This week we saw what happened with the bank Exia and a few months ago an administrator of this bank received a prize of 600 thousand euros for his so wonderful administration as we know.
But to be serious, Mr. President, the Commission has to go to the governments and present the complete package. And the complete package is what has the essential.
The essential thing is that taxpayers' money has a credit policy for growth as a counterpart.
The essential thing is that banks start paying taxes on their profits, which does not happen in many countries, namely in my country, Portugal.
In two years, or rather, in three years, this is the second time they ask us to save the banks with the money of the unemployed contributors.
The banks that also save the economy by helping to create jobs. Thank you very much.
Madam High Representative, there are times when I think that we need to take stock and this seems to be one of those times.
And it seems to me that because we are always in the rhythm of events and responding from one event to another, we lose a bit of what is the perspective of the whole.

It is true that each case is a case and each country we are talking about is a specific case, but allow me to say, Madam High Representative, it seems to me that it is difficult to scrutinize what the criteria are that the European Union has used to act in each of the cases.
I fear that we are often hostages of what are the interests of the countries of the European Union, of some of these countries of the European Union, and not of all.
And that is why we use the expression "two weights and two measures" so many times in this House and we continue to use it.

Sometimes it is yes to sanctions, sometimes it is no to sanctions. Sometimes the interference goes as far as the bomb, as was the case in Libya. Other times it is total silence, as was the case with the invasion of Bahrain by the forces of

Saudi Arabia, and Madam Baroness, let me tell you, I have studied all the dossiers carefully, I have not yet seen a single statement from the European institutions condemning the invasion of Bahrain by the Saudi military forces.
Death sentences, endless violence, doctors and nurses sentenced to up to 30 years in prison by a military court for supposedly being against the regime and not helping the wounded who needed them.
Regarding the dictatorial monarchy of Bahrain and regarding the dictatorial regime of Yemen, the Saleh regime, we have had much more silence than action.

I am not in favor of interference, I never was. But I fear that we are putting ourselves in an uncomfortable position, a position seen from the outside, Mrs. Baroness, which is, instead of helping us develop, to the aspirations of the
Instead of helping the Arab Spring, what we do is prevent it from spreading, either by excess or by default, and I don't think we should be burdened with this sin.
I hope that the awarding of the Nobel Prize to an activist like Aung San Suu Kyi can serve as a signal that our side is on the side of the peoples that are in revolution. Thank you very much.
Thank you, Madam President. Mr. Commissioner, this is a good report by colleague Casa.
First of all, we must ask why review the VAT in the European Union.
First of all, there is a need to make it compatible with the single market.
The more VAT regimes and varieties, the less fluid the market will be.
A VAT reform favors e-commerce, focusing competition on the value and base price of goods and services and not on tax differences.
It fights fraud and ensures the necessary confidence, especially in cross-border transactions. It improves the economy of SMEs and reduces administrative burdens.
What other measures with adjuvants are already in progress in the single market that can be associated with the IVA?
Firstly, a simple, clear and transparent digital support mechanism, measure 7 of the single market.
Measure 5, on services, the need to review the legislation on standardization and the implementation of Directive 2006/123/EC.

The new measure that is intended to remove tax obstacles and to explicitly review the VAT system and VAT equalization in online commerce and face-to-face commerce that we all feel when we order books.
The pressures for the reform of the VAT have two fundamental reasons.
Firstly, the economic crisis.
More revenue is needed, including, probably, in some countries, the reduction of contributions on labor to promote economic development, passing this responsibility to VAT.

Secondly, the second major source of pressures is population aging, demographic aging and the trend of shifting from indirect taxes to direct taxes, which, due to the reduction of the population base of incidence.
It is necessary to rethink the balance between this direct and indirect taxation.
Finally, we must, in these reforms, reconcile subsidiarity with harmonization.
It is necessary to restrict the variation range of the normal VAT rate so that we can all understand each other better.
It is necessary to have greater transparency in the definition of the reduced VAT rate and its scope of application, a clear and widely disseminated list of the reduced rates.
It is necessary to study exemption thresholds for SMEs, knowing that each exemption brings with it a train of small or large frauds.
Finally, I would like to welcome the recent proposal by the Commission to create a European VAT.
Good morning, Madam President. I would like to thank colleague Rula for the excellent report she prepared.

The advantages of public procurement are certainly known, but the obstacles are also evident. Conflicts of interest between European legislation and the objectives of Member States harm competitiveness.
The dichotomy between quality and price and the complexity of laws and procedures are evident.
It is essential to look at the existing good practices, namely in Portugal, where electronic contracting has worked well and has facilitated public contracting.
An effective European public procurement represents a privileged means of controlling the public deficit and of more growth.
For this, it will need a stable and predictable legal framework, less bureaucratic procedures to attract SMEs and defend social and environmental values.

That is why I express satisfaction with the intentions that Commissioner Barnier presents to us here for the revision of public procurement, as one of the 12 priorities of the Single Market Act, still this year. Thank you.
To congratulate colleague Rula and all those who collaborated with her.
Important in the field of public contracts is the issue of electronic public procurement.
Unfortunately, the objectives proposed by the European Union, 50% of the adjudications by electronic procedure in 2010, failed, finding themselves in the low average values of 5%.
Only a few countries, such as mine, Portugal, have been successful in this area.

The advantages of electronic public procurement are more than evident and have been mentioned here. It allows the replacement of the expensive access processes for a simple consultation of the electronic platform, that is, it reduces many costs for companies, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises.

Small and medium-sized companies, the disclosure on the internet and the ease of receiving the procedural documents increase the number of suppliers, increasing competition and allowing for better purchasing, making the process of awarding public contracts

More easy and flexible, it simplifies access to public contracts of the European Union, especially for small and medium-sized companies, thus facilitating their participation in the public contracts market, these important engines of the economy.

In this sense, we applaud and encourage the European Commission for strengthening the mechanisms in order to transform electronic public procurement into an increasingly widespread reality. Thank you very much.

We are living decisive hours for the destiny of Europe. And if the situation quickly went from being a problem of the Greeks or the Portuguese to a problem of great European dimension, the truth is that the insufficiency of the solutions pointed out and their delay have not produced any effectiveness in the rapid degradation of the situation.
The search for solutions aimed at the States, to the detriment of truly European solutions, allowed the markets to continue speculating on sovereign debts and imposed deadlines and rhythms
absolutely impossible goals that some states are trying to achieve with measures of a brutality previously unimaginable, applied to people, companies and the public sector.

It is absolutely urgent to find a common solution for the risk of European sovereign debts, which would relieve the pressure from markets and speculation and provide time for the essential adjustment to be made.
Without it, what we will have in the end are countries that will continue without means to pay their creditors, destroyed economies and a lot, a lot of suffering.

To the colleagues rapporteurs of the shadow, with whom I had a fruitful collaboration, and I also thank the rapporteurs of the partners of the four involved committees. These partners are a valuable contribution to this report.
We received 400 amendments and drafted 47 commitments that were all approved.
This demonstrates the importance and the interest aroused by this theme of new skills and jobs.
It is, after all, about preparing the human resources of Europe, anticipating the needs of the labor market in the next decade.
The key strategy for drafting the report was to rephrase common ideas in order to avoid repetitions and ensure the report's coherence.
I think that this objective was achieved.

We all know that the crisis that currently affects us has revealed the fragilities of the European economic and social model, as well as it has annulled several of the progresses achieved in the past.
Since the first effects of the crisis began to be felt in the labor markets in 2008, Europe has already lost more than 5 million jobs.
Today, there are almost 23 million unemployed people.
Youth unemployment is even more frightening. The youth unemployment rate is close to 21% and is more than double the general unemployment rate.
On the other hand, in all member states, unemployment rates vary with qualification levels.
This means that people with higher qualifications find it easier to get a job.
We also know that in the near future, the needs in terms of skills, competencies and qualifications will increase in all types of professions and levels.
In this context, Europe faces four challenges. First, job creation. Second, the need to develop and remain competitive.
Then, the sustainability of social security systems and, finally, the difficulty in finding people with the appropriate skills to fill job offers.

This report thus has a dual objective. First, to highlight the need to act quickly in order to eliminate the skills gaps in Europe. Second, to better anticipate the needs of the labor market in terms of skills.

For this, several measures stand out. First, to ensure the availability of qualified labor, it is necessary to improve basic skills, as well as skills in science, innovation, information and communication technologies, as well as foreign languages.
As I have already mentioned, the need for skills must be identified early, with a minimum horizon of 10 years.
Today, we know the potential of a new sustainable economy, the green economy, and the need to invest in ecological qualifications.
Then, participation in lifelong learning and professional requalification should be increased, as well as reducing school dropout.
Another important matter is the mutual recognition of diplomas and professional qualifications and the urgency of advancing with this recognition.
Fourthly, we draw attention to the connection that must exist between educational institutions and the needs of the job market.
Internships should be of quality and supervised by tutors so that they can lead to a job and end any possible abuse of the situation of interns.
The role of social partners and social dialogue is also given particular emphasis.
The report also proposes measures to promote job search and creation.
We have a future ahead of us and we need to create jobs.
Small and medium-sized companies play a decisive role here for this objective.

It is also necessary to strengthen the single market to facilitate the free movement of workers and, therefore, the need to coordinate social security systems so that workers can have their acquired rights guaranteed, especially the portability of pensions.

Lastly, the issue of labor market flexibility. To improve the functioning of the labor market, the rules of flexibility and security must be adapted to the socio-economic contexts of each Member State. Thank you very much.
Thank you, Madam President. I would like to start by thanking all the colleagues who participated in this lively debate.
All colleagues had very useful interventions and contributed to a very constructive discussion on an ambitious agenda at a time when we are experiencing a serious crisis.

In fact, this discussion is taking place exactly on the eve of a European Council that will show whether there is or not political will to overcome the difficulties we are experiencing and whether there is will to
political will for a deepening of our economic coordination and if there is really a harmonized and unitary will to be able to carry out the ambition that is in this agenda, that is, to have

New jobs in the next decade, new jobs that will give hope to young people who are currently unemployed and to those who are being trained in the job market, hope in an inclusive job market that will meet their expectations.

ambition of dignification through work and that they also have the opportunity to be in a permanent dynamism to accompany the challenges of a globalized economy and with a dynamic that has no parallel in the last generations.
Therefore, our ambition is really to create jobs, to have economic growth, to not only respond to those who are unemployed as a result of the crisis, but also to those who will enter the job market.

response to the great challenges that are there with the green economy, with the services in the health area, with the services in the transport and housing area, which require from all of us a different vision, an intelligent vision and an inclusive vision of the labor market.
Thank you very much to all.

Marisa Matias. Thank you, Madam President. What was said to us today here in the Council's statement is that, for technical reasons, democracy should be sacrificed in the matter of the European semester. But what we are talking about is a political issue. And the question I ask is whether there can be political coordination without democracy.
Where is the European Parliament's curtain, after all?
Where is the scrutiny of the national parliaments over their major budgetary options?

But if the question were technical, as it was said here, then we are talking about a variable technique. Because we know how the Council substantially eased the conditions of the four countries that are on the waiting list, France, Italy, Hungary, Spain. It did not do the same in relation to the countries that are under rescue.
So, what is this model of intergovernmentality that allows Germany to give opinions about Portugal, but does not allow Portugal to give opinions about Germany?
And Mr. Commissioner, please, I just ask you to pay attention to this. No democratic legitimacy problem is solved by asking the deputies to consult the information on the internet.
This is a problem of false exclusion, not a problem of democratic exclusion, which is what we are talking about here. Thank you very much.

Thank you, Madam President, Mr. Commissioner, colleagues. First of all, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur from Ardennes for the quality and timeliness of this report, and also Mr. Commissioner Andor for the initiatives announced.
Poverty is really a very serious problem that requires effective and rapid action to stop the increase of the phenomenon that at the moment affects more than 80 million Europeans.
The serious crisis we are already going through has worsened this situation and made the times we live in dramatic, as Commissioner Andor said.
The number of unemployed people keeps increasing and we all know that unemployment is a passport to poverty and social exclusion.
This scenario requires resources, will and a lot of effort from the European Commission and the Member States.
If this does not happen, the goal of removing 20 million European citizens from poverty during this decade will not be achieved.
For this reason, I strongly support the initiative of the Platform against Poverty, which is a very important instrument to ensure social justice.
But no one doubts that the best antidotes to poverty and social exclusion are job creation and the promotion of economic growth.
Mr. President, access to the internet should today be considered as a new fundamental right of citizens and not merely as a commercial object, because from this right...
They depend on essential things such as freedom of expression, access to and sharing of information, access to and sharing of culture and knowledge, as well as democratic and media pluralism.

And that is why this access cannot be subject to speculative tariffs or to contracts that lock in free choice and the possibility of easily changing suppliers, particularly in the world of mobile telecommunications, as we also know.
Active citizenship requires, therefore, that complete and transparent information be provided.
The blocking of internet use is not exclusive to political regimes that are afraid of their people.
It can also happen as a result of economic options, by offering privileges to police clients, and it is a less equal treatment to clients who are not so profitable.
This is why I support the Parliament in clearly siding with the neutrality of the Internet and the defense of its totally open character.
Let's be honest.
We have been taking medication for three years to get out of the crisis and the situation worsens day by day.
Instead of a cure, we created two fatal vicious circles.
The first one between banks and states.
In Europe, it is easier to discuss the failure of a State than that of a large bank, but it is still expected that banks will finance States and that States will save their banks.
This spiral must be broken.
The Commission must move forward with European legislation that protects taxpayers from bank crises.
But it is also vital to protect the States' debt from the attacks of speculators.

And for that, it is urgent and already late to prepare the coordinated emissions of sovereign debt, call them Eurobonds or Stability Bonds, and guarantee them through robust instruments of a community nature and not intergovernmental.
In short, we also have to review the involvement of the European Central Bank.
But a second vicious circle results from the argument that some states are rich because they are virtuous, while others are poor because they sinned.
This narrative is politically explosive and technically wrong.

She ignores the essential fact that a market and a single currency, built by political choice and among unequals, necessarily aggravates the competitiveness imbalances between the center and the periphery.
And this is what must be tackled in economic governance.
No, Mr. Rompoy, through sanctions that promote the crushing of wages and income, with the control of one country over another.
First, through the involvement, Mr. Commissioner, of both countries with surpluses and countries with deficits, in order to converge productivity through investment, education and science.
The sanctions have only generated unemployment, disillusionment and a wave from which we cannot escape.

Thank you very much, Madam President. Madam Commissioner, the Integrated Maritime Policy advocates a coordinated approach to the management and governance of oceans, seas and coasts, in a global and coherent perspective of all European policies related to the sea.

Having a global perspective and an integrated approach implies the interaction of European policies related to the sea and requires better governance through greater involvement in the European decision-making process.
The success and relevance of this policy has been demonstrated over the last few years through the various initiatives funded in the form of preparatory actions and pilot projects.
The integrated maritime policy should, for this very reason, continue to benefit from adequate funding during the next years of the current financial programming period.

In this sense, it defends adequate funding until 2013, not only to consolidate previous projects, but also to support the definition of a stable framework in relation to the objectives of this program.

The issues of politics, governance, sustainability and maritime surveillance are, for obvious reasons, topics that particularly interest some regions of the European Union, such as the outermost regions.

The overseas regions, with the exception of French Guiana, being islands and of small size, depend on a limited number of economic activities, in which activities related to the sea and fishing assume special importance.
Moreover, the ultra-peripheral regions contribute to the European Union having the largest exclusive economic zone in the world.

The outermost regions represent more than half of the European Union's exclusive economic zone, about 15 out of 25 million square kilometers, being, together with the coastal regions, fundamental for the economic growth of the European Union and its Member States.
A program such as the Integrated Maritime Policy should benefit these regions, prioritizing the transnational coordination of maritime policies and relevant international cooperation.
It is therefore necessary to ensure continuous and sufficient funding, not only for the next two years, but also and above all for the next financial framework from 2014 onwards.
Not to take advantage of the opportunity when talking about integrated maritime policy to highlight the enormous potential that the Atlantic and insular dimension hold for the European Union.

The Atlantic, being the western maritime border of Europe, also establishes its connection to North and South America and to Africa, conferring a strategic dimension to Europe that is indispensable in the architecture of a maritime policy elaborated with an eye to the future.

And it is thinking about the future that the integrated maritime policy, besides promoting the articulation of maritime activities, should place in the first line of its priorities the potential of the Atlantic in its three-dimensional dimension based on science and technology.

The investigation of the Mid-Atlantic Ridge, the deep sea and the seabed constitutes a new frontier whose potential exists in biotechnology and mineral resources and is of incalculable value to the knowledge economy.
The Union should take advantage of the privileged position of the Azores and the excellence of its Oceanographic Department to install a deep-sea observatory there. Thank you.
Enough of this path.
When the diagnosis is wrong, the remedies do not work.
And in the case of the Eurozone, the excessive remedies have taken it to the brink of death.
The successive miracle solutions that were proposed were also equally discredited by the markets.
The Financial Stabilization Fund, the successive distributions of reinforcement of the Stability and Growth Pact, the receipts of the Troika in the countries under program.
The blind discipline without growth generated a recessionary wave among fully interconnected economies, which were thus contaminated with bankruptcies and unemployment.
And in the hands of the markets, that is, of the rating agencies and speculators, governments are falling one after the other and solvent countries are becoming insolvent.

Changing the treaties now is another step in this disastrous path, with an aggravating factor. We risk destroying what remains of national sovereignty, putting the countries in the hands of the European Court of Justice.
No, it is not necessary to change the treaties.
In this emergency we are in, it is necessary to make two decisions.
First of all, it is necessary to establish a true agenda for sustained growth and cohesion.
Where is the 2020 Agenda?
Where is the launch pad?
Where are the so-called project bonds for Europe's structural investments?
And secondly, it is necessary to protect the sovereign debt.
Of course, the eurobonds are necessary, but in this emergency we are in, it is urgent that the European Central Bank, directly or indirectly, defends the sovereign debt against speculators.
Not in a shameful way, but with a definitive, decided position, as befits any central bank that defends its currency and the economy that supports it.
For this, it is not necessary to change the treaties. What is needed is political will and European conviction.
We will change the treaty when we have drawn all the lessons from the present crisis. And there are many lessons to be drawn. But this is certainly not the time. Thank you very much.
Mr. President and Mr. Commissioner Dali, the first Single Market Forum, an idea that stems from the Greek report, took place in Krakow.
It was rich in content and fruitful in the debate carried out by the Polish Presidency with European, national, regional and local authorities and civil society.
We have a roadmap outlined in the Commission's communication of April 12 with the 12 levers.
It needs to be passed into law, just like the strategy of the other 38 priorities identified in the Single Market Act.
For a market to exist, trust is necessary.
Now, the trust of citizens and consumers cannot be seen as an acquired fact, it needs to be stimulated, fed.
The single market is not just a buying and selling operation. It involves horizontal policies, such as health, social protection and consumers, labor law, the environment and sustainable development.
The Single Market Forum should therefore become an emblematic event of the European Union, with an annual realization and with a diversified and increasingly participatory audience.

Thank you very much, Mr. President. I think we are at a time of balance sheets in terms of these crisis policies, austerity policies that have affected so many countries and also the so-called structural reforms.
And it is in this context that I think we cannot fail to see how they have generated so much social commotion.
And it has generated social unrest not only in the countries in greatest difficulty, in the southern countries, not only in the so-called PIGS, but also in other contexts in Europe.
Last week, Portugal had the biggest general strike ever, both in the public and private sectors. A strike that took to the streets.

But if we look at what happened today in the United Kingdom, we see that we are witnessing the biggest strike ever, especially if we take into account that people went out on the streets just like they did in Portugal.
And we are expecting a big demonstration in Brussels on Friday.

What this proves, Mr. President, and what the strikes and the people taking to the streets prove, is that the causes and the problems we have been facing are common, and that is why the reaction is also common.
The crisis of the European Union is affecting all member states, reaching incredible proportions.

We are witnessing chaos in the financial markets and the increasing inability to ensure the essential funding for the activity of our small and medium-sized companies, even those that are healthy, leading them to despair, bankruptcy and unemployment.
It is a spiral that feeds the recession and is destroying the economy and society.

No one denies the need for rigorous budgetary discipline, deep restructuring and more economic governance. But these are necessary conditions that, in the short term, are no longer sufficient to counter the ongoing degradation in the Union.

And if it is true that political decisions are needed, they must stimulate employment and growth, without which we will never be able to control sovereign debt. The central issue today is to guarantee the financing of our companies and our economies, without which the Union will collapse.
Therefore, more than ever, more than the revision of the treaties, we need today a strong and safe intervention of the European Central Bank.
Thank you very much, Madam President, Sir Commissioner. We are all here today united around a resolution with a set of very important requests in terms of intervention.
We are talking about World AIDS Day and this evaluation of the 2009 resolution and communication is fundamental.
It is precisely fundamental because of things that have already been mentioned.
We repeat ourselves because, unfortunately, there is still room for repetition, which means that there is still much to be done.
There are many new cases diagnosed every year in Europe and in the European Economic Area. A 2010 report speaks of more than 25,000 new cases.
If we consider the neighboring countries, we are talking about more than 100,000 new cases.
And if we think that there are things that cannot get worse, they can always get worse.

And one of the issues that I want to make very clear here has to do with the disinvestment that has been made in the health sector as a result of the economic and financial crisis that we are currently experiencing.
And this disinvestment has seriously affected areas that are fundamental to the fight against HIV/AIDS.
It is for this reason, Mr. Commissioner, that I believe that the Commission has a fundamental role in asking Member States to fulfill their obligations in these areas.

A second issue is also related to the increase in discrimination, also evidenced by the economic and social crisis. Discrimination against workers who have lost their jobs because they are carriers of this virus.
And that is why prevention, treatment and care should be equal for everyone, regardless of gender, age, regardless of the region where they live.
I hope we can implement these measures with the support of the Commissioner. Thank you very much.
Welcome to this Parliament, Mr. Draghi.
We are living in special and dramatic circumstances, and they require determined and urgent measures.

The spiral between the States' debt and the banks' debt must be broken, but at this moment the priority is to defend the States, to ensure that the Eurozone countries and the Euro itself are not destroyed by the rating agencies and the speculators.
In the report that we will approve, Tremosa and Bacels, we have proposals to rethink the architecture of the Eurozone, to create Eurobonds and a European Treasury. But all this takes time.
At this moment, we are talking about an emergency. And in this context, the only solution is in the hands of the European Central Bank.
Technically, the European Central Bank knows what needs to be done.
Today, he should not be inhibited in his intervention and action by limited interpretations of his mandate.
Its mandate is to safeguard the euro, not to deal with inflation.
At a time like this, there is no doubt. Saving the euro and doing what is necessary is what this Parliament and the citizens expect from the European Central Bank.
Good luck and courage, Mr. Draghi.
The European Neighborhood Policy already contained, in a very explicit way, the positions that the European Parliament has been adopting.

And it was with great satisfaction that we saw included in the subsequent communications of the Commission and the Council a large part of the principles and proposals that we have been defending in this House.

I would like to thank the excellent and permanent collaboration and coordination that we have maintained throughout this time with Vice-President Cathy Ashton and with Commissioner Stefan Fule and their cabinets.
First of all, by the upgrade achieved in our relationship with the neighboring peoples.

By prioritizing relations with the population in general and with civil society organizations in particular, we will be giving greater objectivity and greater effectiveness to our neighborhood policy, which is intended to be exclusively based on the universal values that we defend and share.
However, I would like to stress that the European Union does not intend to impose a model or a pre-defined formula for political reforms in third countries.
But when it comes to our taxpayers' money, we should give more to those who are doing more to get closer to the values we believe in.
Does this principle mean that the faster a country progresses in its internal reforms, the more support it will receive from the European Union?
The principle of more for more is therefore correct, fair and consistent.
Which means, obviously, that we also anticipate the possibility of having cases or countries where we will have less for less.
The neighborhood policy is now based on the defense of the pursuit of common values and the commitment to democracy, human rights, the rule of law and good governance.
But this search implies greater responsibility.
Our partners are called to have more responsibility in the process. That is why we defend the principles of greater differentiation, greater conditionality and the so-called more for more.

By adopting a posture of approximation to our partners, from the bottom up, and policies made to measure, what we call the bottom-up approach and tailor-made policies, we make development and institutional capacity more effective.

The institutional building that we want to defend so much and that is at the basis of the rule of law and of the democratic process that we want to see implemented as soon as possible in the societies, in the economies and in the communities of our neighbors.

The idea is to give a voice to citizens, as well as to all civil society movements that identify with our values, supporting organized movements that strive to achieve positive and democratic changes in their countries.
countries, improving the rights of women and children, building and deepening the principles of freedom, be it of expression, of association, of religious belief, of the press, of choice, etc.
etc. With fair elections, combating corruption, a state of law, greater social justice, respect for minorities, environmental protection and efficiency in the use of resources.
The serious economic and social problems faced by our neighbors must also be the subject of immediate action.
It is clear that without our concrete help, the democratic processes in progress may fail.
These are the ideas that we have always defended for the future European Neighborhood Policy.
These are the proposals that make up the report that we bring to your vote.
Now is the time to act.
On our part, we will continue to be attentive and to exercise the new powers of monitoring and oversight now granted to the European Parliament.

Lastly, I would like to thank my colleague, co-rapporteur and friend Marek Siwiec, to whom I leave a word of special recognition for his notable work in the Eastern dimension of the Neighbourhood Policy.
Also to the shadow and opinion rapporteurs and to all of you for the immense suggestions proposed in the amendments that you presented and that I consider to have enriched our work.
And a final word to the Commission Secretariat and to the political advisors for the excellent support work that I benefited from.
The European Neighborhood Policy, including the ultra-peripheral regions as active borders of Europe in different parts of the world.
As external borders, the border regions transmit our values of democracy, peace, respect for human rights and fundamental rights to the third countries of these regions.
Regions such as the French overseas departments have an absolute need for greater integration into their geographical areas.

Far from the internal market of the Union, this integration is fundamental for its development and constitutes enormous potential for the deepening of the neighborhood policy with the countries of the third neighbors.

The neighborhood policy requires a new boost, a boost that also takes advantage of the privileged historical or cultural relations that the ultra-peripheral regions of the Azores, Madeira and the Canaries maintain with North America and South America.
A more active role in favor of the European Union can and should be played by these regions within the framework of a new European Neighborhood Policy.

Thank you, Mr. President. It is now September, one year since, after a deep debate in which I also took part as the person responsible for this matter in the Socialist Group, promoting meetings and debates with European, national and regional organizations linked to the

To retailers, to industrialists and to farmers, the Parliament approved the Bouvet report, containing an exhaustive set of recommendations to the European Commission, with the objective of a fair income for farmers and a better functioning of the food supply chain.

Since 2008, in fact, communications, reports, recommendations have been produced in the Commission and in the Parliament, and forums and high-level groups have been set up to solve this serious problem, without, beyond a greater awareness, anything having changed in practice.

We return to the subject and it is necessary to say it without hesitation. A significant part of the problems that farmers face derive from highly penalizing behaviors imposed, above all, by operators of modern distribution.
The problems are more than identified.
What has been lacking in the Commission and the Member States is an effective political will to implement the solutions.
Until then, we will continue to suffer the loss of farmers and consumers.
He is saying that this treaty is useless.
Unfortunately, it is especially dangerous.
First, because it reinforces with more punishments and strict rules a recipe that does not work.
The recessionary spiral has been launched.
Who can trust a doctor who does not distinguish weight loss from anorexia?
A doctor who, the more the patient weakens, the more he insists on the remedy, while openly discussing the probability of his death.
How many more countries have to go into recession for the Commission and the Council to realize that the diagnosis is wrong?
But it is also dangerous, because we here represent the citizens of Europe.
23 million and 700 thousand are unemployed.
Almost 6 million young people have no hope of finding a job.
Will the Council and the Commission not understand that ignoring this fact, not giving an adequate response, reveals an autism and an insensitivity that are politically explosive?
Let’s be clear.
The Great Recession is not a fatality, it is an ideological obsession.
There is an alternative agenda. It must, however, be not of words but of action.
Where are the project bonds to finance European investment?
Where is the reinforcement of the European budget with the tax on speculative financial products?
Where is the barrier that should protect countries from the ruinous interest rates that the markets impose on them, leading them to ruin?
Citizens demand options and not words, but competent options. Thank you very much.
Thank you very much, Madam President. The Commission and the governments now promise to reprogram the structural funds to support SMEs and create jobs.

However, it is good to remember that, at the end of last year, the Commission also decided on the suspension of the allocation of structural funds to countries that do not comply or did not comply with the objectives in terms of deficit or debt.
It is not necessary to be a genius to realize that either the promise will be fulfilled or the punishment will come, but not both at the same time.
And that is why, Mr. Commissioner, I would like to ask you a very direct question. Does the decision to suspend the allocation of structural funds still stand? Was it frozen or annulled?
In other words, will Greece, Portugal, Ireland and other countries be able to access funds they are entitled to if they do not meet the objectives that are being imposed by the Commission and by you?
Answer, Mr. Commissioner, please. It is that in Portugal we are very tired of promises, you know?
Thank you, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner. The proposal made by President Barroso to redirect the available structural funds to support our SMEs
Stimulating employment, especially youth employment, could not be more welcome, especially for economies that are being subjected to strong austerity measures, such as the Portuguese economy.

With the external intervention agreement and the great difficulties in financing the economy, and in particular our small and medium-sized enterprises, through the banking system, this proposal assumes special importance for regions such as the Azores, which have a high absorption and good use of funds, but are inserted in a recessionary context.

Here, national governments can find a real opportunity to stimulate their economy through small and medium-sized enterprises and the indispensable contribution of our best-prepared generation of young people, which is the best response to growth and employment with these funds.
we could obtain.
What we need to know, Mr. Commissioner, is how, in practice, we will access these funds and how our regions will participate in their reprogramming.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, the package of ethics presented here as an instrument of organization of the sector contains important positive elements, such as the reinforcement of the role of the producers' organizations and of the interprofessional organizations and contractual aspects that in some States themselves can, with the voters, leave us...

However, it is still far from the instruments that the sector needs to prosper in the coming years, in the context of an agriculture that we want to have, in Europe, access to the fair distribution of value in the food chain, which does not become an agriculture of large intensive exploitations, concentrated in a few Member States.

If improving the self-regulation condition in the relationship between actors in the sector is desirable, to think that this alone is enough is to make a serious mistake that can drive thousands of milk producers, dozens of regions and even some countries away from dairy activity.
The debate on the regulation of the dairy sector, in the perspective of a sustainable sector, economically, socially, environmentally and territorially, continues, thus, still to be done.
And we cannot abandon the milk quota system without having guaranteed real instruments of supply control.
Thank you very much, Mr. President, Madam Commissioner. Since May 2010 until today, we have seen how a problem that seemed manageable has worsened in an uncontrolled way.
It is true that the fight against the crisis opened by the financial markets worsened the indebtedness of the countries of the Eurozone and that the most fragile ones became particularly vulnerable.

However, is it possible that countries sharing the same currency are left to the mercy of attacks by financial operators and those who profit by betting on the likelihood of eurozone countries going bankrupt?
The terrible consequences of the Council's inability to respond generated problems that are undeniable today.
The speculative interest rates practiced on individual countries made any exit strategy from the crisis unviable.
The consequent worsening of the country's economic problem justifies a new increase in interest rates, until the total credit cut kills the country's economy and the contagion does the rest.
This Parliament has long been calling for a form of common management of sovereign debt, subject to demanding but clear rules.
We welcome the fact that the Commission has finally produced a Green Paper on the subject, what was called the

Today it is clear that without some kind of obligations of this type, properly articulated with the European stabilization mechanism, the so-called protection barriers, the so-called firewalls for sovereign debt do not exist. And while they do not exist, the euro is in danger and Europe is too.

In the resolution that this Parliament approved by majority regarding the new treaty, it became absolutely clear that it is not admissible to continue to impose more rules of fiscal stability, budgetary discipline and sanctions on the Eurozone countries without taking concrete and urgent steps in the solidary management of sovereign debt.
The two processes will have to evolve in parallel.
This is what we expect from the Commission and it is already late.

I would like to think that this European House of Democracy will unanimously reject the behavior of President Assad and the Syrian authorities in the massacre of their own people, which we witness daily, powerless.
It is important that Europe can speak with one voice about the meaning of the values of respect for human life, in the face of an indiscriminate and nobly orchestrated massacre.
The entire international community must maintain pressure on the Syrian regime through the application of new restrictive measures.
The murders must stop. And this is not negotiable.
Insist on dialogue, without a doubt.

A democratic Syria needs a transition period and guarantees for all its minorities. However, the application of more restrictive measures to the Syrian regime is not possible if all countries do not row in the same direction. And this has not happened, clearly and unfortunately.
Besides thousands of deaths, the two resolutions were shamefully rejected by the United Nations Security Council.
We continue to disapprove of the position of China and Russia, increasingly isolated in relation to their incredible support for the Syrian regime.
Everything else remains the same. A rotten, desperate and cornered regime continues to govern a country and we, the international community, continue to be powerless to stop the genocide of a people.
We are already late in strengthening the action of the European Union and the international community.
We must give more concrete support to the Arab League in its interventions and in its intentions to send a peacekeeping force to Syria.
We must support without reservations the work of the Red Cross in its efforts to minimize the suffering of the populations.
The International Criminal Court must immediately initiate proceedings to punish those responsible for the crimes against humanity that are being committed.

and as a form of pressure on the countries that have maintained support for Assad, also prohibit the trade exchanges of the European Union with all Russian or Chinese companies that have commercial relations.
And start yesterday.
Thank you, Mr. President. Welcome, Madam Commissioner, to discuss this topic of such importance.
In fact, we are talking about central issues related to data protection and, above all, in a context in which there may be conflict between two different jurisdictions.

And data protection is, in fact, one of the sensitive areas and has generated so much controversy and, in my opinion, should continue to generate it. Because we are talking about what can be the clash between the
The rights and guarantees, the safeguard of European citizens, which are protected by European legislation and then are surpassed when legislation from other countries overrides European legislation.
It is sensitive for several reasons.
It is sensitive because there is a break and a doubt in what is a contract that for all intents and purposes exists between European citizens and European institutions.
When they give their personal data, they do so understanding that these will be protected by the entities and European institutions and that they will not be distributed for other purposes.

And therefore there is a breach of trust here, and this is a difficult data to manage, and on the other hand it is also a serious and precarious situation, because the European Union ends up transferring personal data to third countries, thus breaking the trust that is generated.

between European citizens and European institutions. And therefore, if citizens accept that European institutions can be guardians of their personal data in so many different areas, from health issues to other issues such as those mentioned of companies,

that require the data, and I am specifically talking about the case of the United States, which systematically requires data from the European Union, what we are doing, when the citizens leave the assumption that they are giving, and as I said, for the European Union to be the guardian of their data, what is done is a breach of trust.

Therefore, I also want to tell you, Madam Commissioner, that these issues have been problematic many times for different reasons, but I will always be on the side of the demonstrations of citizens and citizens.

They want to safeguard the protection of their personal data. And if there are demonstrations that understand that they should be held because European institutions do not comply, I think we should be on the side of the citizens and not on the opposite side.

It is almost like a kind of betrayal that is being committed. And that is why we are asking you this question, these issues that we are placing before you, Madam Commissioner, so that you can clarify once and for all, because no community is built on the basis or foundation of destruction or...

The decrease in the bonds of trust that exist between their citizens and their institutions. And in this sense, Madam Commissioner, please answer us, to what extent can we guarantee that European legislation overrides the legislation of third countries?
Because if it is true that European legislation overrides the legislation of the 27 Member States of the European Union, then the citizens abdicate.

of this space of sovereignty at many times, for what reason could we accept that other countries, such as the United States, would then impose European legislation that would impose national legislation?
It is necessary that this be clarified because it is, in fact, very sensitive, it is serious and it is an issue that we must take into consideration.

And lastly, Madam Commissioner, I would like to ask you, please, to tell us what the Commission is doing so that this does not happen, so that it is not recurrent and so that the personal data of all citizens and

that the companies and various sectors that are referenced in these issues are, in fact, data that people can trust, that they are sheltered from what we protect. And with this I mean that I do not even share that all the information that is stored should be stored, but that is another debate.

Regarding this, as it is a serious matter and as it is a matter that is precarious in terms of what are the rights of citizens, I would like you to give us these clarifications so that we can all be more at ease. Thank you very much.
Mr. President, I would like to say that we expect a major economic decision from the next Council for the countries that are under aid, very much linked to the issue of structural funds.
It is necessary to make the structural funds more flexible.
There are many that are about to be used, most of them were used only for large infrastructures.
They must be aimed at competitiveness, at small and medium-sized companies, at relaunching the economy.
The only investment that countries like Greece, Portugal, Ireland and others can have is the one that results at this moment from these structural funds.
It also left a political note for all the politicians of the Union, those who are in good faith in the European process.
When talking about these systems, it is necessary to respect, to be very careful with respect for national identities and for member states. And not all...
Politicians, sometimes many of them with good intentions, but not all, have been up to the challenge of strictly respecting the national identity of each Member State.
Thank you, Mr. President, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner. I agree with the rapporteurs, but I would like to say that enough of pious speeches about employment and growth.

Today, with the first results on macroeconomic imbalances in Europe, the veil is beginning to lift on why some countries in the European Union, and particularly in the Eurozone, are thriving while others are failing.
Europe is losing competitiveness in external markets and this agenda must be reviewed because this is where much of the insufficient internal growth lies. But, focused on the internal market,
Four countries, including Germany, accumulate surpluses year after year, while 20 other countries, I repeat, 20, accumulate deficits year after year.
As deficits accumulate, the external debt of these countries increases unsustainably.
Of course, this process has to be controlled.
Of course, discipline is needed.
But it is important to ask today, is the solution to crush the most vulnerable with restrictive policies the only possible solution?
Will the tax competition of some winners within the internal market continue to be tolerated?

Will the largest European economy be able to continue to develop common policies that favor it and internal economic policies that, while being right for its economy, capture most of the gains from the internal market in its favor?
Can the Commission and the Council continue to impose regressive policies that tighten the economy of the most vulnerable, discussing...
openly the possibility of default of sovereign states of the Eurozone, when they know that the firewalls never left the drawer of intentions?
Do the Commission and the Council have full awareness of the political and economic explosive risk that this speech brings to Europe?
Yes, it is necessary to review the revenues in a radical way.
But for that, there needs to be political will.
While this will does not exist, out of respect for the citizens, let us stop saying that we defend growth and employment, because it is not true.
And the citizens cannot continue to be deceived.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. I begin by greeting the reporters.
Saying that we are living the most serious financial, economic and social crisis since the creation of our modern international financial model is already a commonplace.
Emphasizing that unemployment rates in the European Union have reached historic records is never too much to demand that the fight against unemployment be the priority of priorities.
Youth unemployment is dramatic. In my country, Portugal, more than one in every three young people are looking for a job and have no prospects of finding one.
Our citizens are so incredulous.
It is urgent to return their confidence.
After years of imprudent management of public finances, it is time to adopt budget reconciliation reforms and to put the accounts in order.
But we should not be fooled, austerity without economic growth is only a partial solution.
The creation of more jobs and better jobs is the great European goal.

Measures to ensure that young people do not remain for more than four months without receiving a job or training offer, as well as to reduce the risk of poverty and social exclusion, must be a reality.
A year ago, we witnessed the tragic combination of an earthquake, a tsunami and a nuclear industrial accident, all in sequence.
Today we pay a heartfelt tribute to the many thousands of victims of Fukushima.
Honoring the victims is telling them that we learned the lesson. We must learn to deal with natural disasters. With nuclear disasters, we have the obligation to avoid them.
But unfortunately, this does not seem to be the truth.
A year after Fukushima, new nuclear power plants are still being built.
A year after Fukushima, new nuclear power plants are still being planned.
Japan unfortunately has the memory of tragedies that last, Hiroshima, Nagasaki, and we Europeans also have the memory of a tragedy that lasts, Chernobyl.
Fukushima forces us, because of all this, to reopen a debate that should never have been closed, the debate on nuclear energy.
A year ago, nuclear energy was unquestionable for the Japanese. Today, two thirds of the Japanese do not want it.
They know it costs lives, they know that this cost is priceless. On the contrary, it is a cost that increases from generation to generation.
The stubborn policy in favor of nuclear energy is the policy of arrogance.
Here in Europe, we also have a majority of public opinion against nuclear power, and yet nothing seems to change.
There are currently 320,000 refugees in Japan. Of these, 100,000 will never be able to return home.
What was once familiar is now dangerous. What was once comfort is now ruin.
It is the ruin of a building or a house with radioactive vegetation. It is the ruin of the soil or contaminated water.

And Fukushima cannot be visited as other ruins are visited, for example, a Mayan ruin or a Roman ruin. However, like these, Fukushima also portrays a civilization. And the ruin of Fukushima portrays our civilization.
The one that chose to include a deadly technology in its development model.
An earthquake and a tsunami have no culprits, but a nuclear disaster has those responsible.
In Japan, just like in Europe, many citizens decided to create anti-nuclear movements.
They know better than anyone that safe nuclear energy is something that does not exist. They know better than anyone that there are no stress tests that
They can simulate what happened in Fukushima. And that is why we know that energy policies are national, but in the sky...
As Ms. Matias has already mentioned, diabetes affects more than 30 million people in Europe.
These are, in fact, the numbers of an epidemic.

And that is why I understand that it is also justified to make a specific resolution regarding diabetes, especially since this is the first time that this Parliament has dedicated itself to this issue.

It is the result of collective work and it is work that does not annul the work done so far on chronic diseases, on the contrary, it reinforces it and reinforces this capacity that we have to intervene together.
We have about 325,000 annual deaths associated with diabetes, because we know that diabetes is the main cause of, for example, heart attacks, blindness, amputations, and failure of vital organs.
And, in the face of these data, we have two options, in my opinion.
The first is to say that it is not so serious, that we can live well with this and that each government deals with it.
The second is to say that the absence of a European strategy in this area is part of the problem.
I understand that we have a lot to do on this side.
We have a lot to do in early diagnosis, coordination, and investment in research.
And that is why this resolution has the value of a beginning and of joint work in this sense. Thank you very much.
Thank you, Mr. President. What I basically wanted to draw attention to was to congratulate the Council on its results.
Not because the measures are ideal, but because they are the possible measures.
There is no doubt that today we have come much further and we can be more optimistic than we were three months ago and six months ago.
Many states have been making a huge effort to stabilize and consolidate their public finances, and this effort has only been made in some states by the induction of the European Union.
It is essential for them to recover their credibility in international markets and it is essential for them to be able to grow in the long run.
With these guarantees that the States have given, among which the Portuguese State stands out, in the sense of making fiscal consolidation, budgetary consolidation, I am
I am convinced, also with the new treaty signed among the 25, that we will be in a position to seriously relaunch growth in the next steps of the European Council.
But it is only with this confidence that is being generated little by little that this growth must be made.
And that is why I say, solidarity from the richest to the poorest is important, but from the poorest to the richest is also important, providing these guarantees.
Mr. President, I would basically like to say that it is with great joy that we have seen steps being taken to integrate Serbia into the European Union.

This is very important because the experience of countries like Portugal, like Spain or like Greece, which were countries that lived under dictatorships and that had a set of very serious problems, is the experience that European integration was the way to consolidate democracy.
And that is why Serbia also deserves this opportunity.
I would like, in any case, to give a note here a little different from the one given by my colleagues.
I know and share the concern for minorities, but we must not forget the Serbian majority. It is essential that the Serbs themselves have a place in the European Union and a full place.
This cannot be forgotten.

There will be no peace in the Balkans without Serbia. And therefore, as much as we emphasize the rights of minorities and they must be respected, we cannot forget the Serbian majority, its identity and its full right to be European citizens, equal to all others, with their own State and their own national pride.
Thank you, Mr. President. Last week, Portugal voted on the Treaty, or rather, the Budget Ultimatum, which is not, in fact, a European Treaty. It is good to refer to it.

The favorable vote of the government parties reflects the accumulation of decades and decades of stupidity and a typical attitude of the good student, a sycophant, who does not think and obeys the bad teachers.
The position of the PS and its leader was to move from a very dangerous violent abstention to a crawling vote in favor.

This alliance makes our Assembly of the Republic, the Portuguese one, the first Parliament to accept the humiliation of amputating one of its most important functions for which the people elected it, to decide annually the country's budget.
This is yet another blow from the European Union, another one. It is a blow in which the power of money is increasingly out of reach of the citizens' vote.
And I ask, Mr. President, is it democratic for someone to vote so that no one can vote anymore? Thank you.
Fiscal consolidation is imposing almost unbearable demands on some European citizens.
However, every day there are fewer people who have to bear a greater burden.
The tax burden falls on workers, small and medium-sized businesses, consumers, and meanwhile there is a completely disproportionate tax evasion and avoidance.
The European Socialist Group wanted to know how much this tax evasion was worth in the 27 countries. And it is worth one trillion euros.
This is more than what the European Union countries spend on health.

This means such a volume that if we spent only a fifth of this value in investment, the investment would rise in Europe from 2.7% of GDP to 3.5%. We are therefore talking about an exceptionally high value.

And the purpose of the resolution that we are going to approve, initiated by this Parliament, is precisely a very clear demand to the Commission and to the Council that they accelerate the concrete action to combat tax evasion and fraud.

This means, in particular, concrete initiatives of fiscal cooperation within the European Union, of fiscal cooperation with our neighboring countries, particularly Switzerland, but negotiated by the Commission and not country by country in a bilateral manner.
This means reforming and harmonizing accounting rules, increasing transparency and reporting.
This clearly means reactivating the fundamental issue of combating fraud and tax evasion through tax havens.
Europe is not a minor partner.
Europe is a great partner in the international context.
Europe has the obligation, within the G20, to clearly defend a common fight against tax fraud and evasion.

Without this, we lose credibility with our citizens and therefore my last words in this debate are to encourage the Commission and the Council to start an effective fight against fraud and tax evasion. Thank you very much.

Thank you, Mr. President. I start by congratulating colleague Niebler for the excellent work and point out the coincidence that on Europe Day, which we celebrate today, we debate and tomorrow approve measures that meet the legitimate aspirations of our citizens.
What is at stake in this regulation is to impose limits on mobile phone rates charged to European consumers when roaming, with the main objective of ending roaming in the European space as of 2016.
Our citizens will benefit from a significant drop in prices regarding calls, SMS and data.
If today there are operators that charge 3 euros per mega, from July the maximum price they will be able to charge will be 70 cents per mega, with this value going down to 20 cents in 2014.
As for the calls received, the maximum price that can be charged will be 8 cents this year and 5 cents in 2014.
In July 2012, a family with two mobile phone users will save, as the Commissioner said, 200 euros on their bill.
Second benefit: better quality of information to consumers.
Starting this summer, operators will be required to inform consumers of the prices charged when they travel outside the European Union as well.
Until now, the obligation was only within the European space.
Third advantage: the possibility of more operators entering the market, which means increased competition that will stimulate better services and better prices.

In the near future, the consumer will be able, if they so wish, to have two contracts, one for services in the national territory and another for services abroad, keeping the same mobile number and having only one bill.
Will the consumer, our citizen, also be given the possibility of contracting with any European operator that offers the best price?
This report is the perfect example of the Europe of citizens, the Europe of freedom of movement and freedom of establishment. Thank you very much.
Madam President, in February 2009, this Parliament approved a report where it supported the European Commission's proposal to relaunch the European economy.
There were projects for clean energy, transport, new technologies, innovation and, at that time, the role of the European Investment Bank and the structural funds was already being outlined.
More than three years have passed and we have been able to produce the Six-Pack, the Euro Plus Pact, the Fiscal Pact, the Two-Pack, all of them full of reinforced discipline and sanctions.

But meanwhile, while unemployment, especially among young people, reaches frightening levels, the European economy is in recession and more than seven of its member countries are experiencing negative growth.
Meanwhile, while Greece is nothing more than the first stone that threatens to bring down the castle, the relaunch agenda seems to have been forgotten.
At this moment, this agenda is clear.
What matters at this moment is no longer to attribute it an urgent character, but an emergency character, in a situation that threatens to explode.
It is necessary to urgently intervene in a set of pillars.
First of all, it is necessary that such a European Marshall Plan be constituted, with investment promoting growth, employment and convergence.
Project bonds are one of the possible sources.
Secondly, it is necessary to stabilize the interest rates at which countries finance themselves.
Let us at least prepare to coordinate the issuance of sovereign debt and manage the accumulated debt together.
Third point. The European Stability Mechanism and the European Central Bank must prepare to function as true fire brigades in the defense of European sovereign debt.
Fourthly, the credit that was massively transferred by the European Central Bank to the commercial banks has to reach the companies.
It is one billion euros that is being held in the banking system, while thousands of viable companies die every day due to lack of funding.
Fifth point. Investment does not make sense without demand.
The most fragile economies are being crushed by austerity plans.
It is the strongest economies that have to free up domestic demand.

is that almost 80% of the exchanges are made today within Europe. And it is up to the Commission, Mr. Commissioner Olleren, to make recommendations directed not only to the most fragile economies, but also to the most dynamic ones.
And lastly, Mr. President, I would like to set a limit on the revenue from taxes imposed by the Troika.

We must say enough to the punitive style, without dialogue and without accountability, with which high officials determine the fate of millions of European citizens and the democratic institutions of member countries. Thank you very much, Mr. President.

Thank you very much, Mr. President, Mr. Minister, Mr. Commissioners. What I wanted to say is very clear. Naturally, the Portuguese deputies of the PPE fully support all measures that can contribute to growth. There is no possibility of...

We cannot get out of this crisis without promoting growth, especially in those States that are most affected by the financial crisis. But sometimes, when I hear some colleagues, I get the feeling that they think that growth can continue with excessive deficits and with bad public accounts.

Now, we must continue to insist on reducing spending and on structural reforms. We can do everything on the growth side, but we cannot abandon the path of containing and reducing public spending and...
More growth cannot be more relaxation, more rest. More growth and more growth policies must go hand in hand with great rigor in public accounts and with great rigor in structural reforms.
If we start talking only about growth and thinking that there are magical solutions for growth, we will end up again with unsustainable public debt and we will continue without structural reforms.

That said, I would like to draw attention to the fact that tomorrow's summit will not only address this long-term or medium-term growth issue. The urgent issue of Greece will be at stake. And I think it is essential that the European States stand, in some way, by Greece.
We are responsible for finding a solution to the Greek problem. And I would like to reject here the statement of the British deputy who spoke of the Portugalization of Europe.
the Portugalization of Europe, at least in terms of values, would not be a negative thing. And therefore, I reject this idea of trying to humiliate or reduce any peoples.
We are all Europe and we all have a place in it.

Thank you very much, Mr. President. Mr. Commissioner, you came here to tell us that every euro more spent on debt is one euro less for job creation. So, explain to us why continue with this obsession.

He came here to tell us that one of the priorities of the Summit is to keep Greece in the Eurozone. And I ask you, Mr. Commissioner, do we believe in ourselves or do we believe in Dr. Durão Barroso or Mr. Trichet, who were saying exactly the opposite a few days ago?
You spoke about the maintenance of the Eurozone, but I ask you, which Euro?

In the euro we live in today, in this area we live in today, or in the euro that was announced yesterday by Deutsche Bank in a study in which it referred to a G-euro, a second-class euro, in case the left wins the elections in June in Greece.
This is a trap, Mr. Commissioner, the trap of a Europe hostage to governments and the trap of a Europe hostage to financial interests.
Let's not allow people to live in fear, because that is not a way to live. Europe can be something else. Sir, you are wise. There is no lack of money, there is a lack of courage.

Mr. President, Mr. Minister Vaman, the first thing I would like to declare is that it is regrettable that in a debate of this importance the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative, Ms Ashton, is not present.
In any case, we are pleased to work again with Mr. Minister Vaman, who made a statement here in which I fully agree.

I would like, first of all, to give a word of comfort and solidarity to the Guinean people, which has basically been the people of Guinea-Bissau, a people systematically massacred by democratic instability, political instability and great insecurity.
Already surrounded by poverty, it has been systematically affected by these evils.

I would like to say, on the other hand, that the PPE, in its presidency, has been following this issue from the beginning. And it is also regrettable that the European Parliament only manages to have a debate on this matter at the end of a month.
This has to do with the invisibility of the Guinean people and the Guinean question.

And this invisibility must be due to the fact that, unlike other matters, also very serious, there are no major economic interests at stake here that would motivate European, American and world powers to debate the situation of the Guinean people.
But I must say, if it is necessary, the reason is external, if misery and political instability are not enough for us to have a global humanitarian and political action, there is...
