Not to mention the drug trafficking situation that plagues Guinea and directly affects European and American peoples, which would be a reason for us to focus on this.
And for this reason, I ask here that the European Union be stronger.

There is no doubt that Resolution 2048, there is no doubt that the decisions of the European Union, of the Community of Portuguese Language Countries, of the African Union, but perhaps not of the Economic Community of West African States, are going in the right direction.
But resolutions are not enough, actions are needed.
We must be firmer, we must be more effective together with the States that have the capacity to intervene in Guinea-Bissau.
This is our duty.

And I believe that the European Union, at this moment, is responding well in terms of principles, but it is not responding as it should in terms of practical instruments, of operation on the ground, and that is what I ask of the Council and ask of the Commission.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, globalization has brought with it a disproportionate growth of the financial sector, whose transactions are today, as is known, 70 times greater than global wealth.

The opacity, the very frequent transactions, the high remunerations, the very high risk ended up not only characterizing the world we live in today, but also being fundamental reasons for the crisis we are going through.
However, this crisis has demanded more accountability and effort from ordinary citizens than from the sector that caused it.
So, today, this moment is important.

It is important, and I would personally like to obtain a situation in which the tax would be generalized in all the countries of the European Union and subsequently extended to the rest of the world, through an active participation of the Commission and of the European Union in general, in the context of the G20.
I would like it to cover all products, without exception.
I would like it to serve as a basis for the necessary reinforcement of the European Union's own resources.
In the short term, we have to accept compromises, but we must not lose sight of where we need to go.
And this can only be achieved with a clear identification of these objectives by this Parliament, by the Commission and with a great spirit of commitment by the Council.

This is what European citizens expect from us today and I can only thank here today the role not only of Annie Podimata, who was tireless in this process, but also of all those who managed to overcome the divergences to reach a common position.

Thank you, Mr. President. Thank you, colleague Podimata. Today we are discussing here, for the first time, the tax on financial transactions and, if approved, it will be the first sign that speculation will not go totally unpunished in this crisis we are living.
This House and the European institutions must answer to people and not to financial markets.
For decades, the financial markets lobbies have managed to govern the world without opposition and without any problems.
It is obvious to us that during 2008 and 2012, the speculative financial market crisis was at the root of most of the problems we faced.

And yet, these speculative financial markets managed not only to ensure that nothing was done, but also that a transfer was made directly from the pockets of citizens to these same speculative markets.

We have been fighting for this for many years, Mr. President. But it was only when the people, a little bit all over Europe, started saying enough, that finally there was some initiative on the part of the institutions that govern the European Union.
And therefore, this is the answer we must give to the citizens. It is the first sign we must give them.
The citizens of Europe, who have everything paid for, do not deserve to be disrespected.
And therefore, this proposal is not complete, it is not perfect, it will not solve the entire problem of financial speculation, but it is an important sign.
We have been, not us, the European leaders have been asking for forgiveness from the financial markets.
They should apologize to the people they have affected.
And quoting, to conclude, Mr. President, a famous politician today, we are talking about these markets, the markets that govern us without ever having been elected.

I sincerely hope that the governments give a sign of confidence to the people and I sincerely hope that with this approval and with the positive vote of the colleagues we start talking about justice and solidarity in Europe.
Colleagues, muster up courage, let's get this project approved.
Thank you, Mr. President. The tax on financial transactions should work as a way to control and discourage speculative activities with high risk in the financial sector.
It aims to reduce speculation and increase healthy competition, the basis of the single market, and also generate revenue.

The Podimata report tried to bring the initial proposal of the European Commission closer to the well-known Stamp Tax of the United Kingdom. Thus, we made this proposal more attractive to the reluctant Member States.
It is hoped that the Council will also understand the message.

If the Commission's proposal applied the tax to transactions of financial institutions located in the territory of the European Union, it is now intended that transactions of European assets, even if carried out by non-Europeans, are also taxed.
This measure will broaden the revenue base and reduce leakages.
It is expected that the tax revenues will be considered as a source of own resources of the Union or of the States, reducing the taxes of the Member States, a matter still to be decided.
I conclude, Mr. President, congratulating the rapporteur for the quality of the work and I hope that this symbolic text...
Madam President, this weekend we had another request to save the private bank.

They continue to say the same argument, which is to avoid contagion to the Eurozone. And what I ask is if we don't learn anything. Greece, Portugal, Ireland and now Spain, and yet the contagion continues.
But what kind of containment of contagion is this that is destroying us?

This policy does not work, we should already know that. It is the same rulers who say there is no money for culture, education, health, public goods, who, when the banks or the markets ask for it, make it appear almost as if by a miracle.
This economic policy is not a remedy, it is a deadly poison for growth, for employment, for the European economy, for social Europe.
The markets order and the governments obey and blackmail the people. And that is what the governments are doing to Greece at this moment, during the election period.

I sincerely hope that it is in all of our best interests that the Greek people do not allow themselves to be blackmailed next Sunday and that they teach us a lesson, because this recipe, Madam President, is a recipe for disaster. Thank you very much.

Thank you very much, Mr. President, dear colleagues. Unfortunately, the proposals we are discussing here today confirm the prohibition of anti-crisis policies in the Eurozone and further concretize the logic of the Fiscal Treaty.

There are some statements of intent, but they are very timid. I refer, for example, to the agenda for one day to start thinking about ways to define possible legislation for the hypothetical introduction of eurobonds.
The problem is that this day will only come when all the problems of the Eurozone are solved and it is taking a long time to arrive.
We support some aspects of this proposal, but at this pace, everything will be too little and too late.
Placing a country under legal protection implies maintaining the rates and amounts, as well as the priority of new loans. In other words, it is required to...
Member States that honour their debt, but have all the instruments that could allow them to grow and find the resources to do so taken away from them.

Let's be frank with each other. The only legal protection that exists in these proposals and that is foreseen is for the creditors. But even these will not be solved, because it is not effective for them either.

As we have seen in Greece, Ireland, Portugal and now in Spain, this means condemning countries to recession, unemployment and insolvency. And I finish, Mr. President, by saying that the worsening of these situations and their spread to other economies brings us closer to a point of no return.

Faced with the complete failure of austerity, the European Commission or the German government propose the same policy to us, but in an overdose regime. It is neoliberal fanaticism that is killing the euro.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. With the extremely limited time we have, I want to say at this moment to the Commission that it can count, as it has always counted, on this Parliament.
Parliament in effective work in favor of the solidity of the Eurozone and of Europe, but that this is only achieved when the initiatives that focus on discipline, we

We have managed to add the conditions for a balanced sharing of gains and sacrifices among the different Member States and among the different citizens and a hope, a hope that we will get out of the crisis we are going through.
For this hope to exist, other initiatives are needed, and these are the ones that this Parliament is trying to fill, an initiative aimed at investment, growth and control.
of the sovereign debt that has been the Achilles heel, obviously, which reflects the fragility of the economic systems of some of the member countries.
Mr. Commissioner, you can count on us, Council, Madam President, you can count on us, but the agenda must be a comprehensive agenda. It cannot be an agenda that...
Discipline is not the condition for everything else to follow, nor does it make discipline the alpha and omega of our European proposals.

Our citizens expect this from us, they can count on Parliament and I want to thank again the colleagues, the rapporteurs, Mr. Gozés, who is another rapporteur, and all the colleagues who, as shadow rapporteurs or merely active elements in the construction of this project, were able to contribute.
For a more balanced and solid project of the Parliament, and that I hope deserves respect, the capacity for dialogue and the spirit of construction and compromise that it has had until now.
Thank you very much, Mr. President, thank you very much, Madam President, thank you very much, Mr. Commissioner.

Thank you very much, Madam President. Besides thanking everyone who contributed to this result, I would like to ask that the final vote be postponed so that we can negotiate immediately at the Trilogue level.
Today, the EU is faced with three agendas: the growth agenda, the agenda regarding the management of banks and the agenda regarding the management of sovereign debt.
And dealing with the European semester implies including these three dimensions.
Regarding the issue of growth, I think that at this moment it is important to emphasize that the Commission's recommendations cannot only focus on...
Countries with deficits must also impact on countries with surpluses. And if some have to reduce their internal demand, others have to free it.

I also think that, in terms of growth, it is essential that the Commission controls the recommendations of the so-called Troika. Because when a country goes into recession, it cannot continue to crush its public investment, to crush public spending as if nothing had happened.
The troika must have its recipe reviewed and adjusted according to the results. And I want to tell you, Mr. Commissioner, that we have approved today, here in the...
The Parliament, the need to immediately launch an instrument for growth and for the countercyclical activity of the order of 1% of the EU's GDP for 10 years.

A second dimension, which is fundamental, is the dimension of what is now called the Banking Union. We asked in Parliament for this to be done two years ago, in a report from June 2010. Until now, it is being implemented.

A third dimension is the dimension of sovereign debt. Without it, there is no stability in Europe. And I also want to tell you that today we approved the TUPAC here, but we introduced into the TUPAC, in addition to austerity,

some other dimension that has been missing. And it is the immediate establishment of a redemption fund, using the German terminology, so that the sovereign debt that exceeds 60% can be managed together.

This is a legislative text and we await the good support of the Commission to this initiative of the Parliament, so that we can control the completely threatening spiral that is currently destroying the European Union. Thank you very much.

Thank you very much, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues. Now that we intend to discuss a growth pact, it is essential not to forget the citizenship and the consumers, in the end, the human and social dimension.

which gives it substance and which was the theme of one of the three reports on the Single Market Act of 2001. Because any growth pact must take into account the sacrifices and social benefits associated with it,

As important as an internal market test will be to carry out a social impact test of all the measures taken to implement the single market. A test, yes, an examination that allows us to measure the progress made for the benefit of the citizens of the European Union.
Since 2008, Europe has already lost more than 6 million jobs.
In my country, Portugal, the economy is suffering a contraction that is unprecedented and unemployment among men, women and young people has reached historic records.
According to the Bank of Portugal's forecasts, the situation will worsen over the next two years.
It is in this context that we support and welcome the initiative of the new employment package and congratulate Commissioner Andor.
Insisting now and always on the basic premise of the need for economic growth, the Member States will really have to focus their efforts on job creation.

The means for this should go through subsidies for hiring that create new jobs, by reducing the tax burden on work and support for the creation of new companies and entrepreneurship, but also for small and medium-sized companies that maintain jobs.

It is essential that national employment policies should take into account that the areas with the greatest potential for job creation are health, information and communication technologies and the green economy.
As the communication states, it is urgent to reduce the gap between the qualifications provided by education and the skills demanded by the job market.
On the other hand, one of the solutions to combat unemployment is through the mobility of workers.
It is also crucial that the use of structural funds for job creation and the practical importance of the EURES portal as the best recruitment tool and job offers in Europe.
Finally, social governance must be on the agenda because our citizens eagerly await concrete results. Thank you very much.

Thank you very much, Madam President, Mr. Commissioner. It is true that six months have already passed since this scandal with the PIP occurred. And the most incredible thing is that for ten years a private company could have...
to operate in the market and to have introduced silicone implants that should have been destined for the construction and manufacture of mattresses and were used in women in 71 countries.
This affected hundreds of thousands of women, as already mentioned, it is estimated that around 500 thousand.

Now we are talking about estimates because there were failures and there were serious failures in this process. We know that what happened with this company is a criminal case, it is a fraud, it is a court case, but we also know...

There is a fraud here that must be controlled by the courts and the courts will deal with it. But there is a legal failure, there is a legal vacuum and we must deal with it. We have responsibilities in this matter.

For 10 years, we were unable to identify what criminals were able to identify. And so there was a gap in terms of control, in terms of traceability, in terms of archives, in terms of records, everything failed. But these gentlemen from this company were able to put into practice what we were unable to control. And that is why...

In this process, there is not only the issue of lack of information, which is very important, in fact, the lack of information in all matters related to breast implants, but also the humiliation of thousands of women and the humiliation, in particular, of those women who had to submit to tests to find out if they had the correct implants or not.

We are talking about a public health issue and we cannot be lax about public health. We control so many unnecessary things. We even control the authenticity of spare parts in cars. Not long ago we approved a directive on this.

We have to control what is fundamental to people's lives. The revision of the medical devices directive is good news, it would be better news if we didn't have to do it. But now that we are going to do it, let's do it with...

Conditions with traceability, transparency, control, sanctions, because unfortunately, the sanctions, even if applied, will not be applied to the women who suffered from this problem, and the States must assume full responsibility.

Thank you, President. I would like to state very clearly that, for us, the Council that will take place at the end of June is fundamental. And that what is essential is that a European solution is sought for this crisis.
From our point of view, the problem so far is that we have been dealing with each of the issues that arise in isolation and individually.

The time has come for us to have a global solution for Europe. A solution that, as President Dole has made very clear here, involves more integration, more cooperation, greater alignment of European policies and a revaluation of the community method.
It is essential that, alongside stability, there is growth, but that we do not abandon our concerns about stability.
We therefore have a global European response and not a divided response for each State or for each region that is in difficulty.
The productive and more possibilities of production caused considerable increases in the milk produced, creating critical situations, excesses and low prices in the milk and dairy market.

In many regions with high productive potential, these surpluses were sold at bargain prices in the markets of other countries, further increasing the downward pressure on the prices paid to producers in these countries.

This happened, for example, with French milk, sold in France at double the price it was sold in Galicia. And the producers, with the increase in the cost of raw materials and production factors, saw their ability to withstand low prices extremely reduced today.

This is a bad omen for many explorations and many productive territories in Europe and it seems to be also a clear omen of what will come to be the future without quotas and without adequate supply regulation instruments.

Therefore, it is necessary to conduct a detailed audit on the territorial impacts in thousands of locations throughout the European Union of the abolition of these instruments that we currently have to regulate supply.
Thank you, Mr. President. I would like to start by congratulating the colleague rapporteur for this report.
This is a matter of extreme importance to Europe.
At a time when we are experiencing a serious economic, financial and social crisis, protecting intellectual property rights by combating counterfeit products is essential for the European economy.

This protection should strengthen the performance of research and promote innovation. It should ensure scientific and technological knowledge, contributing to the development of new products and services.
All this in the sense of generating growth and creating quality jobs.

Unfortunately, in recent years we have witnessed a significant increase in the violation of intellectual property rights in Europe, which represent annual losses, as already mentioned here, of 250 billion euros for companies and the destruction of 185 thousand jobs in the European space.

But beyond these negative effects on the European economy, the violation of these rights also constitutes a serious threat to the health and safety of European consumers, since many counterfeit products, such as food, cosmetics, medicines, etc.
etc. are produced in unregulated environments.
For this reason, the customs authorities of the European Union play a crucial role in preventing counterfeit products from entering the internal market.
With the revision of the current regulation, it is intended to strengthen the control of the application of the legislation in question, strengthen the legitimacy of its intervention, increase the
Legal clarity by adapting the provisions of the Regulation to the new realities and developments, thus contributing to better protection of the European economy and consumers.
Intellectual property rights are thus a crucial priority to achieve the objectives of the 2020 Strategy in the sense of achieving smart, sustainable and inclusive growth. Thank you very much.

Thank you, Mr. President. Indeed, the election of a new Egyptian president in the post-Mubarak era is good news. But we cannot delude ourselves, these presidential elections do not close in any way what is the transition process that is taking place in Egypt.

It was well said that the dissolution of Parliament days before the presidential elections puts several risks on the table. And in this case, the power that is concentrated in the Superior Council of the

The Armed Forces are at least exaggerated. They have legislative power, reduce the power of the President and, in addition, they still have in their hands the definition of changes in the Constitution.

Now, all this raises some concerns and should raise some concerns, because the Egyptians risk being hostages to the military power and to a return to the past, with the lack of a fundamental element, which is the democratically elected Parliament.
It is not up to us to make the change in Egypt, it is up to the Egyptians.
But I think that we Europeans will have to be alongside all the changes that propose the restoration of what is democratic legitimacy and of a democratically elected Parliament. Thank you very much.

Thank you very much, Madam President, dear colleagues, Madam Commissioner. I would like to start by congratulating the rapporteur colleague, Lara Comi, for the excellent work developed in this report, which is of vital importance for the future of Europe.
In a world and in a society in accelerated transformation, Europe needs a comprehensive, integrative, effective and updated standardization system.
A system that ensures the proper functioning of the internal market, that improves the protection of consumers and their lives, but also that protects the environment, is essential.

It is also very important to have more innovation and social inclusion and the interaction and communication of networks and systems, especially in the field, as already mentioned here, of new information and communication technologies.
As Professor Monti referred to in his report, a new strategy for the single market, European standardization is essential for the governance of the internal market, highlighting
The need to review the European standardization process, which maintains the advantages of the current system and which finds the fair balance between the European and national dimensions.

In this sense, the report that we are now discussing follows and defends these objectives, which are the correct and appropriate ones. Ending the slowness and fragmentation that exists and that makes companies incur costs

of transaction and in higher unit costs, reinforce the participation of SMEs in standardization activities, particularly at the national level, as well as facilitate their access to these standards, also strengthen

On the other hand, the participation of the parties that represent the interests of society, such as consumers, environmentalists, workers, people with disabilities, maintaining the financial support to the European organizations created to represent the public interests.

I conclude by saying that the approval of the present report will contribute to the relaunch of the European project, to European innovation, to the strengthening and competitiveness of our companies. Thank you very much.
Thank you very much, Mr. President, Madam Commissioner. The future Common Fisheries Policy must prioritize its environmental, economic and social sectors.
in a synergic and non-hierarchical way, in favor of sustainable development and in accordance with the objectives of smart, sustainable and inclusive growth of the EU 2020 strategy.
As the rapporteur of the third regime, I would like to highlight the particularity of some regions, such as the outermost regions, whose economies are heavily dependent on the tourism sector.

In these regions, the reform of the Common Fisheries Policy should seek to ensure the survival and future prosperity of their artisanal and small-scale fishing fleets, thus safeguarding and defending the jobs that depend on them.

I agree with the position of the European Commission regarding the need for an adjustment of this policy and specific measures that must take into account the different realities of the fishing and aquaculture sector in the various coastal regions.

I defend that this policy places the focus on regionalization as a form of governance, through a reinforcement of the participation of the various interested parties, so that it is possible in the future a more adequate response to the demands and sensitivities of each maritime basin.
We are reaching the decisive moments in which we will shape the new fisheries policy in Europe. And we cannot fail.

The need and urgency to achieve sustainable balances in our fisheries resources, but also in the revitalization of our coastal fishing communities and in the promotion of their socio-economic level, in the modernization of the sector and in the supply of quality food, require, more than ever, courage and bold measures.
We must therefore make choices and prioritize objectives.

I proposed protection for the fragility of my region, proposing that the exploration of its resources be done taking into account the scientific data and giving priority to our coastal communities in its exploration and restricting external access to more than 100 miles to the existing fishing banks.
I propose to safeguard the fishing capacity of our important fishing communities, rejecting the proposals for transferable quotas.

I propose that our communities have better intervention in the management of their fishing affairs with the creation of a Regional Advisory Council more suitable for the ultra-peripheral regions. I hope that this way we can have a better future.

Taking into account what we know about the application of the third package, and part of this issue has already been discussed today, regarding the delay in the transposition of its directives, as far as I know, the last information I have is that...

that 18 Member States were notified, probably this information is already outdated, due to lack of transposition. The question I ask you is, how do you see the possibility of, in the legislation that is being prepared, namely the trans-European networks,
trans-European, including a device, an incentive that conditions, a conditionality for the presentation of PCIs, of projects of common interest, or what is

It conditions the compliance by Member States with the obligations arising from the third package. Or, on the contrary, do you understand that this is an extravagant mechanism and that it should be left only to the regular competition mechanisms, Article 101?
601 and its neighbors, all the intervention in this matter. Thank you very much.
The will of the Commission and the tolerance, the spirit of tolerance that has existed in this matter. But the question is to know if, being in preparation, legislation that can
Introducing an additional and much stronger conditionality, do you understand that this conditionality is an abusive instrument or do you think that this conditionality would be acceptable?
I confess that I share the concern that was initially presented here about the democratic legitimacy and democratic control that are related to this proposal of the...

The Banking Union and Banking Supervision, because it remains to clarify and to solve an essential issue, which is the role of Parliament, the only institution democratically elected by the citizens, directly.

But there is another concern that I also have, which is a fundamental concern, and it has to do with the following. The instruments of monetary policy are controlled by the European Union. Monetary policy is the responsibility of the European Union.

Banking supervision also becomes the responsibility of the European Union. However, if everything goes wrong, if the banks go bankrupt, the responsibility for paying for this bankruptcy remains with the taxpayers of the national states, it remains a national responsibility.

This is not a problem of lesser importance, it is a fundamental problem that is not solved. And lastly, I would just like to point out that the fact that we continue to tie monetary policy to what is a secondary issue in the context we live in, which is inflation, and not to job creation and growth, as it should be, is also not solved. Thank you very much.

Thank you very much, Mr. President. European leaders continue to insist on budgetary discipline and I ask, budgetary discipline, so let's go to it. Because what exactly are we talking about when we talk about budgetary discipline?

In my opinion, budgetary discipline is respecting the contracts with pensioners and not abandoning the State's commitments halfway. In my opinion, budgetary discipline is respecting the contracts of those who work and not inventing extraordinary taxes or cuts in subsidies.

Fiscal responsibility is to respect commitments in health, education, culture and not to close services or to end and cancel projects halfway. Discipline is to put banks in order and not to go and take from taxpayers to put in the hands of speculators to save their banks.
This is the budgetary discipline that I would like to see implemented in the European Union and not continue in this market party.

If you need an example, the budget that is being discussed in Portugal, at the hands of the Troika, is a perfect example. It violates all the commitments that any State must have with its citizens, so as not to violate the agreements made behind closed doors that are uniting Europe and its countries.

Thank you very much, Mr. President, Mr. President of the Council, Mr. President of the Commission. First of all, I would like to congratulate the Council's results. Although it seems to me that it is a bit delayed in time, the final decision comes a bit late.
The truth is that there is progress.
Now, precisely because I am reviewing everything that my colleague Cassio Lides said, I would like to ask the Council President just one question. The countries that are under assistance...
The countries that are in trouble have fought a lot for there to be a retroactive application of bank debts in their separation from State debt.
This apparently was not accepted.
But yesterday we heard statements from the highest German and French authorities saying that they would treat Ireland as a special case.
What I ask is if the Council approved any decision of discriminatory treatment for Ireland, different from that which is reserved for countries like Portugal, Greece, Spain and others.
Mr. President, dear colleagues, Mr. Commissioner, it is a privilege to present the report on the 20 concerns of citizens and companies.
Regarding the operation of the single market, precisely in this debate with Commissioner Barnier, in which the 20th anniversary of this market is marked.
A first word to thank the colleagues of all political groups and, in particular, the rapporteurs and the shadow rapporteurs for their very constructive contributions and their very positive attitude.
It was a pleasure to work with everyone and the report greatly benefited from our joint effort.

We know well and we are proud that, over these 20 years, the single market has been the engine of great economic and labor opportunities in Europe, which have transformed the lives of European citizens and European companies.
Traveling, residing and working in the Union space are freedoms that are within the reach of all citizens of the 27 Member States.
For European consumers, the single market means more freedom of choice and lower prices.
For our companies, the single market means more business opportunities with access to 500 million consumers, which means more economic growth and more job creation.
To illustrate the progress that the Single Market has brought to Europe since its creation in 1992 until the beginning of the crisis in 2008,
In 2008, just look at the 2.7 million jobs created and the additional 2.13% growth in GDP.
Today, making or receiving a phone call while traveling in Europe is 13% cheaper than in 2005.
The freedom of movement of people has its most eloquent expression in the Erasmus program.
More than 2.5 million students benefited from this European education and mobility exchange program.
In the last five years, companies have also benefited from a 25% reduction in administrative charges due to the Single Market legislation.
But a question arises: is everything going well in the single market?
No, not everything works well.
The economic and financial crisis that affects us has had negative effects on the functioning of this market.

Our citizens, in some countries, living with the drama of unemployment and being confronted with austerity measures, have come to have a skeptical view of Europe and a negative view of the internal market.
People still do not know or do not understand their rights sufficiently, nor do they know where to find information or help.
On the other hand, many Member States unjustifiably delay the transposition of directives and European legislation on the single market, thus harming its full potential.

In certain areas of citizens' daily lives, such as, for example, the reimbursement of medical expenses after a temporary stay in another country of the Union, the opening of a bank account for a student of the Erasmus programme,

Erasmus, changing energy suppliers, transferring retirement pensions, the recognition of qualifications and the registration of a vehicle in another Member State are still very complex, difficult or costly procedures.
It is important to respond to these problems.
That was my concern as a reporter.
That is why the message written in the report is very clear. It is necessary to have more political will, much more political will from the Member States and the European institutions.

Council, above all Council and Commission, to govern better and together. It is necessary to reconquer the trust of people and companies and it is necessary to facilitate the exercise of their rights.

Finally, I take this opportunity to greet the European Commission, in the person of Commissioner Barnier, for the presentation of the Act for the Market 2, 12 priority actions for a new growth, which marks, I am sure, a new stage for the future. Thank you very much.
Madam President, Commissioner Barnier, and dear colleague Regina Bastos, my congratulations for your efforts, which have already been so successful.
When Jacques Delors was president of the European Commission, the Single Market of the Union was created in 1992.
Delors then synthesized the three basic principles of the single market: competition that stimulates, cooperation that reinforces and solidarity that unites.
Twenty years later, the economic and financial crisis has brought back the threat of national protectionism and it has become clear that the internal market is not a completed work.
The celebration of these 20 years must be used to relaunch the single market, with the concern of putting the market at the service of the citizen and not the citizen at the service of the market.
For this, priorities must be defined. I would like to talk about a particular priority.
It is essential to have a common policy to produce and distribute energy at affordable prices for the consumer, with a high level of energy efficiency.
Through the European energy market, served by cross-border infrastructures with the possibility of community leverage of the investment that represents added European value.
In energy, Madam President, the common market will also be judged.
One of the greatest achievements of the European Union, which certainly represents one of the strongest pillars of the development of the Union, of its Member States and of its regions.

However, in order to be effective and fair, it is necessary to emphasize its policies in the sense of equality of opportunities for citizens and all regions, promoting the internal cohesion of the Union.

In this context, it is essential to recognize that we can only achieve greater development in our most remote regions, such as the outermost regions, through their greater integration into the single market.

Regions like the Azores need to continue to increase their competitiveness by improving their competitive conditions. But we will never be able to do it if we do not better solve our accessibility problems in the transport areas.
We can achieve it through specific instruments that better respond to the problems raised by our distance.

We understand, therefore, that the Commission should consider a specific program, such as the one for transport, as an essential instrument for the integration of these types of regions in the internal market.
Thank you very much, Madam President. I would like to start by saying thank you very much for this excellent debate.
It was a very constructive debate and it was a debate that demonstrated that the single market is really a great achievement of the European project.
I welcome the presence of Minister Mavroiannis and his participation in this debate. I thank all colleagues for their constructive stance, some with a skeptical stance, which is understandable.

And to say thank you very much to Commissioner Barnier for the commitment and enthusiasm he puts into discussing these issues, these problems of the internal market and the political will to solve them.
We still have a lot to answer to the citizens.
Citizens are dissatisfied, disillusioned and expect more from us, expect more from the Council, expect more from the Commission, expect more from the Member States.
This balance is very useful, this 20-year balance is important, but as many have said here, it is important to open the door to the future.
And the future outlook involves many issues that have been raised here and many measures that have already been announced by the European Commission.
The digital single market, the mobility of citizens, the reform of the EURES portal, the European energy market are examples.
eloquent that we still have an important path to follow in the future and that this path is very important and vital to respond to this time of crisis that we are living.
Citizens are suffering, citizens expect a lot from politicians and from the answers that politicians can give to the adverse conditions they are suffering.
That is why it is important that the single market is one of the answers to the great challenge of competitiveness, employment and economic growth.
I am sure that all of us, after this 20th anniversary celebration, are better equipped to provide the answers our citizens need. Thank you very much.

The Gozés report, together with the report that we will elaborate on the annual growth prospects of the Union at the end of this year, and which will be submitted to the Spring Council, are two essential pieces of the so-called European Semester.
This report addresses the recommendations made to each of the Member States by the Council, under the proposal of the Commission. And these recommendations fit, as has just been said, with the...
The Six-Pack and the future Two-Pack, an extraordinarily strong body that reinforces European control over the economic and budgetary policy of the Member States.

The balance between this control and national autonomy and legitimacy is not easy to find. It has fallen to a level of imposition, especially of discipline, and ultimately may even result in a serious package of sanctions.

Regarding the Tupac, I would like to briefly comment that it is important that the Council, which is absent today, gives a negotiating mandate to its negotiators compatible with the ambition to quickly conclude this package, this Tupac.

But more European coordination, returning to the topic, means less control of the countries over their own destiny, which requires a subtle balance, but also an increased demand for the quality of the recommendations made to the countries in at least three or four dimensions.

First, it is important to ensure the consistency between the medium and long-term objectives, which include growth, employment and real convergence, and the short-term recommendations, focused mainly on discipline and nominal convergence. Second, it is necessary to ensure consistency

with the conclusions that should be drawn from the analysis of macroeconomic imbalances, in particular, on the asymmetric impact of common policies and the negative externalities, the spillover effects of some national policies on other countries.

Thirdly, we must agree that there is a minimum threshold of social, economic and labor rights that cannot be exceeded by these recommendations. And lastly, it is important that the quality of the recommendations is assessed based on the results achieved, which has not been the case so far.

I will finish now, Madam President. I would like to thank Mr. Gozés for his spirit of collaboration and hope that he will take one more step in this spirit, in order to broaden the consensus around his report and that this spirit will also remain in what concerns the next...
It is true, and it has been mentioned many times, that there are many things we do not know about shale gas extraction.
But there are also many that we already know and it is not right to forget them.

We know, for example, that each shale gas extraction operation uses more than 19 million liters of drinking water, which is enough to supply 1,000 European citizens for a year in terms of their needs.
We also know that each shale gas extraction operation pumps 300 tons of chemicals into the soil, and about 80% of these chemicals remain in the soil and do not leave it.

We also know that in each extraction of shale gas, radioactive elements and heavy metals are released underground, which, together with the evaporation of the toxic waste resulting from the process, constitute an effective threat to public health.
This is a risk of contamination of drinking water resources and it is a real and imminent contamination.

Knowing this, we know that shale gas extraction is also an apparently easy answer, which only thinks about the immediate, the industry and the profit, ignoring the populations, the future and the environment.

But this is also the Europe that knows, in this House, that water is an essential, vital and important resource, that knows how to protect the health of citizens and that must protect it, that seeks to make agreements to avoid emissions and to propose energy efficiency because we know that environmental standards are important, as well as health standards.
Therefore, when you don’t know everything, being cautious is the least you can do.
And they may even want to do it, but do not do it in our name or in the name of the citizens who are here for us to represent.
Thank you very much, Mr. President, dear colleagues. In fact, the last few years have shown us how the Economic and Monetary Union did not withstand the crisis.
We also showed that we still had a European institutional architecture full of holes, particularly the institutional architecture of the Euro.
And that is why the report that is presented here and the proposal that is presented is so far above in terms of vision in relation to what is proposed by the governments.

But also, as the reporter said, we are in a field of making political choices and that is why I would like to clarify the reasons why we have some problems and we will not be able to support this report.
First, it has to do with issues related to conditionality.

What we see is that we continue to have a narrative in which there can only be solidarity between the different countries when everything has been fulfilled in terms of the Stability and Growth Plan, in terms of the Intergovernmental Agreement, the Growth Pact.
One euro or more and a set of measures that impose nothing but massive doses of austerity in the peripheries and also a set of restrictive measures that, as we have already seen, are not working.
A second reason has to do with the banking union.

The reporter very well presents the banking supervision mechanism, but it is so necessary that we cannot escape the essential. And the essential here is to escape to the extent that we continue to add up

We have grouped national systems, which means that we are all together in banking policy, we are all together in banking supervision, but we are all separate when something goes wrong and, therefore, the contributors will continue to pay.
And a third note has to do with the issue of common debt and the issuance of eurobonds.
Here, once again, the possibility of issuing common debt is considered, but only when it is already too late.

Because we need the debt as it is now, not only when the deficits and excessive debts have been corrected, because with these policies that we are following, they will never be corrected, on the contrary, they will be increasingly aggravated to the despair of a whole set of populations.

Therefore, Mr. President, I would like to conclude by saying that, despite all efforts, I believe that we have a very clear example here that, together, we could still rise, but divided, we will surely fall. And that is why it was important to have gone even further.
Mrs. Ferreira. Mrs. Ferreira, please. There is always room for improvement, but the support of the European Union has been crucial for Portugal in recent years.
Portugal has transformed itself from a country whose competitiveness was based on cheap labor into a country with highly trained, highly sophisticated labor.
But when the country exports, it is necessary to have conditions to where?

And that is why it is important that some countries that have surpluses open their doors to the re-qualified exports of countries that started with a specialization profile that was absolutely unsustainable.

A final note to say that it is not possible for immigration to be the solution, that the requalified workforce and where the support of the European Union was used is now lost through a massive export of the most qualified to the countries that have the margin to welcome them.
This is dramatic and completely unfeasible for our future. Thank you very much.

Thank you, Mr. President. Small-scale fishing deserves special protection from the Common Fisheries Policy, not only because it promotes socio-economic cohesion and ensures the livelihood of many families, but also because it is a factor in the settlement of these communities along the coastal areas.
Its economic and social sustainability should be an objective, ensuring us a differentiated fishing regime that gives priority of access to resources.
It allows for local management and protects the fishing rights of the fishing professionals of those communities against transferable fishing rights.
It is equally important for its sustainability to pay attention to the water access regime, especially in waters or regions with biogeographic basins.
Seas with a reduced continental shelf and scarce resources concentrated in seamounts and fishing banks that must have protected access.

In a context of liberalization and crisis that weighs on fragile regions, it must also be ensured that products from international trade meet the same requirements as the products that the Union imports.
Thank you, Mr. President, Mr. President of the Council of Ministers, Mr. Commissioner. I will be very brief because I believe that what is at stake here is essentially a political issue.
A financial point. And the question that is raised is the following: whether we want the European Union to make a difference in the context of the crisis or whether we want to worsen the crisis.
Most European countries are currently making a huge effort, from the point of view of their public finances, to overcome the crisis in a competitive way, in a way that can place their countries...

The European Union, on a global scale, has great capacity for competition and rivalry, but it is obvious that without investment there will be no growth and it will not be possible to overcome this crisis.
If the European Union insists on these radical cuts, namely in the cohesion policy and in the common agricultural policy, what this will mean is that the countries that are making a huge...
Without effort, they will not be able to grow and this plan that we have accepted in all countries for the European Union will fail. Good accounts with growth and competitiveness prospects.

The only and great instrument for this is precisely this multi-annual financial framework. And therefore, if we want the European Union to be successful and for its policy to be exemplary for other countries, we must bet on the budget for the financial perspectives.
